job_title: Major Gifts Officer in Seattle, WA
pros: Work-life balance (unless you have a big project, in which case no one is willing to give up a weekend or evening to help you, so good like there). Fantastic athletics program, which gives you the feeling of being at a "real" Division I institution. For some departments, flexible Fridays in the summer. Casual working environment. Beautiful campus. Generous 401K matching and retirement plan. Excellent benefits.
cons: Decisions are made by consensus in large groups. While it's a process that may work for academic departments, trying to run the business aspect of the University in this way is nonsensical. Many, many, many meetings, wasted time and pointless conversations. Casual environment can lead to a lack polish and sophistication to external stakeholders, which translates to missed opportunities. No one answers the phone after 4:00 pm, and the UW lacks a "service" culture found at better institutions, where employees seem to genuinely care about excellence and mission. Titles mean a lot, but the people who hold them often know the least and are afraid to admit it. Junior staff who may be more experienced, or show talent in some areas, are not cultivated to grow. Silo mentality and lack of a sense of teamwork (and again, mission). No one will critique or offer authentic feedback out loud; it's almost considered to be rude to be honest or straightforward. UW calls itself "transparent" but few colleagues share information or collaborate. This place has the potential to rise and become a great place to work and learn, but no one wants to confront the thread of mediocrity that runs through campus. Divergent thinkers will not last here.

job_title: Clinical Laboratory Technician in Seattle, WA
pros:
1. Benefits package okay.
2. Access to many recreational and learning facilities.
3. Good job starting point because you will be exposed to a variety of challenges, such as knowing how to deal with personality conflict, politics and work prioritization.
cons:
1. Worn down employees from the lack of morale.
2. If you bring up concerns, prepare to have them ignored or a cause for reprimand for being a "rabble rouser..."
3. If anything happens to your family that requires the request to exercise the Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA), prepare to get denied repeatedly until you quit or find another way to terminate you.
4. Good people work there and feel hopeless as if this is the only job they will ever find.
5. Heavy political issues.  If you are talented, you pose a threat to management and will never see a promotion...ever.
6. Unless you possess a PhD or MD, your supervisor will never truly address your concerns.

review_title: UW, So many great people, so many big challenges
job_title: Director, Research Computing in Seattle, WA
pros: UW is the major research university for roughly a quarter of the contiguous US land mass. Seattle is a gateway to the Pacific. Its science, engineering, and arts programs have long, distinguished histories. It's medical school is among the best in the world. With all this going for it, UW attracts an amazing, diverse, optimistic student body, faculty, and staff. The regular people at UW make it a rewarding place to make a career.
cons: UW is a state university in the aughties - it's broke. Only ~5% of UW's budget comes from the state budget. More than half of the ~$4B/year overall budget is the hospitals - making UW subsidiary to an enormous medical enterprise with its own agenda. The explosive growth of the CS program has come with substantial leverage - an expensive new building, and a commitment to quadruple the undergrad matriculations without reducing quality. Temporary staff fill more positions, leaving them outside the university family and at risk of sudden termination.

review_title: Great place for students, not so much for staff; overworked, underpaid, and under-represented.
pros: There's a very active and bubbly campus life and students seem to really enjoy it. There's always lots of activities, plays, shows, and events to attend, and as a staff member you can get a pretty nice discount to go to these.
cons:
The politics more than ruin this place.  Sometimes the politics make it downright impossible.  There's plenty of diversity in the lower levels but certainly not in the upper management.  Like a lot of typical government offices, the harder you work, the more work they dump on you, without the compensation to even it out.  Furthermore, don't look to the union to help or protect you.  I often felt marginalized, with nobody to reach out to.  Nowhere have I been around so many people and felt so lonely.  

As for the "opportunities" the upper management knows it's cheaper to move people sideways than up.  They encourage you, from the beginning, to look around at other job opportunities on campus, and hardly a word about how to rise up the ranks in your own office.  Far too much favoritism and politics in a place that is meant to help students.

job_title: Operations Manager, Center for Commercialization in Seattle, WA
pros:
Working for UW was my first job out of college. I worked there for 4 years, with the same department, and truly loved the experience. UW is a very large institution, and while they can't pay as competitively as the private sector, they make sure to take great care of their employees through benefit offerings and associated job perks. 

In addition, I was the youngest person by far to be working in my department. I felt that all of my peers had my best interests in mind and genuinely wanted to support my personal development and opportunities to further my career.
cons: Well, UW is an academic institution and as such they put a heavy emphasis on research (as they should). They are also the #1 federally funded institution in the country, with $1.5B dollars in federal money per year. With that in mind, if you are a not a PhD, JD, or have plans to pursue a higher level degree beyond a bachelors, it becomes very difficult to move up in the ranks. I found myself hitting a significant plateau after about 2 years.

job_title: Student Web Developer in Seattle, WA
pros: Working in a student capacity is a bit different from a full-time position at the University of Washington, but there are a few common generalities I can draw out from my experience which might be helpful. First off, working in any University or center of higher learning is great, because you have no shortage of intelligent human beings around you. The world of academia itself is quite diverse, and working on a campus gives you an opportunity to fully explore all of that diversity. Beyond just working at a particular position, you're free to take any class that might interest you and broaden your horizons, not to mention using a lunch break to sit in on any of the different lectures happening throughout the day all over campus. Finally, the work itself, in most cases, is for a worthy cause. You're either working on projects that are cutting-edge in their respective fields, or are working at a task to help the stalk-holders of an academic institution, ie, the students, the faculty & staff, their respective families, and finally, the community.
cons: I'd say from a tech perspective, professional growth is at a slower pace compared to working at an established tech company.

pros: Great benefits, good community and access to resources

job_title: Computer Support Analyst II in Seattle, WA
pros: Great benefits - including health, retirement, as well as the ability to take courses and degree work for free or discounted.  Generally open environment where people support trying new things.  Also a very commuter-friendly workplace, with showers, bike lockers (often have to be on waiting lists for a while), and bike racks.  Often get to work with interesting people and most I have worked with have been social - lots of happy hours or group events.  Being part of campus also includes local entertainment and on-campus entertainment discounts.  Domestic partner benefits are obtainable.  As long as income isn't your priority, it's a good place to work.
cons: There's not always a push to advance beyond the status quo.  In particular, once you're a permanent employee, it's very difficult to lose your job - which may lead to a less than wonderful set of coworkers.  As a non-corporate entity, your salaries tend to be quite a bit lower than at other organizations unless you're upper management or a researcher.  Lots of older furniture/renovations going on at one place or another so you may not have the most attractive office space.  The Seattle campus never seems to get the adverse weather days that other campuses in the area/region get.

Pathology:  This department is generally laid back and accommodating of life situations (this does not apply to individual advisors, they are very much case-by-case most places you go). cons:
- Pay is low
- Rent is absolutely insane around here now
- Dealing with bureaucratic hurdles is a nightmare at times
- Graduate health insurance coverage is constantly changing and has awful service and a broken website (To give an idea.... the user login has been broken for years for many grad students. I have called several times w/ no solution so I haven't been able to login to view my my plan and costs for several years now.). Beware: They drop your dependants during the Summer unless you pay a lump sum of the Summer insurance cost at the very beginning of Summer. If your dependants are auto-dropped during Summer their medical claims will still accepted because LifeWise and UW don't keep the database up to date. This can leave you in a situation where you have to repay them in full later if you want to keep dependants on your insurance.

review_title: Good place for a part-time teaching job.
pros: The Fund-Raising Management Certificate Program offers interesting teaching opportunities, diverse students (a wide range of age and experience, especially), expert colleagues, and flexibility.  Instructors are given a free hand to teach what and how they think best (though of course we do let the administration know what we're doing). The students are interested, enthusiastic, and bring a lot of their own life experiences to bear on the curriculum.  As adults, they ask questions, don't just accept everything the instructor says, and have lively discussions.  I've been teaching in this program for eight years, and every class I've had has formed strong social bonds among themselves.  The last class is always a little sad for me, because it's hard to say goodbye to this enthusiastic group of people.
cons: As a part-time, part-year contract position, this is not a way to make a living wage. I'm not sure how the pay compares to similar jobs at other universities, but we instructors are not in it for the money.  All the instructors have "day jobs" in the field they teach in--which is a bonus for the students, of course.  The facilities could be improved--we're always lobbying for better rooms.  The scheduling and program change every year, which means constantly reworking the curriculum.

pros: It's very rewarding teaching people, and the staff are all very kind

pros: Friendly work environment, great co-workers. Amazing benefits, if full time you receive 22 vacation days, 14 sick days and 8 paid holidays.  After 1 year of employment you receive free schooling to Washington University. If employed over 7 years you also receive free schooling for your children to Washington University.
cons: Not the most competitive with pay/salary.  I started my career within Washington University making the very low end of an entry level position.  The reason given was my lack of experience.  A year later I was still making my starting pay (there are only yearly reviews in July, first review I only recieved a 1% increase) and was now training new employees.  These employees were being hired in at a level 2 and had no prior experience.  At my next review I was able to be promoted to a level 2, but again at the very end of the pay scale because of how much they had to increase my pay.  The only reason anyone knew about how much anyone made is it's available what range it level makes.

review_title: Software Engineering - Battling the Politics and Budgets of the Government
pros:
*Extremely flexible.  Able to set up multiple WFH days per week.  Infrastructure generally in place to support WFH (not even a VPN - just go right in and RDP to your machine directly)

*Smart, curious, and fun colleagues.  

*Since it's government work, safer to assume that people aren't working here for the money.  As such, when it comes to review time, less backstabbing so higher bonuses can be secured.  Instead, everyone has fewer ulterior motives.  When they do something for you, it's genuine
cons:
*Pay well below private IT industry.  But it's hard to imagine that an applicant would walk in not expecting this

*Bureaucracy is heavy.  Politics brutal.  Expect to work with small budgets and not be able to move at the same pace as technology itself.

*Unmotivated management.  Leadership seems fatigue, especially those that do not continually understand that they are not compensated the same way as the private industry - that is, the reward will be in the form of a contribution to higher education and research, not with money

review_title: Ideal for student seeking a little big of extra spending cash.
pros: I worked for the University while attending as a student. This worked well for several reasons. One, my job is within walking distance from both campus and my residence. Two, management is extremely support of taking time off to work on school projects, homework, study for test or if you just need a break (i.e. flexible work schedule with no real minimum hour requirements). Three, everyone I work with is extremely friendly, positive and nice which creates a non-stressful work environment. Four, some of the tasks you are given are boring and repetitive (e.g. filing, copying, shedding papers, etc.) but sometimes this is a nice mental break from the intellectual rigor that is part of attending a University.
cons: Several reasons come to mind. One is pay. Although a part time student position, I could definitely be making more money waiting tables, bar tending or another similar part time job. Two, there are no benefits such as health care for student assistants. Three as a student assistant there is not good opportunity for advancement or career growth and sometimes I feel other employees don't feel you are as smart as them because you are still a "student". Four, some of the tasks you are given are boring and repetitive (e.g. filing, copying, shedding papers, etc.).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
-Get to work with a large community of very motivated students on really interesting problems. It's an especially great place for environmental sciences.
-Great career services center
-Campus very accessible by bike, bus and light rail
-Entire Seattle transit system is free with U-Pass
-Students with research and teaching assistantships are unionized (this is really important!)
-Good health insurance, which includes dental and (some) vision coverage
-Location in Seattle--great for networking and job opportunities, get to live in a city
-Good work-life balance, at least in my department
cons:
-Have to pay quarterly fees in excess of $300, and the university keeps wanting to raise them--this is the biggest point of contention in our union negotiations. 
-High cost of living, with rents rapidly increasing and stipends not keeping pace. You probably won't be able to afford a place in Fremont or Capitol Hill, where many grad students used to live. 
-As with any grad school, there's always a possibility of having an advisor you don't get along with. Negative stories are relatively rare, but vet your advisor and department carefully before making a decision.

review_title: Top notch research, outdoors, city life, and West Coast.
pros: The UW provides an excellent area to live around and is a top notch academic center.  Being the premier research university in the pacific northwest it attracts the brightest students of the region and some from elsewhere.  Smaller schools and regional business have an excellent incentive to interact,collaborate, and sponsor.  There are plenty of entertainment and dinning options in both the immediate area and the broader Seattle metropolitan region.  The culture of the city blends well with a liberal political view, but gives an outdoorsman closer adventure options then the big universities in the east and California.  The quality of research is world class, while the attitude is West Coast relaxed.
cons: This is still a big university, therefore one person is but a number in the books.  One end does not know where the other tail is.  While everybody is real relaxed the competitions play out hidden even deeper.  It's easy to get lost on campus walking around or looking for your future.

pros: Working with students and really smart people is great. The benefits are terrific.  Education is a worthy cause and the UW is the best around.  Some of the departments are fun to work in and take good care of their employees.
cons: Some departments have revolving doors that drive off talented employees with good track records.   Check the history of the department you are considering joining and ask some hard questions about turnover.  Work your network to learn as much as you can about the group before you sign on.  At least two groups have had notoriously high turnover of experienced women professionals with formidable backgrounds and records of accomplishment.  Also, be aware that, though it is a business school, it does not run like a business.  If you are used to the modern business best practices corporate America has to offer, you won't find them at the Foster School of Business.

pros: Great research, community, and resources

pros: I was extremely excited when I received a job offer from UW.  I've heard great things about being a UW employee and after doing some research on this site, I saw all the positive reviews and thought it was going to be a great place to work.  I was wrong!  After a month, I submitted my resignation. I can't wait to be done working here! To be fair, many of my co-workers have told me to explore opportunities in other departments because things can be very different depending on the area you work in. Maybe I just joined the wrong team and the job wasn't a great fit for me.  Either way, my advice would be ask A LOT of questions during the interview process to ensure you don't end up in this situation!
cons: Does not pay well, archaic systems, unnecessary processes, monotonous work, controlling managers (micro-managing!!!), little autonomy, not a lot of flexibility (regarding work schedule or time-off), extremely formal, tense culture.  In a nutshell, this place operates a lot like many companies did 10 years ago.  They need to step it up and get with the times!

pros: smart people to work with
cons: seattle city winter is bad

review_title: Student Coordinator: A good part-time job for students
pros: A great way to make money and do some work while studying. I worked for Housing & Food Services for South Campus Dining. The pay was very good, you could develop your schedule based around your class schedule and the management and classifieds are generally good people to work with.
cons: There's virtually no oppertunity for promotion beyond a Student Coordinator (granted after a year of service) and there's no oppertunity for wages or to move to full-time, though this is due more to the fact that Seattle doesn't understand economics rather than any fault of HFS. There is a problem of lazy student workers, mostly rich kids from international countries who've never worked a day in their life. There's also the issue regarding the inefficiencies poor decision making of the heads of HFS Dining, largely as it's a government run branch and is therefore funded by the taxpayer.

pros: Flexible work schedule for students
cons: Limited experiences gained from work

review_title: Interesting work; smart co-workers; a bit heavy on the bureaucracy
pros: UW-IT (NDT) manages fast networks with a large diameter, which means interesting problems and a lot of potential for cool projects. Network engineers are allowed to work autonomously and given a great deal of freedom in their day to day work. The work/life balance and benefits are very good. There are a ton of smart people here and it's likely that you'll learn new things pretty regularly.
cons: UW as a whole is stuck in the mode of being a giant state research university. This means that it doesn't adapt itself to the times and as a result it can be frustrating to champion new ideas. The enemy of almost everyone here is bureaucracy and politics and thus it can be hard to determine when you're crossing someone's invisible line.  The university can be a bit heavy on the meetings.

pros: The campus is lovely. You get state holidays as paid time off. Centrally located for many. Good transit options to main campus.
cons:
Wages are falling behind the local market. Union representation is mandatory in many positions but not always effective in representing the workers. Egotistical and out of touch academics get in the way of the progress you would see in a private sector, for profit environment. Departments and projects bleed funding because of this. Generally 5-10 years behind in best practices for business. Gender inequality and academic tenure make some professors, doctors and researchers essentially impossible to discipline for behavior that would get them fired by any reasonable company. 

The University district has a crime problem; break ins assaults and robbery are common. This is not he fault of the UW but, certainly something to be aware of as a worker.

review_title: Student Work at University of Washington
pros: A beautiful campus, with a great location in a very fun city. Always something interesting happening since it's a bustling college campus. Student jobs balance relatively low wages by allowing much greater flexibility and options in hours worked.
cons: Relatively low salaries across the board when compared to large universities elsewhere. High cost of living of seattle compounds this disparity. Student hourly jobs can range from very dull and monotonous to engaging and rewarding, but the salaries for these jobs stay quite low. Generally minimum wage + $2-3/hour for lower skill level jobs. The premium for many highly skilled job positions is quite small for student employees- maybe minimum + $4-7/hr. In more desirable skill areas this can mean a salary that is equivalent to as low as 30-40% of an equivalent off-campus, non-student job.

review_title: Great place to work as a student.
pros: Depending on where you work, some positions - despite UW's size - have a very small-business feel to them. I loved TAing and it was an opportunity to strengthen my own basic skills while actually feeling like I made a difference for some students (not all, but a definite chunk). They're pretty much always hiring for something. I worked with the same professor for a year after being one of his students, and we ended up getting really close and would frequently go out to lunch together. You meet some really great people. And the Quad in the springtime can't be beat, of course.
cons: The area where I worked was definitely under-funded, so things were sometimes scattered or confusing to work through (i.e. they once lost one of my paychecks before I signed up for direct deposit. I got it eventually, though). Also, given the work I did, I feel like I was underpaid - but I didn't mind much because I did truly like the job and it was great experience. Also, I was a lowly undergrad.

review_title: The UW has room for improvement as a work place
pros:
The campus is beautiful and vibrant.
Working around students and smart people is energizing.
Benefits are decent.
UW has a great reputation in the community from a student perspective and in terms of research happening here.  People outside the UW smile when you tell them where you work.
There are lots of great place to walk to for lunch or for a scenic view nearby to campus.
Employees are generally pretty nice to each other across units.
cons:
Pay is below market.
More "corporate politics" and silos than any company I've worked for before.
Commuting to campus is getting increasingly worse.
Some faculty and mangers get away with treating others poorly and HR has no clue and are ineffectual (at least in some schools/departments).
There is little to no career development for staff -- short of applying to other departments/schools. 
Most people I've met in my School (Business) and in other places like the Law School and Nursing School express being understaffed and overworked.
Some staff employees cope with mediocre pay and the pecking order by just "punching the clock."

review_title: Stereotypical state job, for the most part
pros: Good benefits, some unique (class discounts, academic software pricing, campus opportunities), even for half-time employees. Opportunities to work at less-than-full-time positions. Can easily advance through the entire salary range (classified employees). Many internal classes one can take as well. Beautiful campus in spring and fall (Seattle), somewhat invigorating to be around students.
cons: Low salaries for all except many directors, big gap in-between them and staff, some of their managers. Generally lesser equipment and software. Lack of climate control (air conditioning) when I worked there, was very uncomfortable in hot weather. Bureaucratic. Poor performers, those offering poor customer service - particularly managers, and unethical practices are generally allowed to continue, which can be frustrating, but must be accepted in so far as possible. Difficult at best to advance, many interviews to fill a quota. The big picture isn't shared, senior management beyond one's department are invisible. No concern about employees as people. Due to pay system, many employees do the minimum, though I came across several exceptions, which was surprising.

job_title: Test Automation Architect in Seattle, WA
pros:
Working here is pretty cool. My team is both well-educated and well-rounded, so we have lots to talk about that isn't just work. Because the environment is education and research, there is a general interest in doing our work because it improves the world, not just to make big profits (especially for us tech workers). The teams I work with tend to be more collaborative with very little competition or derision.

Additionally, the benefits are pretty cool, with a good choice of insurance options, as well as the opportunity to take advantage of so many Campus opportunities.
cons: It certainly depends on the type of work, but advancement can be difficult in a University environment. I wouldn't say it's "political," per se, but there aren't often a lot of options for mobility (again, applying this to tech workers). At the same time, I find that even though research and forward-thinking are important here, management styles and the view of "leadership" vs. "contributor" seems somewhat old-fashioned.

review_title: The Univ.of WA is a great place to work.
pros:
The UW is one of the most respected public universities in the USA, and many of the programs are recognized internationally.  The university's reputation adds a level of prestige that I don't think is necessarily true for other public universities.  Also, the benefits I was afforded, including excellent health benefits, the UW retirement plan and tuition reimbursement made going to work quite bearable.  

Seattle is a beautiful place to live and work, and I would highly recommend the city and university to anyone considering moving there.  The opportunities for outdoor activities, cultural events and the pleasant weather (it's really not that rainy!) make it a great place to live.
cons: As in other university settings, sometimes faculty members assume administrative/managerial roles when these type of non-teaching/non-research roles really aren't their strengths.  For example, the faculty member who was my boss really detested administrative and managerial tasks and responsibilities, which obviously led to a less-than-ideal situation.

review_title: The University of Washington is great, however, one has to vet individual faculty PI’s in Bioengineering
pros:
Great University 
Nice campus
Good location 
Good community 
Good cause
cons:
PI has no oversight of his behavior
PI is very congenial towards outsiders, but he does not respect his employees or grad students 
PI does not behave according to a basic code of conduct
PI underpays by a long shot, even by academic standards, though he has a lot of funding
PI is only getting published in a friend’s journal 
PI is sloppy with no attention to detail
PI does not value good software practices nor support the use of any features or tools with which he is unfamiliar, and it doesn’t take long to find those 
PI complains tremendously if employees and grad students want to use sick or vacation leave, leave which the university provides as part of the benefits package, and the complaining is “always”, i.e. unrelated to potential “deadline” times

review_title: General experience as a UW worker.
job_title: Temp/PSR/Customer Service Representative in Seattle, WA
pros: As a temp you will be able to work roughly 6 months of full time hours begore having to take the same time off from temping for UW. Pay is competative and benefits are granted for assingments of 90 days or more. It's slow and stable and if you need a place to camp while you figure out your next move, it's pretty great. Long term, maybe not so much.
cons: The UW is a city in a city. And it is bound by both state law and restrictive academic leadership. Things ponderously in comparison to the outside world and in some areas, technology and best practices lag behind market norms by ten years or more.  Pay is ok but, if you are just a pawn, there is no real incentive to do anything more than the minimum. Your union gets you raises now and then but is mostly just a drain on your paycheck. You will never have a fast track here.

review_title: Best work/life balance I've ever had
pros:
- This review is a little tricky to write. A lot of your experience depends on what department you're in and who your managers are. I've been pleased overall with my department and managers. However, if you do find yourself unhappy, it's not difficult to transfer to a different department.

- Work/life balance is excellent! The University actually wants and encourages you to have a life outside of work. 

- Really amazing benefits. Even part-time workers get them. I have my entire family on my health plan. Their retirement plan is REALLY good. Not to mention, tuition exemption

- great values and mission

- Unions

- Lots of diversity

- Seattle campus is gorgeous
cons:
- Too many greedy, sexist men in charge that could stand to retire.

- The pay isn't great. They try to balance this out with the really great benefits you get. While that does help, it's still difficult to get by with the high cost of living in Seattle. If you're single, you'd probably have to get a second job

review_title: Huskies, chew that bone to the marrow!
pros: The UW offers lots of time off (vacation), stead work, and can be practically impossible to get fired from (union). Company does try to promote from within and they will work with your schedule.  UW offers opportunities to participate in some good research studies and offers opportunities to meet some amazing individuals. You can get out what you put into the job.  As far as I know, UW is one of the few employers who still offer a pension.
cons: Low pay and you get to work with (some individuals) who practically can't be fired (union).  Can remain in the same job title for years even if you are doing the job outside of your job class.  Professional and Classified Staff receive salary raises and title promotions based on the kindness of their supervisor and not on any particular metrics (regardless of performance).

review_title: Such a large corporation that they do not value their employees
pros: The number of sick days and vacation days that you get is okay and I don't get a lot of flack for taking my days off.  Not like I did in the private sector.
cons: The pay is awful....especially for an SEIU 925 union member.  It does not seem like the union really fights for the members and the UW does not really care about its employees enough to pay for all of the work that we do.  There is definately a lot of work for one person to do and the communication between departments and within the university is soooo bad.  There is also a lot of duplicate work and many wasted resources.  You would also think that being in Seattle and being a huge university, that we would have better technology available.  Not the case.  We are working with very limited technology and very poor systems.

pros: The University of Washington is a great place for smart, motivated people to advance their career and make an impact.
cons:
The University of Washington is incredibly large and decentralized.  Most departments operate in silos with no interest in collaborating with others.  This results in a great deal of inefficiencies that can be frustrating.  It takes a loooooong time to get things done.
You will encounter people that fit the typical state employee stereotype (unmotivated & not to bright).  There are also a lot of talented people but many leave for better opportunities.  It takes a strong person with a lot of patience to succeed at the UW.

review_title: Makes You Feel Like Your Time Is Theirs
pros: Paid Holidays, Rotating Holidays Off, Rotating Weekends, Union Job
cons: Severely poorly managed. Our breaks are already accounted for in pay (whether you take them or not). No coverage on breaks most of the time (when you do get them) putting you behind. If management notices you complete your tasks in a timely manner they create/pile up more work on you which in turn takes away possible break times. Constantly pulled away from training on new tasks due to call outs (management does not help out in areas in need). There seem to be a lot of "managers" walking around with clipboards and notebooks, all of them with offices/office space in the pharmacy but I'm not entirely sure what they actually do.

review_title: Unique opportunities & benefits none can beat & bright people
pros: You get to work on research projects, things that no sensible profit-driven industries want to risk investing and investigating such as developing flight control software for newly designed autonomous underwater vehicles.  You get to work with very liberal, open-minded and bright people.  Benefits are unbeatable.  Compensations are not too bad for academic entity, generally 10-15% lower than equivalent positions in the private sector; much higher than usual departmental units.  Usually very flexible in schedule, vacation needs, etc.
cons: Hardly anyone cares about QA.  There's a saying "don't let PhDs code", and it's so true.  You'll be forever "programmer" unless you can come up with a noble idea and fetch grants from federal agencies yourself.  If you are like me who's passionate about engineering aspect of software development, you will find a dead end in career development.  As for compensations, though I said it's generally only  10-15% less, the gap has grown wider since the state wide salary freeze since 2007.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Large institution with lots of resources and partnerships, great education readily available for students, many options on classes, very research-based
cons: Current department's budget keeps getting reduced, meaning there are fewer and fewer sources of support for graduate students. Unfortunately applying for fellowships outside of UW is also very competitive, so funding is always a concern. Sometimes colleagues don't get back to you quickly or at all unless you keep reminding them, which cuts into your time. It can be difficult to plan large-scale projects in academia because so many unexpected snags keep popping up, and working around all the administrative stuff can be aggravating.

job_title: Graduate Researcher and TA in Seattle, WA
pros: Being a graduate student is unique experience. For me, the toils and tribulations that I shared with my peers helped to form much tighter bonds than I had developed as an undergraduate. Teaching was also a lot of fun. I liked trying to find the balance between being charming and informative--between quick thinking and careful consideration. There was plenty of interesting research being done in the department. There was always a push for innovative, self-reliant solutions to problems that arose.
cons: Work was often done in isolation so people often had difficulties appreciating the effort that their colleagues had made. There were never any clear end-goals or metrics of accumulated success--expectations always shifted as projects did. There seemed to be an expectation of working-to-be-seen-as-busy rather than working because it provided intellectual stimulation or genuine human fulfillment or even accomplished anything. The hours were unappealing and uncompromising. By the end of my short stint here, I had grown to hate many of things that I had once loved.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Nice campus. Good benefits. World class research environment. Lots of interesting programs, clubs, and activities you can participate in. Good location. Has exercise facilities. Lots of life and career guidance programs.
cons:
Administration seems to be over eager to penalize. They often went straight to threats and penalties out of proportion to the issue instead of asking nicely first. For example, an admin locked down my computer account until I resolved an issue that turned out to be due to the admin's confusion on a minor point in a form. (When I contacted the admin, the admin said there wasn't anything wrong and unlocked my account.)

On an unrelated note, an administrator seemed to have made some weird assumptions about me. She kept being irritated and seemed to think I didn't know English, even though I am a native English speaker.

Overall I got the impression the administration is unfriendly.

job_title: Academic Services Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: I've worked in three departments over the course of several years, and each has been quite different with regard to flexibility, likelihood of promotion, salary increases, and most important, how much freedom employees have to take on responsibility and use their talents.  The result is that the UW is not one employer, but many.  When management in a department changes, the entire culture changes as well, so a good job can turn into a bad job.
cons: Too little commitment and accountability. Infrastructure support is sorely lacking, and each department is required to pay for services yet they are not permitted to find competitive bids for such services or to perform it themselves.  Thus, public spaces are in abyssmal condition: the walls need painting, the floors are maintained by untrained custodial staff, the bathrooms are often out of supplies, doors broken.  Very uneven infrastructure support depending on department.

pros: Encourages innovation, independent work, but also work in teams. Leadership skills are important depending on your position but also leading committees and student teaching come into this. Best benefits I've ever had and they do some matching on investments. Great people to work with, collegial and lots of great ideas come out of meetings, etc. Students are eager to learn and gain pearls from faculty outside of the classroom. Innovative teaching methods including flip the classroom, small work groups that share, and more. Senior faculty great at assisting junior faculty. Distance is the only reason I left.
cons: Most faculty are paid less than a pharmacist but the generous benefit package makes up for this.

review_title: Suzzallo Library is a great place to work; UW not so much
pros: I had an extremely positive experience working as a student at the Suzzallo Library. My supervisors were all terrific people and I learned a lot more there than I did at school. I'd love to work there again as staff someday.
cons: UW does its best to avoid paying student workers more than they absolutely have to, and forget about ever seeing benefits. I'm glad to see that they're being forced to comply with the $15 Seattle minimum wage, because my understanding is they were fighting pretty hard to get out of that.

review_title: Great benefits, Great workplace, So-so pay
job_title: Fiscal Specialist I  in Seattle, WA
pros:
Excellent Benefits, the best I've seen so far. Including; 401k/retirement funds, health and dental, all is above par.  They even subsidize bus and "occasional parking" costs for employees.  They offer all sorts of counciling and access to great professional development through courses designed to help you move up within the university.

Relaxed atmosphere, everyone is helpful and understanding.  Best management I've ever had, couldn't be happier.

Very easy to move around from department and positions, everyone understands the desire for an upward career, even management will help you move on to better positions.
cons: Low pay considering the required qualifications and education of nearly all positions.  Strange rules and regulations regarding safety that can annoy some employees, c'mon I want to have my own coffee maker at work.  Horrible parking, it is either very expensive or nonexistent based on which site you work at.

review_title: What's more important- work/life balance, or having a fast paced, high-paid job (that you could loose at any second)?
job_title: Senior Computer Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: the benefits, work/life balance, tuition exemption policies (ability to get a free degree while you work!), and overall low-stress workplace make this a great place to work. There is also a lot of really interesting research and great people, so if you find a job in a good department, you can be very happy.
cons: The university of washington has a crazy bureaucracy, so if you can't handle the slow pace of getting things done, you will be miserable here. Sometimes it seems as though it takes mounds of paperwork and multiple phone calls just to buy a box of paperclips! It's the kind of place where it takes a couple of years to figure out how to navigate the bureaucracy. Also, a lot of jobs are not particularly challenging.

review_title: A University is more than just science and engineering
pros: Opportunity to build on my graduate school training and to develop as a teacher and a researcher. Encouragement and support for new initiatives and controversial ideas.  Excellent and supportive atmosphere.  Opportunity to work with people of various and diverse backgrounds and perspectives.
cons: The only downside is the low level of salaries in comparison with other occupations, but also from discipline to discipline. Sciences and Engineering pay good salaries, while faculty in the humanities have relatively low salaries.  Nine month salary payment structure provides three months off in the summer, BUT it is without pay.  One must budget carefully to make it from June to September every year.

review_title: Great benefits and work life balance, lots of hurdles for change
job_title: Administrative Assistant, School of Medicine in Seattle, WA
pros: Excellent health and retirement benefits, PTO accrual and sick leave accrual rates are great as well (for professional staff anyways).
cons: Base compensation isn't great, but that's where benefits come in. Change is slow. The recruitment process is SLOW (several weeks to months depending on the department, which loses talent). Managers have to wait on higher up leadership for any change, which takes months and months of committee charging, gathering, and resolution (if any). Diversity efforts are MAJORLY lacking in the UWSOM. I've been hearing the same complaints from staff and students the YEARS I've been here about lack of diversity and anti-racism training and I feel I will continue to hear the same stories for years to come. Executive leadership at the SOM doesn't care about equity, diversity and inclusion. Its actions prove it.

review_title: Amazing benefits and resources but current budgetary crisis is worrying
pros: As a research scientist coming up on 3 years in this position, I'm earning 8 hours of sick leave and 11+ hours vacation time each month, the University is matching 5% of my salary in a 401k and there are several companies and types of health insurance to choose from with relatively reasonable premiums. The campus is beautiful and busing into work is a cinch from most any part of the city. The UPASS (bus pass) is ridiculously cheap (~$40/month) and is the best way to commute to work.
cons: State and Federal spending cuts have made a lot of jobs (including mine) precarious for the foreseeable future. Many positions are reliant on federal grant money and much of that is drying up as funding for federal grants is cut and competition is getting higher. The insanely complex and impossible to understand bureaucracy of the University system can be extremely frustrating at times.

pros:
*Lots of time off.  
*Virtually impossible to loose your job.  
*With such a large workforce there are some wonderful co-workers who really care about doing a great job.  
*If you enlist with the right group, there are exciting opportunities to do some great research.  
*Flexible work hours.
cons:
*Lowest pay around. 
*Few opportunities for any significant advancement. 
*A rampant culture of "Thats not my job."
*Your working in an environment where ineffectual employees cannot be / are not let go. 
*Archaic administrate systems in place such as purchasePath, Leave Time Reporting, ect.  
*Management doesn't work with / respect the opinion of those individuals without advanced degrees.  
*Rife with bureaucracy (the ineffective, inefficient, inflexible variety).

review_title: Rewarding for the kids and families, management could improve
job_title: Counselor At UW Apex Summer Program in Seattle, WA
pros: I loved working at the UW Apex Summer Program because getting to work with these kids and see how much they improve in just five weeks of ABA treatment was so rewarding and it reminded me of why I love working in this field. Management provided thorough training and provided housing for employees who lived far away from campus.
cons: Management did not provide a lot of support for employees. There were over 100 of us and it didn't feel like our concerns and needs as counselors were always met because it was easy to get lost in the crowd. It's very rewarding but also draining to work in these types of programs at times, especially because you work for about 50 hours each week and this internship is UNPAID. If you come back a second summer, they have to pay you but it's very little.

pros: The UW is truly boundless when it comes to career opportunities, provided you know where to look. Once you find what you are interested in, even if it doesn't directly relate to your job, you are free to pursue it.
cons: Due to our lean government budgets, most job descriptions at the professional level are really too big for one person to fill. I am always impressed that we strive to get the best and the brightest. But, I find that often new hires are unable to fulfill their entire job descriptions.

job_title: Senior Computer Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: The campus setting is nice, extremely smart people to work with, most places have at least as good a job security as private industry. There is considerable independence between units so it is a good place for those who do not fit into a highly structured large corporate environment very well. Good benefits package.
cons: Too much job security can make underperformers stick around for a long time... Office space is always on short supply, people are working under cramed, noisy, unpleasant conditions which tends to bring out differences in working style. Facilities maintenance and janitorial staff performance is under par. Tuition exemption program is set up in a way that makes it completely useless for all practical purposes.

review_title: Be very sure what it is you want before working here ... Not bad for a pit stop on your career path.
job_title: Public Information Specialist II in Seattle, WA
pros: Location, The Campus is beautiful.  Helpful commuting assistance and support.  Diversity friendly.  The occasional 'gem' of a manger if you are lucky enough to work for one.
cons: Low pay, no career path, nepotism, favoritism, mangement by emotion rather than good business practices.  Much of the existing upper management are dinosaurs from the 60's who should have retired decades ago.  Instead they have been resting on there perceived laurels and self congratulating themselves for being so unique and special while the real world passes them by and leaves them in the dust.  They will always blame everyone and anyone else for their management failures while dumping the lowest echelon personnel.  They are beauracracy at it's worst.

review_title: A safe yet somewhat predictable job path.
pros: Job duties are clearly delineated and security is good for UW employees who fall under the "classified" category.  I was a "program coordinator" at the UW, which does fall into that category.  In other words, it was a unionized position.  I was required to pay union dues but I think it was worth it, because of all the lobbying the union did on my behalf.  When my position was phased out in one department, I was automatically eligible for another equivalent position in another department.
cons: Limited opportunities for advancement, promotions often based on seniority; bureaucratic structure is sometimes cumbersome.  Also, the pay is less that you would get in the private sector.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Seattle, WA
pros: Consistent schedule, requesting vacation is very simple, calm environment
cons: If you do not have a degree the majority of people will automatically value you less - especially the doctors. Doctors are contracted and the managers of the clinic have little to no say on how they treat the staff. There is a Clinic Chief who is in charge of the Doctors but the one at my clinic was very rude and pretentious. I have had multiple Doctors yell at me in front of my peers and patients. Usually when Doctors get upset it is because they don't understand protocol but as a staff member they drill you to follow protocol.

pros: Everything about being at this hospital seems to be a 'pro'. I extended my 13 week contract to a 26 week contract because I was so happy with working here. The staff has been extremely helpful, and I've always felt supported by the assistant nurse manager, as well as the manager of the unit herself. The nurses are encouraged to be very autonomous, and have good relationships with the residents / doctors / PAs. There is also available help from STAT RNs, which help you to feel confident with acute patients on the floor.
cons: The only con would be the amount of PCT help on the floor. In a 28 bed unit, it wasn't uncommon to only be staffed with 1-2 PCTs. Luckily, RNs frequently only had 3 patients so this made it easier to help, but if the floor is heavy, which it usually is, it would be highly beneficial for patient care to be fully staffed with techs.

review_title: How to have fun while being poor.
job_title: Research Scientist I in Seattle, WA
pros: freedom, good benefits, friendly environment
cons: low salary, poor HR support

review_title: A good place to hone your skills but very cold staff.
pros: They offer some pretty good assignments. You learn and grow with each project. The staff seem to like what they do. The office culture reflects the great energy of UW's students.
cons: Where can I start? UW and the Seattle freeze go hand in hand. Many of the staff are passive aggressive (like in Admissions). They like people who are local not from other cities, states or countries. If you have dark skin, chances are you won't go far here. For example, in Family Medicine, there is only 1 black female doctor.  That dept. is FULL of political issues. They lack the diplomacy and tact to handle people. They like to mistreat people and they don't care at all.

pros: Good Benefits (State Employee), make a difference for a diverse population of people seeking dental care / services, many long time employees, opportunity to impact lives of the underserved. Say they are trying to move into a more effective business model.
cons:
Dealing with academia (teaching student dentists), arrogance and old school thinking (Some Faculty Dentists) and a business model that is dated and not working.
No opportunity for front line employees to collaborate or be a part of change 
No flexibility (without using sick leave & vacation), Scheduled hours are in peak commuting hours resulting in a loss of 2-3 hours a day, depending on where you are commuting from,

review_title: Very inconsistent standards for faculty and manager's behavior
pros:
Great mission working with very intelligent and  highly qualified faculty and colleagues. Most care about treating everyone with respect, creating a culture of diversity and inclusion.
e
cons:
Some extremely high quality leaders who uphold the values of 
the the U of W. Others who are bullies and abusive to those who report to them. There is no place and no one tell tell about abusive behavior unless you're in a department that has a code of conduct. Otherwise, HR goes along with whatever a leader says. They are never employees advocates. Very obsolete HR model.

review_title: Fine place to get the degree and move on, especially in the region.
pros: The University of Washington provides a good education, has sufficient degree recognition, and is a good entry point to regional employers who both look to the University of Washington for recruits and contacts.  The location and access to local employers such as Microsoft, Google, and Boeing make it a great starting point for career development.
cons: The pay and benefits are not as high as competing institutions.  This is made worse by the higher cost of living in Seattle.  Some localized cultures promote long durations of graduate school, leading to further delays of entry into higher wage positions.

review_title: Rewarding university experience.  There are plenty of places that lack the benefits of this university.
job_title: Affiliate Assistant Professor in Seattle, WA
pros: Teamwork, travel funds, high staff loyalty, excellent training opps, great students. It seems like the perks have increased: I am now invited to march, and they even rented a gown for me this year. I was too broke to buy my doctoral gown when I graduated, so have avoided marching til now.  I have to say that I have been able to travel when I needed, and have been supported in my writing.  I have an amazing research library at my finger tips, and it is also great that the university plans its tech roll-outs so well.  The administration has also been very supportive in my efforts to build community outreach and collaboration.
cons: There are no cons, really and truly.

pros: The benefits are awesome, all of the staff are hard working and overall contribute to a team effort. I worked within the library and it such a supportive place. Everyone is friendly and it's a very positive environment. I also enjoyed being around all the academics who have the most interesting story stories to tell. Also, awesome place to network and move around to different areas of the University, as it is vast and full of opportunities.
cons: The tenured staff tend to be less motivated and that can be frustrating. Budget cuts are constantly happening so there isn't always the job security you might hope for. There are also times when the culture gets cut throat and I've heard of many staff trying to get others fired for the wrong reasons. Working for professors can sometimes mean they have little regard for your life outside of work, and their anti-social demeanor can also get tiring, honestly.

pros: Seattle can be nice in the summer.
cons: The biggest thing is that post-docs are considered temporary workers & not eligible for full staff benefits including retirement contributions, despite the fact that appointments are usually 4-6yrs. The health insurance coverage is expensive & not very comprehensive. The career development programs are lumped in with development for grad students, kind of like an after thought, despite very different need at each of these stages in scientific career development. Some of the best development opportunities that are available are only accessible by competitive application! The CYA regulatory environment (EH&S & DCM) can make pushing a project more complicated than it needs to be. You have to write significant protocol changes for everything, even pilot studies! EH&S makes ridiculous laboratory rules that keep changing. For example, they have decided that 70% EtOH is a fire hazard. What?

pros: Great benefits, some flexibility in work hours, professional development encouraged, challenging job that keeps you learning, satisfying to help students and recruit students to STEM programs.
cons: Systems are numerous, redundant and not as integrated and seamless as they could be. Advising, payroll, purchasing and registration systems are getting better, but are often clunky and not well explained. Work culture caters to faculty, and staff are there to serve them, as well as students. Much of STEM related department leadership dominated by male faculty who are not necessarily capable/experienced managers. Tendency to be hypercritical of minor errors; annual evaluations can be more focused on weaknesses, rather than balanced assessment of successes and recognition of strengths, and development of goals.

pros: Great environment as students and staff are motivated to succeed and excel academically, as well as be the best they can in life. The access to industry-leading and respected faculty, staff, and resources was a dream.
cons: The inability or unwillingness to create positions to assist staff in thriving in roles that fit them and their desire to grow professionally. This might be just in my area of work, so be sure to ask how the department you are applying to plans to grow you professionally once you have outgrown your role.

pros:
-Part of an innovative university that is renowned internationally
-Very focused on work-life balance
cons:
-Isolated environment for employees 
-Little opportunity to advance 
-Complacency amongst full time staff 
-CONSTANT red tape and inability to accomplish tasks. Everything is 'pending' because 15 other groups have to approve it as well. If you are motivated by accomplishment, this is not the place to be 

Seems the benefits package is what draws everyone in, and with a set salary people quickly loose their ambition to constantly grow as professionals. From the time I've been here, it seems as though everyone is just buying time to get a pension. 

Great environment to work in if you are middle-aged and wanting something a little more relaxed. But in my experience, if you want to accomplish things quickly, collaborate with others on projects, and enjoy going to work everyday, the UW probably is not the greatest fit.

job_title: Senior Computer Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Working at a large and prestigious university, tuition assistance.
cons: Salaries, working environment, New initiatives have caused the university to move to a Shared Services concept which basically means they are doing massive lay offs, combining work to overload salary employee's because OT is not an issue and management frequently reminds you that you have to get the job done even if you are working 60-80hrs/wk, and paying less. Also, most areas of the campus, especially for IT are extremely dated, dirty, and lack basic common utilities, no break rooms or such, food on campus sucks.  The new centers they are building basically put employees on assembly lines reducing a workers station to a 3 ft table that fits one small monitor, keyboard and mouse. No place for storage, dividers or privacy. I will remind you that these are professional staff, Server Admins, Finance Analyst's, Managers.

review_title: The University of Washington is a great place to develop your skills as a scientist.
pros: The benifits are very competitive at the University of Washington for professional staff members: matching (100%) contributions to 401(k) retirement plans, medical/dental/vision, reduced bus pass.  Working at the University of Washington provides a stimulating environment with many seminars given by world class scientists.  You can always find someone who knows something about what you are interested in.  You can also find people who have equipment not available to people working at a smaller schools.
cons: There seems to be a glass ceiling that is reached quickly if you are interested in growing and developing new methods of doing things.  Much of the research at the University of Washington involves tried and true experimental methods, so thinking outside the box is sometimes difficult.

review_title: Great university in a great city
pros: In my opinion it is one of the best public universities in the nation.  A great medical center, law school, and many other areas.  Located right in Seattle, the UW is in a great location to be able to hit the town.  I also love Seattle for its proximity to the mountains and ocean, its just beautiful.  There is no shortage of money here for research (at least that I've seen thus far).  It is one of the top research universities in the country for a reason.
cons: Some of the facilities are a bit old and in need of repair, but what university doesn't have that problem.

review_title: Good place to get a PhD, depending on the department and program
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Seattle, WA
pros:
Students in my program have covered tuition, health benefits, a reasonable faculty-supported work-life balance that has allowed me the flexibility to start a family.  The coursework is very useful and practical and the TA requirements are modest.  There was plenty of funding (within my department) for doctoral research and access to all the equipment that I required.

(Some of these Pros are guaranteed by the Graduate Student Union Labor Contract at the University of Washington and some of these are program specific.)
cons: Some work and benefit policies and decisions by departmental chairs are not as transparent as they ought to be.  It makes it hard to judge whether everyone is treated fairly.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
As a graduate student, it's one of the only ways to get your tuition paid. For out of state and international student, this is particularly valuable.

Another plus is that you get to work on diverse and interesting projects that may turn into research opportunities for dissertation work.
cons: Your pay is extremely poor, and you have effectively no ability to affect your pay rate, as it's largely defined by state funding levels. Advisors vary widely in quality, and your work load may exceed contractual requirements. Finally, since you're often tied to a particular professor through both your work and your research, you're effectively unable to move if conditions are unacceptable to you. This last point is really important - if you're lucky enough to work with someone you like, you're fine. But if you have difficulties with your employing professor, it's very hard to do anything about it without endangering your academic career.

review_title: Good Health Care, Low pay, Poor research environment
pros: Access to quality health care on campus is excellent. Numerous clinics around campus in addition to the University Hospital, all well run (at least from the standpoint of the consumer). The campus is especially scenic during cherry blossom season. Work here if you need easy access to good health care and like the pacific northwest, just don't expect to get too much research done or be well paid.
cons: Bureaucracy is terrible and makes running a lab capable of cutting edge research extremely difficult. Faculty don't collaborate well and are typically very underfunded. Research environment is very poor. Outside of working with the minority of faculty who are good and well funded, don't expect to get very much out of a postdoc at UW.

review_title: Housing and Food Services: run, don’t walk away
job_title: Food Service Worker in Seattle, WA
pros: Salary pay. State health benefits.
cons: Look for any department other than Housing and Food Services. There is horrible to zero communication to staff and amongst one another, no pay raises, constantly short staffed. And it gets worse and worse, no hope over the horizon. Someone told you that you were going to get that promotion, then....yep, you’re still in the same position but someone else has been given the job. Oh, someone heard about your personal sensitive information? Yep, managers gossip like teenagers. And to make it worse they will gossip to your coworkers about you, then try to deny it. At some point someone will take the time to bring a lawsuit against this department and it will be justified.

review_title: A good one, great benefits, easy of hours, and a lot of work to go around
pros: The benefits is primarily the best part of working in U.W. It is great for an employee who has family. The UW fairly compensates via health benefits to make sure their employees are protected. Other than that, the work consistency is there, so there isn't too much of a surprise when changes occur.
cons: The measurement of growth and reward is universally structured because of internal control. Departments can't do much to be flexible. It is good structure for people who prefer yearly increases of salary based on dedicated experience. Not the best structure for ambitious driven individuals. Although with proper patience, it can be manageable.

review_title: Excellent work environment, low pay for the area
pros: I experienced a wonderful, and highly flexible, work environment.  My boss was personable and understanding of my family obligations.  I also found collaboration with other units to be fruitful and exciting.
cons:
The salary was too low for the area.  In addition I felt it was too low based on my qualifications (PhD).  Before I was hired I tried to negotiate a better salary, but my boss explained that since the salaries are public I could not be paid higher then my colleague who had been there for 20+ years, even though she only had a Master degree and I was coming in with a PhD.  

I was not issued a laptop.  Although I did receive a $2,000 sign on bonus.

pros: As a public institution, the organization has a strong sense of purpose and accountability to the taxpayers; nice to work in such an innovative higher ed setting, beautiful campus, great people
cons: For being so innovative, UW is a little behind the times in how it views its employees; also, excessive politics at the top and a lack of clear vision from senior leadership; there is no one single mission statement for the organization, which makes it challenging to set a cohesive direction; benefits are decent, but pay is low (and if they do pay you a decent amount, they beat you over the head with it because of the tax-payer piece); this is my experience in the administrative side of the house--I've heard the environment is better in the academic side

review_title: Too much waste, but the benefits are great.
pros: Universities are amazing places to learn, be part of a community, and work for things that ground you. Once you work here, very easy to move to different departments on campus. And yes, that benefit package is as bomb as they say it is.
cons: The places at UW that bring in money like professors and students get most of the dollars and perks. The rest of us who support them get the short end of the stick. And yes, red tape and bureaucracy results in huge amounts of waste.

pros: The benefit package is what draws and keeps people working at UW. Salaries are decent but not often not commensurate with the expectations placed on employees.  Excellent health and retirement benefits.
cons: At least in my experience, staff members were expected to do much more work than they were being paid for. I worked there through the housing crash, after which the State of Washington froze all state salaries for 4 years. As budgets were cut, staff positions disappeared and remaining staff were told to pick up the difference. Many mid level personnel worked constant overtime for no extra pay.

review_title: University of Washington Strives for Excellence, Achieves Mediocrity
pros: The UW is regarded as a stable employer although somewhat of a revolving door as people leave for higher paying positions when times are good and return when their new employer downsizes.  Benefits are good and the opportunity for learning is also good as employees receive 6 free course hours each semester, pending approval by manager and instructor.  Transportation to the UW is excellent, encouraged and facilitated by the UPASS program.
cons: Without a PhD, there is virtually no chance of advancement in Science, and the University of Washington is no exception.  Department Administrators preserve an aristocratic view and clear working class divisions among peers, post-docs, scientists, technicians, assistants and students.  This is both demoralizing and devaluing and reduces the work incentive.

review_title: Great place to give up at
job_title: Senior Computer Sepecalist in Seattle, WA
pros:
Low expectations
Time off when you want it, even if it creates staffing issues
If you are a yes-man it's easy to get promoted
cons:
Managers are  perfect example of failing up
They don't even want to hear ideas that don't fall inline with the direction they want to go
Unless your improvements can make a big splash to make your managers look good it will probably be ignored or you have to make the changes without any support
Managers always say we need to "run like a business" but most of the managers have zero experience in the private sector

pros: Great benefit all around, including lots of time off, and it's rarely (if ever) expected that one puts in more than 40 hours a week.  Separate annual leave and sick leave means there is no drawback to calling in sick... which is great because I want sick people to stay home so they don't infect me!
cons: Tuition exemption is difficult, and sometimes impossible, to actually use.  Every department feels very separate from the rest of campus, making information sharing difficult, and promotions are basically impossible without changing jobs (which requires going through the same process as outside hires).  Be prepared to manage your own career.

pros:
I'm halftime so I have a lot of time to write and finish my dissertation
My assistantship pays my tuition and so I have only had to buy books and admin fees. TAs/RAs are in a union, so we have health insurance and some job security
cons: Busy times, can be very busy, and there is an old saying, "If a professors asks you to work on a project with them, and you say 'no' you may not get another chance to say 'yes'". So you end up working on way to many things at once if you are not careful.  The pay is generally low, even for full-time employment.

pros: Co-workers are mainly positive and helpful. Staff are intelligent, educated, accepting of diversity. I feel valued, respected, and connected with the university's goals and mission. My supervisor takes a lot of time to advise me on projects and answer questions. The work environment is very good. Salary limits are the only major downside of the department I am working in, and the reason I gave 4 stars instead of 5.
cons: Administrative Assistants are classified staff. The union contract is a noose around my financial neck. I reached the top of my pay grade 18 months ago. My supervisor has absolutely no way to change my grade or change my position to professional staff (non-union) even though she would like to compensate me for the level of professional work that I am providing. My only option is to find another job (if I want to increase my earnings).

review_title: You'll get stuck if you work here!
pros: Security. It's hard to get fired.
cons: They can't keep up with cost of living increases and they have no interest or system to support and appreciate staff. If you are not Faculty, you are not appreciated or valued. If you don't have a Masters or higher you are devalued daily. At the Foster School of Business in particular, they expect high-yield outputs, constant growth, and will work you to the bone with no incentive. Within 2 years, I have generated millions of dollars in income for the school through effective recruiting, but have only received the standard state-wide 2% salary increase. I have experienced an abusive environment with leadership and there is no support or accountability. There is 0 job growth or opportunity either.

review_title: I loved the work, but the hassle of being a part time instructor is not worth it in the long term.
pros: I loved working with highly engaged, intelligent students and interesting colleagues in a place with lots opportunities for collaboration and research and where there was always something new to learn.
cons: Working in an interdisciplinary field that crossed departments led to many administrative headaches that could have been avoided by a stronger central presence.  Also, being adjunct faculty hired on a course-by-course basis, with the corresponding do-I-have-a-salary-and-benefits-for the next -12-weeks-or-not dance rapidly lost its charm.

job_title: Event Services Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
- Great coworkers and supervisors -- tight knit community and supervisors genuinely care about their employees
- Flexible hours and accommodates to student schedules
- Learn a lot about the University and its services, as well as insights on building and event management
- Opportunities as a student to be promoted and get pay raises
cons:
- Constant transitions in management. Makes it difficult for consistency
- Hours are not assigned well in advance (supposed to be at least 2 weeks in advance but sometimes is not)
- Must work weekends and very early/late hours, and with messy scheduling sometimes must work multiple weekends in a row

review_title: There are some good people. But the politics can get out of hand
pros: Work schedule can be flexible, which is especially good for those with family. Company does offer classes that might be related to your field for advance learning. Classes might be paid by the department or not, depending if your department will pay for the class. It is up to you to find that out.
cons: People can be lazy, mean, steal ideas and present them as their own, or put the blame on you. Some people who have worked here for years are cocky and rude and think your questions will be stupid and laugh at the question. It has happened to me. No salary increase for years. No pay raise in the near future. Very little, to no chance to advance in your area unless you move to a new department.

job_title: Computer Helpdesk Staff in Seattle, WA
pros: Always understand that school is first priority. A good opportunity to gain experience while going to school, and there are usually a few more opportunities floating around too. At best, you can get some experience that's extremely difficult to get just applying for a standard entry-level position in another organization.
cons: Work atmosphere is really hit or miss. Some departments can have decent office culture, others can be downright toxic. It's really what you make of it; if you're not strong enough at self-management to protect yourself from the atmosphere, you may get very little out of it.

review_title: OK place for a first job; horrible for mid-career people
pros: Great 401k matching, no requirement of overtime, lax management style, easy to take time off
cons: salaries well below market value, no potential for a career path, divisive and condescending managers, skills you gain are useless outside of academia.  Great place to develop a cynical attitude towards employment.  If you are considering a job here check out salaries (these are public info).  Look up potential co-workers and "wa state employee salaries"

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
- As a physical science/engineering student, there did not seem to be a major shortage of TA positions available at UW while I worked on my PhD
- This was instrumental in supporting me as I worked on research, covering 90% of my tuition, as well as including pretty good healthcare benefits (Thanks UAW 4121!)
- Provided teaching experience that may be useful in my future career
- Workload (expected 20hrs/wk) depended on department and professor, but physics TA positions in particular were very streamlined and organized
cons:
- You pay for the financial support with your time, and TA work has a substantial impact on PhD progress.
- Some faculty were not as organized and would lean heavily on TA's without providing enough direction or support.  This could sometimes result in longer hours spent than expected in order to fulfill obligations (>20hrs/wk)

review_title: Not bad, but as a grad student it is easy to slip through the cracks
pros: The campus and facilities are world-class, the facility and administrative people are all helpful and good at what they do.
cons: It can take a long time to finish a Ph.D, over six years in my case, and they do little to help with future job placement.  My adviser basically just wanted us to be little research factories with no direction on how our work may shape our careers; he has actually delegated pieces projects to other people instead of allowing me to learn marketable skills because it would add time, even though the project was mine.

review_title: TAs are overworked and underpaid but fighting the good fight
pros: Funding your education directly and having your work align with your academic studies.  If you have the right faculty advisor you can get a top notch education and get paid in the process.  Academic resources of the institution overall are world class.
cons: Workload for teaching assistants is not commensurate with pay.  Morale is low due to academic job prospects.  Teaching undergraduates is a mixed bag--if your class is required, they're not likely to be all that motivated and so you are going to have to double down to make the class room a positive place.  Undergrads can also have a strong sense of entitlement--you work for them v. them working for their degree--but that's hardly unique to UW.

pros: Great benefits (medical/dental/vision, retirement, flex accounts, health club access, Metro pass, etc.) and very nice people. Plus, once you're hired into the UW, it's fairly easy to switch from one position or department to another. Also, being in the U-District, you're very close to great restaurants and shops, and the students keep the atmosphere vibrant.
