cons: It's sort of a bureaucratic nightmare with plenty of people in management who have no business being there. I'm certain they mean well, but most were not prepared to accept the position in terms of their knowledge of managing people and retaining staff. I've seen a LOT of turn-over since I've been here, and that's pretty much the norm across the University.

review_title: Excellent, collaborative environment with some downsides
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Seattle, WA
pros: Excellent public transit options. Beautiful grounds. Collaborative research and individuals in many departments. Generally great support from departmental services for job/educational requirements.
cons: Getting more expensive to rent much less buy property in the area.  Little to no access to affordable food on the campus if you don't bring any. Sometimes the bureaucratic agencies like payroll and registration do not talk to each other or lack shared databases (this was worst between workday/employee services and registration).

review_title: Great team, great leader, questionable middle management
pros: Being a union member, which allows us to collectively bargain for better wages and benefits, lifting the floor for ALL UW employees. Many different departments and positions, could have multiple careers here. Access to world class speakers and educational opportunities as well as Rec center (IMA) and free admission to Burke and Henry museums.
cons: Many staff (myself included) at top of pay scale. Need more room for growth and fair pay for classified staff. Good efforts being made to reduce and report bias and discrimination, need more resources to continue racial justice work. Seattle very expensive to live so either pay high COL or have a long commute to get here.

pros: Friendly co-workers. Some communication. Potlucks.
cons: Gossip from the Assistant Manager. Was interim lead and friendships were sabotaged by management. Stepped down as lead and friendships were rekindled, but the trust for the new lead, assistant manager and manager was gone. There was a lack of training. No standard work. The clinic seemed to be doing their own thing. This was evident when i attended the lead meetings and how well trained the new PSR's were. Felt a lot of negativity by the managers about previous leads. The clinic was not up to date on the AAHAC audit and overtime and labor was pushed. I feel a clinic should be following up on these standards regularly. Medical records were out of date and not following protocol when i began. The process is choppy and sloppy. Need more front employees to assist with the demands to serve the "patients are first"

pros:
My students have always been very interested in discovery. I't probably my department, but no students seem to behave as if they are here just to party. 
There are lots of interesting talks, concerts, undergraduate research symposia, and other events on this campus. 
The campus is beautiful and there is ample bike and bus transportation options. Soon to have a train too.
cons: Of course, as everywhere, adjuncts have no job security. The main bad thing about the campus is the fact that Seattle is extremely rainy - especially in November when the quarter is really wearing on everybody.

pros: There is a fair amount of political will to encourage innovation, commercialize scientific discoveries and encourage startups. The university has a wealth of discoveries that could be commercialize.
cons: The university is not good at all at commercializing innovation. Bureaucracy, backward academic mentality and egos hold the university's efforts back. The innovation department could do with much better leadership and staff.

review_title: (Job title: Research Assistant.) Great university. Administration should change relationship with union.
job_title: Aircraft Maintenance Supervisor in Seattle, WA
pros: Graduate employee union for RAs, TAs, and postdocs fights hard and fair. This is of huge importance in a city that is increasingly hard to afford to live in.
cons: In the last contract negotiation with our grad employee union, the president Ana Marie Cauce was much more unwilling than her predecessors to meet the rising cost of living in Seattle. Academic employees pay hundreds of dollars a quarter to work in "student fees," a pay cut that the administration has refused to cap over time.

review_title: Job satisfaction depends largely on your supervisor
pros: Good work-life balance, training opportunities, flexible work schedule. Co-workers are generally good people and division of duties is often clearly spelled out given the roles of staff, faculty, etc.
cons: Strong hierarchies are difficult to overcome, job satisfaction depends greatly on who supervises your work, most supervisors are not well trained, and not consistency in terms of methods or processes for doing work across different units at the university.

pros: It's inspiring to be surrounded by so many curious, intelligent people pursuing their own hypotheses. There's an overwhelming amount of research underway at all times at the U. Talks, lectures and presentations from folks at the forefront of their fields are always going on. I work with people who are energetic and invested in their work, which I find key to maintaining my excitement.
cons: Despite the slow boil of creative energy all around, which is exciting, sometimes I yearn for more interdepartmental collaboration and discussion to guide the research we do.

review_title: Great place to work if you're looking to settle or retire
pros: Great work life balance; once you're in, it's easy to move around UW to find other jobs. People are generally very nice and down to earth. Because it's an academic institution, people here are generally supportive of learning and job growth. Overall company benefits are solid. Great place to work if you value work life balance.
cons: Can be bureaucratic and culture can be a little stuffy. Culture can range drastically on the team and department you're in. Not the place to be if you are driven, innovative, and want to move fast. The people you work with can range from incredibly awesome to incompetent. Do your best to gauge the culture in the interview process. Senior management can be out of touch with the people they manage.

review_title: Find a lab that suits your needs, and has funding.
pros:
Great learning opportunities, independant investigation, variety in workload. 
Great benefits, vacation, ins. retirement.
cons:
Very dependant on whose (PI) lab you are in.  Management styles vary drastically.  Lack of uniform professional develoment or oversight.   Low salaries for science jobs - (high salaries for admin though)
Great place to work for a couple years but, since their promotion/review system is so bad you will likely languish in the same job and find it hard to get promotion/recognition or increased responsibilities.   A great deal of work is take up by the Graduate Students who management is able to exploit (no overtime required).

review_title: The University of Washington is THE ideal place to fulfill your dreams and enrich your career!
job_title: Manager, Departmental Computing in Seattle, WA
pros: We have three beautiful campuses with a new one in development, we are famous for our cutting-edge research and technology, our outstanding faculty are recognized leaders in their field around the world, we are led by outstanding leadership, we greatly enjoy strong support financially from the state legislature, we are provided with unparalleled medical/dental and retirement plans, we have all government holidays off (paid) and generous vacation allotments, we also are provided with fully subsidized bus passes which save us a lot of money at the fuel pump and are valid on all the regional public transportation organizations.  The people in the University of Washington are also of the highest caliber.
cons: There is no downside at the UW!

pros: It's in the name.  It's a university.  The benefits were better than industry, but the bureaucracy was more troublesome.  The location was great, easily accessible by public transportation and the flexcars (now zipcars) on site were very useful.  The U-pass is a fabulous perk, I got very spoiled by never having to pay for transit when I wanted to ride, it was all pre-paid.
cons: Academic hierarchy can be rigid, as can that associated with governmental institutions.  I'm not sure how to work around some of the pay-scale rigidity, I know there is some flexibility, but was never very good at taking advantage of that, so I was a bit under-paid the entire time I was there.

review_title: Good intentions, too resource-strapped and bureacratic to innovate.
pros:
Large, stable institution.
Work-life balance is definitely possible.
About as consistent as you can get in today's economy.
As a big player in academia, working for the UW gives you good access to vendors and the thought-leader space.
cons:
Ugh--so much bureaucracy it can be maddening.
Lots of stagnation--many people have been in the same job for so long that they're burnt out, detached and not doing a particularly good job any more.
No real opportunities for change or innovation at such a large, slow-moving, government funded organization.
Lots of talk about good ideas, not so much support for execution.

pros: Wonderful, supportive and able staff and faculty and huge opportunities for growth and success.
cons: Not transparent or consistent in campus planning and growth.  We are struggling with things like old systems, old ways of thinking, low pay, not enough parking or living for student growth, and progress in planning happening too slow.  Also, culture and values are not aligned with what is being projected versus campus actual.

pros: I worked as a student teacher's assistant by invitation- it was a perfect part time job and provided flexible hours, a relationship-based community, and fair pay. Also, I was able to work in one of the best universities!
cons: In midterms and finals, especially as a student myself, this job can feel quite busy and you might feel stressed managing so many things at once. Also, you are capped at a certain amount of hours.

job_title: Fiscal Specialist II in Seattle, WA
pros: The salary is competitive. There is a union at the UW but they do get us good conditions and salary!  We have great choices of vacation and days off.  The choices we have for health benefits are very generous. There are many job choices at the University.  Once you pass the probation you have a wide variety of jobs you can choose. There are many locations and jobs to choose from.
cons:
The University is so big you can easily get lost.  One way you can standout is to 
know who you are, what you want and where you want to go.  For every job you 
select, you will learn a lot and this will enable you to go far. As you do a good job at every job and move up the ladder, you will get a 'word of mouth' approval and recommendation from various people that will be important to you at a later date.

review_title: Good experience but it really depends on what type of job and what kind of supervisor you have.
pros: Good benefits/retirement, etc.  Some opportunity for advancement/classes (depending on where you are and who your supervisor is).  Some depts offer discretionary leave in lieu of raise freeze.
cons: Raise freeze going into the 5th year.  A lot of work and pressure to perform with increased volume without raises but yet increase in parking fees and most times insurance premiums and taxes so ultimately, you end up making less each year.  Minimal room for advancement if you have reached the top of your salary range and/or topped out in your current field and limited support/approval to reclass/reallocate current position to a higher level.  May make more working in the private sector.

pros: This is a stable space to work with a large range of job opportunities. If one field of work does't quite fit, odds are there may be something else which might work better,  because working here is somewhat like working in a small city. The benefits are great!
cons: If you don't love working with young people (17-22) or do not love walking (the campus is huge and parking is spare), then this is not your place. I'm a lecturer with a fairly good salary compared to other lecturers. That's rare and living in Seattle is ridiculously expensive. I have to commute from outside Seattle as do most of my colleagues.

review_title: A proud past, a sad present, a murky future
pros: Really smart technical people (though that's less true than it used to be), a great history of doing good things (IMAP was built here, we did the first HD over IP, etc), good pay and excellent benefits. Good respect for work-life balance, and flexible (usually) on time and hours. It's great to work on a major university campus.
cons: Executive leadership is aging, out of touch, and hopelessly confused. It's very top heavy and bureaucratic, and that trend seems to be on the rise. Recent budget cuts and extensive layoffs are evidence of the morass the organization now has to fight its way out of - success is not guaranteed.

review_title: Pay is bad, people are fun.
pros: Flexible hours, fun people.  The work is really easy.  The people there were really helpful and it was fun to talk to a wide range of people.  We got to attend workshops and hold events for students and I found that very rewarding.  Our higher ups were very nice as well.
cons: The pay is really low, almost laughable for even students.  I couldn't support myself on my wages and had to look elsewhere eventually even though I liked the work I was doing.  We were given a lot of freedom but at the same time the budget alloted to us could not work with what we wanted to do.

pros: I worked in the Applied Physics Lab as a Research Scientist.  Lots of freedom to work with a variety of PI's and do fascinating work.  My PI's were really great mentors and gave me a lot of freedom to explore additional opportunities to extend my skills.  I quickly went from just managing getting buoys to their ships to being a field engineer in just a few months.
cons: All of the funding for your position at APL is grant dependent.  If the funding dries up and there is no other team with an available slot you are stuck.  The new leadership team coming in this year is making it a priority to fix that for the research staff.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
+ Lots of resources available for students and faculty, often through Seattle's philanthropic community but also through city/state/federal sources. 
+ Almost too many opportunities for collaboration (between departments, schools, and whole institutions)
+ Many possible career paths, many of which lead to or are adjacent to industry.
+ Several unions (for graduates, faculty, and staff) keep benefits competitive(-ish). 
+ Beautiful campus. Seriously. It's often rated as one of the top 5 most beautiful campuses in the world.
cons:
- Sometimes they don't give us the raises / benefits we need when we need them. They are constrained by the state budget, after all.
- Sometimes administration is bureaucratic to a fault. (Also: the sky is blue.)
- There is a diversity problem on campus, but they're working on it.

review_title: Great place to work with excellent support services
pros: The UW has an entire office dedicated to visa sponsorship support. There is also the opportunity to take UW classes and of course the great benefits.
cons: Lack of  broad career training for postdoctoral fellows. Any training is highly academia focused and not enough information or training is provided to help postdocs make the transition into alternative careers.

pros: I loved working for UW. It's great being part of such a big organization that provides many opportunities for growth and learning. I worked as part of a research study so I had a small group of coworkers. They were wonderful, kind, smart women. I had flexible hours as a behavioral coder and decent pay. I even got some benefits at one point that continued on even after my hours dropped. I love walking through UW campus..there's alway something going on.
cons: Parking is horribly expensive at UW campus so I would take the bus instead. I actually enjoyed the commute...it gave me time to read.

review_title: A  good learning place but severely underfunded
job_title: Research Scientist II in Seattle, WA
pros: A good place if you have just graduated and are at entry level in your career. There are ample opputtunities to learn new technologies , take  class room and online courses to advance your knowledge. Casual atmosphere and not very heirarchial as in some other universities.
cons:
University takes up a big chunk of any grant money limiting how much actually is available for  research expenses and salaries. Salaries are not quite commensurate wtih experience or qualifications and much below market value. 
HR department is very slow to intervene when it comes to advising on rights or options when grants run out  and staff lose jobs.

review_title: I worked with wonderful people on a beautiful campus with low pay and regular bureaucratic rigmarole.
job_title: Manager of Program Operations in Seattle, WA
pros: I love being around brilliant people--students, staff and faculty--working with fascinating ideas. The campus is beautiful, and the benefits are pretty good. It is an inclusive environment that strives (sometimes halfheartedly) to support diversity.
cons: Though very informal, there is a very distinct and fairly rigid hierarchy, leading to struggles between and among faculty, staff and higher administration. After 10 years, my salary was about equal to a low-level office assistant position at a local private sector business.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Select professors have amazing amounts of funding, and the graduate health benefits are decent. If you get a committee that doesn't chastise you for taking courses outside your department that help you do your research, you have it made!
cons: These comments apply only to my old department, I hope. Tenured professors weren't held accountable for their actions (e.g. sloppy teaching, poor advising, sexist remarks), but I suppose that's more a problem with tenure than with UW. Horrendous and toxic office culture, and the administration is often completely oblivious to student needs. You were seen as weak if you prioritized your life outside of work.

review_title: A huge bureaucracy, so, hard to say
pros:
Ability to switch between appointments at the university relatively easily (if your bosses are okay with it)
Beautiful campus with lovely gardens in which you can rest and relax
Being around big ideas
Stable
Ability to maintain work-life balance
cons:
Bureaucracy...grr So many useless forms, so much repeated work.
Old systems
Isolation and envy between schools/departments
It's rare that those big ideas get implemented
Benefits aren't great, in my opinion...at least compared to friends who work at universities in other states
Food options for lunch aren't the best

pros: I love working at the University of WASHINGTON , the people was very nice and a very nice place to work , the Job was demanding but was was very fair , love the people that I work with . we all work together when we had to but still work good when we had to work alone , students was very nice and polite .
cons: Sorry , there wasn't no downside about working there

pros: The overall environment is supportive and positive. While there are often dead ends in career paths, many managers actively suggest and respect educational opportunities which can promote moving in a new direction to further or change a career.
cons: Depending on the department and management involved, there are a lot of politics and petty arguments which can stand in the way of progress as well as stunt the cooperative spirit of the school. Often new ideas are stopped dead in their tracks for fear of stepping on sensitive toes.

pros: Working for HFS was good for student life, provided some cash and a bit of training. Work environment is generally pretty good, and things run like a moderately oiled machine. Pay was around minimum wage, which in Seattle is sort of good.
cons: Typical retail nonsense can sometimes apply, its bearable. It is a big operation so its easy to feel like another numbered employee, even when you go the extra mile.

review_title: decentralization can lead to inequity and lack of support
pros: advisers are able to participate in professional development, depending on the unit they work for, and the advising community itself is supportive
cons: advising community is supportive but as a whole are not supported in a proactive way by leadership.  many initiatives for professional development are led by the advising community and not by managers.  job titles differ from unit to unit, as does treatment of advisers - some good, some not

review_title: Stimulating intellectual environment; administrative positions can be frustrating because of an emphasis on process.
pros: Some great co-workers and the chance to contribute to the greater good. Tuition waivers are great depending in your field (beware: fee-based programs are not covered by the tuition waiver!) My boss was terrific about letting me structure my half-time hours around those seminars that occurred during business hours. Loved that flexibility.
cons: Rules and process can overshadow progress. It really depends on the area where you work, however.

job_title: Senior Bio Statistician in Seattle, WA
pros: There is great flexibility at the UW and you get an opportunity to play in everyone's research playground. The UW is one of the largest medical research communities in the world. As a research scientist, you can engage in meaningful research projects without having the baggage of a formal academic appointment.
cons: There is little to normal formal management or human resource support available across most/all departments. As a research scientist, the primary source of funding is grant support -- a non-stop treadmill that you need to run on.

review_title: Flexibility and freedom can be found in academic jobs at UW
pros: If you work on the academic side, it's great. Hours are flexible, you can take flex time if you need to run errands during the day. Even sometimes the staff jobs in the academic departments are flexible as well. Benefits (health care, retirement) and vacation are great. Generally speaking, the UW reflects the laid-back NW style. People here tend to take time to smell the roses and enjoy their life outside of work. If you work in research, the UW is one of the best funded research universities in the US.
cons: Probably for a lot of positions the pay is not as good as what you would get in private industry.

pros: A foot in the door allowed me to enjoy  a solid start to my career which included 3 upward moves. I had access to training, great benefits and workshops. The institution is huge so you have a lot of room for horizontal movement as long as you can adjust to different departments' culture.
cons:
A semi-public institution, in many cases it feels like a government job. The dynamics and upward mobility of your job often depends on your supervisor and unit director. Change takes a long time to happen. 
Compensation is also lower than market, given that this is a partially-public funded institution (or in some cases, research grant funded).

review_title: Great environment for people who need flexibility
pros: Flexible schedules and pretty good benefits. They will try and sell you on the tuition exemption program but be weary - it's VERY hard to take advantage of and only applies to a few areas of study. If this is a huge selling point for you do your research and make sure you can actually take the classes you want!
cons: Poor management (and too much management), red-tape and politics make it hard to achieve success, slow work environment. This isn't a place for hungry young professionals, it's an environment suited for people looking for a stable, easy, job.

review_title: University Succeeds Despite Its Administrative Shortcomings
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Stellar in the classroom and research.  Also local health care to the area.
cons: Bureaucratic and controlling - everything needs to be approved by someone else.  Not innovative; they need outside brainpower but insist the "UW Way" is correct.

job_title: Advanced Practice Provider in Seattle, WA
pros: Good state benefits, comp reasonable, interesting and unique patients.
cons: Little to CME money. No options to advance if not from UW. Not appreciated by most physicians and sometimes verbally abusive. Departments have hard lines and do not work well together. Constant unsafe conditions due to poor staffing and lack of management support. No vision for future. Ego drives motivation. Many people leaving poor retention if any attempt. Very passive aggressive atmosphere people will not attempt to address issues face to face. poor culture. Expensive parking.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Bothell, WA
pros: Great benefits and time off one you been with company for a while
cons: While institution as a whole has great ambition and resources it is ultimately depends on your supervisor if you will have access to them. There is not standards that supervisors are being upheld to and everyone does whatever they believe to be fit. Performance evaluations are a joke because they are not tied in to anything. You can work nights and weekends if you like but that does not guarantee any position advancement.  Extremely bureaucratic.

review_title: Nice place to work if you are recognized by a big PI.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Job could be stable, with good benefit, including good insurance package for family.   Usually have  flexible hours, and can take time off or work at home if you need to. People are generally very friendly and nice. Nice gym and facilities.
cons: bureaucracy like all governmental organizations. have some stigma. Sometimes promotion is not based on what you deserve, but more on how your ass kicking skills.  lower than average salary, slow promotion period, competitive, pressure, you have to kiss big PI's ass if you want to be recognized and support by the group.

review_title: Great people, great benefits, low salary across the board
pros: Great health care, retirement, and professional development. Great place to retire.
cons: Not competitive salary. Far below state average. Under pays all positions except for high leadership roles such as HR director ($86k), and senior director positions ($90k). All administrative positions are EXTREMELY competitive and some departments don't have a career ladder.

review_title: A great place for students to work part-time.
job_title: Bike Shop Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: The people are very friendly, and it's a great place to work as a student. For building up a resume, you really can't beat it. Specifically, I worked in the Bike Shop as the manager and got great experience while maintaining flexible hours to keep my academic priorities in line.
cons: The bureaucracy can be extremely annoying to go through in order to get things done. It takes a lot of time for new ideas to become actionable.

review_title: A big company lumbering into the ether (2.5 stars)
pros: Great deal of resources (e.g. state of the art equipment) available to research staff.  Collection of world class researchers performing  high level research.
cons: Bureaucratic nightmare to maneuver around.  Extremely top heavy administration, with a large volume of busy work created jobs that do little more than extract indirect costs.  Overly ambitious capitol expenditure plan with no real vision of how to occupy the space being built.  Poor to non-existent start up packages.  Systematic elimination of tenure.

review_title: The highly flexible scheduling, convenient location, and relatively good pay make Bay Laurel ideal for students at UW.
pros:
(1)  Better pay (and more responsibility)  than other student jobs at the university
(2)  Very flexible with scheduling around classes
(3)  Lots of independence during shifts
(4)  There are many different types of shifts so work is not dull and repetitive.
cons:
(1)  Occasionally in the summer hours are low, but this is often offset by the opportunity to work 50+ hours some weeks for overtime pay (no pressure to work that much though).
(2)  Occasionally some shifts can be stressful or busy but typically they are very reasonably paced and often include time to work on homework.

review_title: Comfortable and ethical but no real team work
job_title: Web Computing Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros:
People seem more ethical, or at least less concerned with being better than other people EXCEPT when it comes to demonstrating one's ability to think critically.

Comfortable, low-key workplace. The lack of a financial bottom line means that it is almost impossible to assess performance so there isn't an overwhelming sense of competition. Also, home/personal life concerns are always honored over work responsibilities. 

Beautiful campus.

Being around students: they are sharp, wise, and soft at the same time, as they navigate the world as adults for the first time in their lives.

Stabiilty: not a huge threat of layoffs, even though latest budget crisis.

Good benefits. Lots to do: lectures, concerts, museums, trainings, classes, etc.

Education of youth is a profound mission, and meant to help people, and to help society.
cons:
Well, I like to say it is a bit like East German socialism: the floor is not too low, but the ceiling isn't very high either. In my experience, the motivation for excellence in government jobs can suffer due to lack of significant incentives or disincentives. There is a palpable sense of inertia and a conspiracy at times to maintain a status quo that does not make any additional demands on anyone.

There is a lot of tribalism: it is hard to get beyond one's local orbit of people and power. Can be very lonely. In my experience, people are not too friendly.

Gender imbalance in staff. I think the fairly low salary encourages men to move on to positions of higher pay beyond the university while women stay because they are not the primary "bread winner" in the household, plus the benefits are good. This disparity is not healthy.

Great deal of naivety concerning the value of professional services -- either what to expect, or how to compensate.

As a computing specialist, I specifically suffer from lack of centralized management who are trained in my field. Web computing specialists are "embedded" into separate niches within the university and we report to people who are trying their best to understand tech work but in the end are mostly guessing.

review_title: This organization is the most disorganized and confusing place I have ever worked.
pros: Campus is nice especially in summer.  When you tell people you work for the UW they are very impressed.
cons: Total lack of coordination within IT which has resulted in multiple groups/organizations working entirely on their own with free rein to do anything with the systems.  No communication between groups and no documentation about anything. Everything relies on workers memorys of how things work or did work.

review_title: Overall I enjoyed working for the university
job_title: Senior Computer Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: The benefits package and vacation time is wonderful. A balance between your personal life and work is encouraged.
cons: While there is good management at the university I unfortunately had a manager that didn't have previous management experience and it showed. The communication from this person to their employees tended to be rude and condescending with a tendency to show favoritism. There isn't much opportunity to advance and they are behind in the technical world, unfortunately this can cause stagnation in ones career in the computer field.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Great health benefits when staying in the university health care system.  Excellent access to campus resources such as legal assistance, career help, or even help with campus life.
cons: As a graduate research assistant, no more of my time is spent as a "student" per-se, instead doing research approximately 50hrs per week.  However, the university classifies us as only half-time employees and half-time students.  That said, our pay is somewhat scant for living in Seattle.  On top of that, the student fees that we are required to pay have increased $300 per quarter since starting.  Our contracts stated that this should not occur, but the grad student union could not win this arguement.

review_title: UW-IT is a great place to work as a student!
pros:
- Managers who really care and advocate for employees' professional development and growth
- Team members who get along with each other and strive for a friendly culture
- Many levels of promotion - raises with each promotion
- Employees are encouraged to pick up new skills and given opportunities to utilize personal skills and interests to serve the team
cons:
- Sometimes clients can be really rude and difficult to deal with 
- The org is going through some leadership and vision changes right now that are making some processes confusing

review_title: Decent place to go to grad school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Number one is the location.  Seattle is a fantastic place to live and work while focusing on your PhD.  The grad students are unionized, which helps protect you from wage decreases.  This scenario did happen while I have been here.
cons: Number one is location.  Seattle can be a rewarding place to live, but it can be soul sucking to walk to work in the grey for weeks in a row.  Number two is the size of the undergraduate schools- the physics students number in the high hundreds here, meaning that physics grad students are under increased pressure when serving as their TAs.

review_title: Excellent place to become the best version of you.
pros: Great to be part of a large, prestigious, globally recognized and connected institution. A lot of opportunities for lateral transfers, personal improvement, and career advancement. Well-developed sense of community among all Huskies past and present.
cons: Being part of a very large institution can make you feel insignificant and/or lost within the bureaucracy. Staff at administrative and executive levels do not appear to be well connected to those working under them.

review_title: Want be part of Husky tradition, work at UDUB!
job_title: Research Technologist II in Seattle, WA
pros: If you are looking for a job security with some opportunity for career advancement within university settting, this is a good place for you. They provide excellent health benefits and retirement plan. A rare opportunity to obtain season tickets for Husky football games (long wait list). Tuitition reimbursements up to 6 credits per quarter.
cons: Low pay and limited opportunities for job promotion depending on the size of the department and high turnover in sample processing and laboratory technician position. Some weekends work are required.

review_title: I enjoyed working as a student employee with Housing and Food Services at University of Washington
pros: My supervisors were always very accommodating to my schedule requests and always worked around my school schedule.  It's also nice to work here as a student because they cannot schedule you over 19.5 hours per week, which makes working as a student more feasible.  There are some opportunities for advancement and moderate pay increases.
cons: There is some expectation to work weekend shifts and over break, particularly when you're first hired.  Another con is that there is high turnover with student employees so there is some inefficiency.

pros: health benefits, some co-workers are nice
cons: Management is not flexible. For a learning institution, the management in this department does not support learning or teaching new skills for employees who are interested to learn. This means cross training to open up the possibility for cross coverage, or even advancement of one's position, is not allowed. Personal education is only supported if done after your work hours. Taking advantage of the tuition exemption for when there are classes offered during the day time is not allowed. It's a terrible shame since some specialized classes is only offered during the day, on a weekday, and limited to the times it is offered each year.

job_title: Graduate Student Teaching Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Diversity of students in terms of race/ethnicity, academic levels e.g. undergraduate to graduate, socioeconomic status. It was a great experience to work with students in different courses and fantastic instructors that were always supportive of not just the students they teach but of the teaching assistants as well.
cons: A disadvantage is that working part-time (20hrs/week) as a graduate student does not translate as part-time because it mostly felt like a full-time job especially when it is a requirement to add 10 credits of course work to the already busy schedule.

pros: The overall work atmosphere  is pleasant with a competitive salary and benefits.  During certain times of the year, mainly at the beginning of each quarter, you are often bombarded with massive amounts of paperwork - which is a good thing, as it allows you to keep busy.
cons: Often very noisy during peak hours as the university students head to their next class, making difficult to concentrate on mentally demanding tasks.

pros: Solid stable work environment. State funded University so you receive all the state benefits. Good medical, dental, vacation and sick leave. Flexibility depends on what department you work in. Working on the Education side is much more relaxed that the Medical side. Departments such as Social Work and Education are more relaxed vs. Business or LAw.
cons: hard to transition form a classified union position to a non union professional staff. Pay is based on Washington State salaries. State jobs pay less than other public sector jobs such as county and city jobs. More diversity in work place and campus; especially in management.

pros: There are a wide variety of classes to teach; you'll never be bored if you don't want to be! There is a fair amount of support for learning to teach from the department and school. In the mathematics department, graduate students are given a large amount of responsibility and it is very good experience.
cons: Not any particular cons, really. Regular reviews by teaching supervisors are really helpful, but do take time so I understand why more aren't done.

job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Seattle, WA
pros: There is much to be said about UW's productive environment. As a junior faculty, I have always had close collaborations and mentoring by senior colleagues. I do find many of my senior faculty approachable and willing to invest in you.
cons: Typical bureaucracy one encounters in any type of state agencies. Sometimes excessive red tape in trying to get simple things like IT services requested. Lack of innovation in that regards, with respect to IT services and health informatics services to present faculty,

pros:
Especially under the leadership of President Cauce, UW is increasingly becoming a diverse and inclusive working environment. 

Each unit and department is different and acts like a separate business, so I can really only speak to working in Undergraduate Academic Affairs.  It's a wonderful and supportive environment.  Leadership is supportive of a work/life balance. Staff have worked in the department for years.  They let you seek out professional development opportunities. 

So many job opportunities within the organization.

Benefits are amazing!
cons: It's extremely hard to get a raise outside of the yearly cost of living raise. Salaries are not competitive, especially when you look at compared to the City of Seattle.

review_title: Good work environment and educational institution
pros:
The faculty and staff at UW have always been very professional and helpful in my experience.  I've never had any trouble figuring out what was expected of me as a research assistant.
The medical benefits for the graduate assistant positions are at least as good as any I've had at former employers.
cons: The commute is a bit excessive if you choose to have a place with a yard bigger than a postage stamp, and you have to pay to park if you drive yourself in.

review_title: OK, if you don't mind being a second-class citizen
pros:
Interesting, intelligent people to work with.
Fun to be around so many kids.
Flexible schedule, informal dress code, great infrastructure to support teaching.
cons:
If you aren't faculty, you are lower caste, even if you are teaching a valued, popular class that no one on the faculty is qualified to teach.
I was hired to provide outreach to the community for possible service relationships, and was amazed to find how little interest or ability there was to actually provide needed services.

review_title: Overall good but beware of hiring politics
pros: Overall good place to work as far as benefits and retention of employees. They invest heavily in teaching all employees the complicated inner workings of UW so you have more valued professional skills.
cons: Hiring politics can be complicated. The large and clunky employment system can cause major delays in even the most simple HR changes. Need something? Be prepared to wait.

pros: Excellent Benefits:  Vacation and sick leave, FMLA policies, health and dental, employer-matched retirement savings, emphasis on work-life balance like back-up childcare (though sometime you have to go digging to find these).  It's more than lip-service that UW wants to keep its employees happy.
cons: Somewhat stagnant wages.  There was a wage-freeze over several years a few years ago, with little rebound or catch-up growth since (at least where I am, your mileage might vary).  Commute into Seattle can be brutal if you don't live in the immediate vicinity.

pros: Seattle is an nice location in the summer.  The university is in a beautiful and easy to get to location. UW has a good reputation for a life sciences studies. Hard to generalize since every department is different...
cons: Depends on which department you are in but some are not very cohesive or supportive of students and fellows.  If you have your own grant they try to take your money from you.  If you have your own grant you do not get ANY retirement benefits. You should be thankful that researchers bring in the grant money rather than punish them for it.

pros: Good work life balance, comfortable office to sit in all day.
cons: Low pay.  Massive political mess...there is lots of back stabbing, undercutting, and brown nosing going on at UW Bothell.  People talk behind your back, play favorites, and try to push talented people out.  Not a place to try and advance your career, you will sit and rot in your position with little compensation to boot.  If you want low pay, want a job where you sit on your behind all day and aren't challenged...then this is the place for you.

pros: I worked in the department of genome sciences and the quality of the work there was top-notch nearly across the board. Numerous top-tier academics and superb access to resources. Individual experiences will depend on the position and the lab, but I suspect that most people looking for a high powered academic job won't be disappointed by the genome sciences dept.
cons: It's a huge state institution with all of the headaches that normally come with such places - there's a fair amount of red tape, and attempting to change some policy or procedure is likely impossible. Parking near campus is close to impossible, and the buses don't typically run on time.

pros: It really depends on boss/department, but I found it to be pretty flexible about work hours. Benefits are decent. I loved working with a small group of scientists. Work is meaningful and fulfilling.
cons: Working for a professor can be challenging. They don't have training as managers, and so some of them are much better at it than others.  Can be difficult to get raises, other than the automatic ones that come with time in grade. Grossly underpay software developers.

pros: Excellent and supportive community. Many opportunities to grow in your career and experience outside of your lab.
cons: As you probably know, the salary is not great, but is comparable to other public institutions.

pros: Great benefits, some flexibility, employee organization is excellent, access to many lectures and low cost yoga/meditation classes. It's honorable work to contribute to the success of the University. Work/Life balance is very good.
cons: Management is not engaged with what is going on with their direct reports/depts regarding workload, with a lack of organization and follow through. The same projects/issues are discussed over and over again, over many years in some cases, with no real outcomes. Indifference to new ideas. Lack of accountability

review_title: Learn all about media equipment and technical support.
pros:
For a college student, CSS offers the following advantages:
- It is relatively easy to rise in the ranks if you can follow instructions.
- Very flexible scheduling.
- There are always different clients with different needs, which keeps the job exciting.
cons:
Some cons:
- Work hours are inconsistent per week.
- Sometimes the shifts end 1 or 2 am.
- The shifts are short and not worthwhile initially. You receive longer shifts as you gain experience.

job_title: Web Design Intern in Seattle, WA
pros:
-Excellent balance with classes and work, I worked about 10-15 hours a week with a full course load.
-Really laid back workplace.
-Fun and laid-back coworkers.
-Lots of autonomy and flexibility to work on what you want, you get to decide for yourself on what to improve and work on.
cons:
-Can be slow in terms of pace
-Low pay
-Silos, working cross-functionally is a pain in the rear. No one likes to share.
-Not good for ambitious people who want to do more.
-As with every academic institution it comes with the office politics.

review_title: My UW job has been fun and stimulating in that it provides me with many opportunities for problem solving and learning.
pros: Co-workers are interesting and smart, the work changes and requires the team to change and learn too. The UW has good fringe benefits.
cons: The pay scale is too low.

job_title: Software Engineer/IT Architect in Seattle, WA
pros: The UW IT Department has been making a concerted effort over the past several years to improve its practices with IT Service Management and Project Management, IT/Business Architectural leadership, Disaster Recovery planning, and collaboration across IT groups to share best practices and communicate project status.  Working for a university is like working for a "good cause."  The staff are generally high quality.
cons: There seem to be some biases, perhaps due to individuals more so than systemic biases, that result in failure to reward exceptional leadership on the technical track, esp for females.

job_title: Dining Room Service in Seattle, WA
pros: They are very accommodating with class and finals schedules. You can work between 10 and 19 hours a week. You have the same schedule per week for a whole quarter. I suggest telling them you would like to work hours lower than you actually want and pick up shifts so when you actually need that time off to study, you can without hassle.
cons: You can work 19 hours per week tops when you are a full time student per their policy. They also don't train people super well so just ask them lots of questions as you go and you will get the hang of it.

pros: The University of Washington is one of the top universities in the world, and the largest employer in the state. Seattle is a wonderful place to live.
cons: Following the 2008-11 recession, about half  of the universities annual budget is the hospital.  While originally a university with a hospital, it has become a hospital with a university. Priorities are on health care and raising grant money.  Education and training are low on the list.

review_title: The opportunities at the UW are as vast as the institution - and the employee experience can be just as varied!
pros: Pretty decent benefits. Many positions are union positions, so employees have assurance of some work-life balance and continued cost of living wage increases. Extensive research community - lots to learn, many talented people. You can always learn in this environment if you put your mind to it.
cons: There is little done to address workplace dysfunction. Because it is such a large, decentralized institution, it can be hard to efficiently get work done.

pros: It's fun, meet lots of people, some RDs are fantastic and upbeat, Wesr Campus is energetic and lively, makes housing on campus affordable, learned a lot of great leadership and communication skills (and a ton more!)
cons: Change is excruciatingly slow, North Campus is dingy and has few amenities, not transparent about hiring practices.

pros: Leaders in the field. Opportunities for career advancement through collaborating on NIH grants to raise national and international profile.
cons: 100% research focused, almost 100% grant funded. Little support from departments for junior investigators. Proliferation of "acting" titles to allow hiring faculty at lower wages to wait until they "hit it big" with a grant, and then they offer a standard position.

pros: Great retirement match, good benefits, mostly good work-life balance, attracts good well-meaning people
cons: Salary is 25% below market. Best for academics or newbies wanting to learn how to be in an office- bad for non-academic professionals. Leadership favors personal relationships over effectiveness and experience. General distrust for non-academics creates internal competition versus collaboration.

review_title: Great benefits. Low pay. Poorly trained administration staff
pros: Medical benefits are outstanding in a low-stress environment.  Not a bad place to work if you are looking for a secure, low paying job and have a medical condition.  Performance evaluation process and unions make it difficult to get fired.  WA state labor policy appears to make downsizing difficult.
cons: From an administrative perspective, does not appear to be  a good place to work if you are in a management position and appreciate efficiency.  Internal training programs appear to be non-existent for administrative staff.

review_title: Great pay, great benefits, so-so job
job_title: Contact Center Representative in Seattle, WA
pros: Stability, great pay, great benefits, many opportunities to advance and learn new skills,
cons: The metrics put too much emphasis on how fast work gets done. They also track every second you are on a bathroom break or away from your desk. No matter if you have had great customer interactions all day, if you go to the bathroom one too many times your numbers go down. You start to feel as if you are under a magnifying glass. Also the entire job is solitary, you in your cubicle, on your phone.

review_title: Great place to start a career!
pros: Everyone is friendly and willing to help out, no one blames one another if there's trouble. There's a warm and supportive environment. Everyone here does their job seriously and does their job well. Also, full time staff qualify for a tuition exempt (almost free classes!) which is an amazing perk.
cons: At least in my position, it would be nice if there was a set path to learn on my career. A lot of what I've learned here has been on my own, with no real knowledge of how the quality of my work holds up

review_title: Great employer, despite current economic downturn and expected reductions in staffing.
pros: Opportunities for promotion and movement within the University. Benefits are generous, and colleagues are team-oriented and supportive, depending on the department. A mix of those with a great deal of university-based experience as well as staff recruited from outside of academia. There are continued calls for staff to apply for trainings and join departmental and inter-departmental committees on a variety of issues.
cons: Salary levels are low, particularly in comparison to other universities.

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: Good work environment and excellent benefits
cons:
Low pay
No emphasis on career planning or development for staff
Hierarchical "academic" environment
Very different work "culture" depending on which School/Department you end up in

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: It is nice to have funding to attend conferences around the country. You get good public speaking skills.
cons: There is no concept of work life balance. You're supposed to work 60+ hour weeks yet be happy with salary policies that assume 20 hr weeks. There is no time for teaching but that is required too. The health insurance sucks.

review_title: I love the students and my coworkers at UW Seattle.  Great environment and workplace!
job_title: Part Time Letcturer in Seattle, WA
pros: Opportunity to join a world class group of faculty and researchers.  Students are eager to learn.  Most classes are scheduled on a 2 day block, either M/W or T/Th, which allows for a great work-life balance.
cons: Parking at the Seattle campus is over crowded, inconvenient, and expensive.  The meal options on campus are vast, but the lines are long and time between classes is short.  Suggest bringing your own lunch or take a brisk walk to University Ave.

review_title: Registered Nurse UW Northwest Hospital OPMC
pros: Amazing patients!  Benefits are good!  I love option to wave benefits and receive 15% salary increase!
cons:
Overtime.  Working through lunches and after hours. Nurses can be spread thin by multi tasking and wearing too many hats.  For example, the nurse takes on the roll of medical assistant and receptionist. It's difficult to get approval to hire additional staff. Managers are spread thin, managing 2 to 3 other clinics at a time. 

Electronic medical records systems don't talk to each other, leading to timely additional chart data entry.

review_title: UW is a great place for a researcher
pros: You get to work with some of the brightest people in the world. The University bureaucracy is for the most part, very favorable to the researchers. They interfere very little and do their best to help you get your work done.
cons: Very few. There was some resentment towards higher salaries among some HR staff. Some of the departments are weaker than the very top universities.

pros:
Working at a University is the great opportunity to work with smart people who are committed to working in the public sector. 
IT department management is excellent, has a good grasp of strategic planning, and delivering large-scale services.
cons: Politics have frozen state salaries for the past five years, so if you entered that long ago your pay is well below average. If you are thinking of working here plan on negotiating for as high a salary as you can get with the expectation that it will not increase.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Seattle, WA
pros:
1) Very nice researcher environment
2) One of the best places to meet and collaborate with great people, researchers, innovators
3) If your dream is to have a startup, this is one of the best places
4) Smell great ideas in the air
5) Very nice health insurance
6) Lots of great tech talks, seminars and events
7) Lots of workshops with Microsoft researchers
cons:
1) The Gym fee should be waived for postdoctoral associate (and their spouses too)
2) Super expensive parking space
3) I hate rain here...
4) should have more Friday-night activities (e.g., free movies) for students.
5) I work too hard (but I love to) compared to my salary

review_title: Good place to work for but people here have no idea who software engineers are  and what they do.
pros:
Stress free work.
Fairly good benefits.
Tuition exempt in school.
cons:
Very political.
Has to prove to IT department folks why developer needs full admin rights on his/hers own machine. This should be trivial. In short, people lack development knowledge domain.
Not prone to changes, even when they are obviously beneficial to the processes.

pros: If your a student doing the Work Study program, the best part about it is that they are very flexible with your school times and are willing to change your hours when needed, of course this varies by the department you are working at, but as for my experience, the School of Public Health provided an unforgettable yet growing experience.
cons: The only con I have in mind is working in the Health Sciences Building. It can be confusing to navigate and even more difficult to give directions to others on the phone!

pros: They are very flexible and work with your schedule, give you school holidays off, are very friendly, and understand that students aren't able to work an excessive amount of hours.
cons: Not the best training, kind of went into making coffee blind. Was hired as a student coordinator with also very little training there, kind of just thrown in and had to figure things out for myself.

pros: Solid benefits, good people, service focus, dedicates individuals, strong mission, inclusive culture, diverse workforce, beautiful campus, and main campus easily accessible via public transportation.
cons: Top heavy administration, unnecessarily political, heavily siloed environment, advancement not always based on qualification or merit but favoritism, and lack of collective vision for IT services.

review_title: Job but no career at UW
pros: I work with people who are motivated and want to do good work. I can get time off when I need it; the hours are fairly flexible.
cons: Low pay and no recognition or performance reviews (so little opportunity to ask for a higher salary and discuss career goals). This isn't encouraged. Many talented people in science have left due to lack of funding.

review_title: Good people, bad pay, health care plan sucks
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Seattle, WA
pros: Lots of flexibility, good supportive supervisors. Most of the people I encountered within and outside my department were helpful.
cons: Unless you're tenured or high-ranking administrator, the pay is typically awful. Grad students are supposed to not care about the money, though I guess that's a common theme in academia. It was really difficult to opt-out of the graduate student insurance plan because they enroll you automatically. Said plan is apparently pretty limited according to my coworkers.

pros: Because things move a bit slower and people take their time to do proper analysis, which allows for team members to really delve into topics of interest and learn as much as they can on any topic
cons: The slow pace in which academia moves can be a bit exhausting and sometimes a moral downer. Also, the way in which knowledge is gathered over a long period of time, when the time finally comes to implement, there is only knowledge to go off of instead of "trial and error" type experience.

job_title: Research Scientist/Engineer III in Seattle, WA
pros: If you're in academia, you know what you got into.  The UW is a large institution and with a little leg work, research can move relatively fast with access to many collaborators.
cons: Academic science sucks if you're in it for the money.  Also, once you passed 5 years of post-doctoral work, they have to reclassify you into another job category.  This makes you "expensive" for the professor who is paying your salary.

review_title: Good work for a student in a good environment
pros: There are a lot of opportunities available for students to work and learn, especially in the technology field. People are friendly and the work environment is very clear about what is going on.
cons: As a student working there, past experience is sometimes overlooked and even on things you may have a lot of skill and experience in, you can get the feeling that they believe you are still 'just learning the ropes'.

review_title: There is something here for everyone
job_title: Manager of Program Operations in Seattle, WA
pros: State Universities have diffuse but hierarchical power structures.  There are state rules and regulations, university rules and regulations, faculty rules and regulations, programmatic rules and regulations.  This is both a pro and a con.  Decent benefits but noncompetitive compensation.  Casual dress.
cons: Do not look for enlightened leadership and/or human resources policies here.  There is no formal management training.  Every office, much less every department, is managed differently.  The State Legislature decreed no salary increases for the last four years, even if your source of funding is not from the state.

pros: Easy to schedule hours around class schedule and often got to work with great people. Work was half on and half off which was fantastic for working on homework or other things.
cons: Often overloaded with hours and nearly impossible to find a substitute when needed. Schedule lasted an entire quarter which was both good and bad for scheduling.

pros: This position was very laid back, and provided plenty of opportunities to do homework. The work culture is fantastic, and everybody was so nice. You also get to meet quite a lot of people that are using the library, which is an added bonus. As it is a student job, school always comes first.
cons: As this is a student position, there were occasionally issues such as one coworker taking multiple days off, but refusing to cover for you when you want to take a day off too. As with any hourly pay job there are no added benefits or bonuses.

pros: I loved this job! Great coworkers, sweet supervisors and super flexible scheduling. I thought the work itself was fun too! There was always a variety of different things to do and everyday was different. It was easy to get hired too. I applied online and a few days later I received an email with my new schedule - I wasn't even interviewed! I started out as a Student Dining Assistant and was promoted to Student Coordinator after 4 months. Wonderful student job.
cons: In the year that I worked there I had 3 different managers. High turnover rate.

job_title: Director, Program Management in Seattle, WA
pros:
I worked in the business school for 5+ years. What I loved about working at UW and the b-school:
+There is a lot of organizational pride and external recognition when working for a well-known and respected university and top ranked business school. I loved the love and smiles I got when I told people in the community where I worked. It was always a conversations starter.
+The campus is really beautiful and a nice place to work. Seeing students of all ages on a daily basis is energizing. It's great to be a part of someone's education and dreams. Many of my co-workers were in it for the mission and love of what higher ed stands for -- rather than money (goodness knows staff are not paid top dollar). Thus, there is a lot of passion for the work. While I went to college elsewhere, I got to be a Husky by profession. That was and still is cool! It's what I miss most.
+Benefits are very  good and competitive with corporate jobs. 
+ There are lots of really smart people in a university and that raises the floor and the ceiling in terms of the quality of people attracted across every type of job. That's a powerful asset (sadly wasted -- see cons).
+ Public transportation options are pretty good  
+Diversity is cherished. I think UW in general and the b-school in particular truly do a lot to be inclusive regarding a wide range of individual differences. The one ironic exception (noted in cons) is discriminatory attitudes and treatment based on faculty/staff and union/nonunion labeling. Coming from the corporate world, this can be very off-putting.
cons:
-Too much bureaucracy and politics in the University as a whole and in the b-school to allow for innovative thinking.  There are a lot of silos and a lot of places and ways for inept people to hide out. It becomes frustrating to see this dynamic after a while.
-Faculty / staff status differences are very dysfunctional. Staff are second-class citizens -- even when they have advanced degrees and/or more real-world experience than faculty. The tenure system is also dysfunctional because faculty can  come and go as they please, telecommute, get the best parking -- while staff are seen as worker bees. There are different performance and retention standards for staff and faculty that reinforce faculty's view of themselves as superior. This is an ugly fact that just gets denied and ignored because the tenure system is so embedded in universities in the US. 
- Professional development is sub-par and not really encouraged, which is ironic for a University. Lack of upward mobility and career paths for staff was one reason I left.
-UW has a number of unions for certain types of jobs. While I know its important to protect employee rights and collectively bargain for wages and wage equity and all that...there is a lot of dysfunction created when you have two classes of staff (union and nonunion) -- and adding in faculty as the "upper class" creates a very tiered status system. I've worked in large corporations with some unionized workers ... academia+unions creates a much worse hierarchy. Again, it's ironic that the unions actually perpetuate a we/they inequity and rank system rather than creating unity.  If you are looking to work anywhere in UW, you will need to be OK with this atmosphere.
-Traffic and parking at UW has gotten significantly worse in recent years. My commute time increased to the point where I was spending about 3 hours a day in transit. That and the inability to telecommute (frowned upon in the b-school and required Dean's approval) was the final deal breaker for me.
-The hiring systems is super slow. When I was trying to hire any new staff, things had to go through central HR before being posted. Often by the time I got the applicant list, the best candidates were no longer available. The b-school HR department was helpful, but at the mercy of central HR in terms of the process,
-The B-school itself should practice more of what it preaches. There are distinct soloing, status and favoritism issues. There is a lot of room for improvement in terms of collaboration, innovation, openness to new ideas and courageous leadership. Rankings went up during my time there, but I saw other strategic goals go by the wayside because so much energy was focused on national rankings. It felt like there was opportunity left on the table because of this tunnel vision.
-Funding for raises, promotions, training & development is a constant issue - particularly for staff. Most people in the b-school complained about being underpaid and overworked.  Even if you love higher ed and academia, that gets old.
-There were a lot of dissatisfied employees who were sticking around because they liked being affiliated with UW and the b-school, liked having a job with good benefits and security, and liked some of their co-workers ... but complained a lot about leadership, the little untouchable empires or fiefdoms inside the school, the politics, etc. It is sad to see people feeling oppressed and stuck and just deciding to live with it because of the cache of working at a well-known b-school and much beloved university. I'll admit that I stayed much longer than was healthy for me and my family because of the cool-factor.

pros:
Work/Life - pretty good. Very seldom that I had to do more than 40 per week.

Work environment - people were generally decent to work with. Equipment and tools were lagging behind the general industry a bit, but were adequate to get the job done.

Retirement plan contribution is decent.
cons:
Pay is mediocre for this area, especially considering that there is little other than salary. No bonus, no stock (obviously), minimal raises (usually less than inflation, often missing completely). 

The commute and parking are an absolute nightmare.

Management is ineffective. There seems to be steadfast dedication to maintaining mediocrity. Middle managers have some responsibility but don't have any authority. In the last layoff I was involved with, there was absolutely no consultation with the personnel managers for their input. The layoff choices that were made were a bit odd - the people who were the most vocal and perceptive about how we could be more efficient were the first to be let go, while others that were actively harming the morale of the team were kept on.

There is a solid resistance to improvement. When valid observations are made about how to improve things, they are discussed, acknowledged, then left to rot while nothing is done about them. It's very confusing, as the management seemed interested and vested in improvement, but all steps taken were more like a retreat into a less effective space.

review_title: Good student job, if you can stand the politics.
pros:
One great thing about working at the UW is that your work is on campus. It makes it really easy to work while going to school: as soon as you get out of class, you walk 5-10 minutes, and you're at work! The hours were also pretty flexible in my experience: people give you leeway because you're a student taking classes.

Another thing I enjoyed was the people. The atmosphere was pretty relaxed: office parties, lots of joking around between coworkers, etc. Go down the hall and hang out with the researchers and their cool research projects. Your mileage may vary, but I had fun.
cons:
There is a lot of office politics. As a student, you will be at the bottom of the hierarchy, and so you will be shielded from a lot of the meetings to which your boss and your boss's boss have to go. However, you will still feel the politics. Every now and then you will have to do something that seems stupid, pointless, or backwards, but someone high up decided that's the way things should be done, and all you can do is take a deep breath and accept it.

Some people will treat you differently for being a student; not all, but some. There will be people that won't trust you to do a good job. You may get menial tasks that no one else wants to do. It's annoying, but there is a silver lining: if there's some incredibly important emergency, you probably won't be asked to work extra hours to fix it!

pros:
Well-run organization, for the most part
Convenient location
The mission is excellent, whether you're in medicine or education
Colleagues are generally very committed and skilled (little dead wood)
Good benefits, although the cost share for medical benefits is creeping up (~$80/mo, for an OK plan)
cons:
Job security is low
Unless you can take a bus there, transportation and parking are difficult and expensive.  Subsidized transit pass helps.
Skills and job training aren't free (your department has to pay)
Pay is competitive with other non-profits; not competitive with the private sector (but that's to be expected)

pros: It is a highly supportive work environment, that really stresses work life balance. Co-workers are supportive and willing to step up and help out when needed.
cons: At times it can be hard to manage the balance of working where you live. Especially in times of high stress, it can feel like there isn't a lot of distance or separation between work and home- since they are the same place.

review_title: UW excellent for graduate school in the sciences
pros: Involved with cutting edge research, lots of shared use facilities available, wonderful benefits, and emphasis on work-life balance not found at some other R1 institutions (however, this can vary across departments)
cons: As with any graduate program, the relationship the student has with the advisor is paramount. While I have not experienced this myself, I have heard complaints about the glacial pace at which higher level administration responds when students must  unfortunately lodge formal complaints against advisors (*very rare, but does happen*). However, I believe this is a sticking point at any large R1 institution.

pros: Big university which is a great place to work since you get the opportunity to find a lot of people with common interest. Further, there are people nearby if you have technical or a management question.
cons: Too big an university, which makes it hard to really know the people well. Further, there are too many bosses for even simple tasks, making it impossible to get things done in a time efficient manner.

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Great to get a look into how a library functions, parties are thrown regularly and I feel appreciated and needed here. Plus you can't dislike that Seattle minimum wage (even though I still cannot pay tuition without loans). Good to note is that the president of the school doesn't manage me, there is a manager in the department I work in who I appreciate and respect.
cons: Lack of relevant experience for the career I want (and for most people, I imagine, unless you want to work in a library or in information sciences), work can be tedious and redudant.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Good health insurance within the UW system, OK dental and vision. Top-notch research setting and resources, although the specifics vary between Colleges and Departments. Work/life balance is what you make of it.
cons: Paid as part-time employees (for being teaching assistants) when most graduate students actually put in 40 hours/week (teaching and research). Have to fight tooth and nail for any kind of raises (i.e. keep up with inflation) or fee reductions. Difficult to afford living in Seattle without loans/fellowship/family support if you have this job. UW administration is out of touch with the needs of its lowest paid employees.

review_title: UW overall has a great work/life balance but unfortunately remains stagnant in keeping up with new technology.
job_title: Senior Computer Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: The UW as whole has a very solid benefits package, the best of which is annual and sick leave, and a free bus pass. You also gain free access to the campus museums/libraries and other resources typically offered to students, and the location can't be beat (plenty of selection for food choices on University Way, and campus is right near the Burke-Gilman trail for bike-commuting or running at lunch). The work environment across the majority of departments (I have worked in multiple departments) tends to be fairly cushy, laid back, and very stable. Typical office jobs (secretarial, programmer, etc) on campus are 8-5pm and do not require high pressure after-hours or overtime work.
cons: If you are looking for a stimulating environment with younger people, UW is not the place. Most employees are older, have been there for years, and are essentially camping until retirement. This goes for most departments within the UW (I have worked in multiple areas). Depending on office location, you may have to walk a ways to eat lunch on University Way, otherwise there are small cafes inside campus that offer minimal selection. Most departments do not allow telecommuting, however the central UW administration has been attempting to encourage this. Most departments also tend to be typically conservative in their software selection, lagging at least a couple of years or more behind current technology, and requiring multiple levels of bureaucratic approval to make changes (and by the time changes are made, another year has gone by).

pros: The opportunity to work at a higher-education institution - if you are committed to the mission of education, you will probably enjoy your job more. Subsidized Metro pass (though that may be going away). Professional development opportunities (though most are not free). Lots of resources on/around campus. Reduced-fee access to Intramural Activities building.
cons: Uncertainty of funding situation. Cost of parking. It's a large institution, so if you don't have the right manager you can feel lost.

review_title: Pretty good place to work -- you're overall experience will depend very much on which lab you work for.
pros:
1) Depending on what project you are working on, the hours are pretty flexible
2) Lots of smart people, great opportunities to learn
3) Really nice campus,
cons:
1) Many of the research facilities are old and dingy
2) A fair number of egos
3) Salaries aren't as good as in private industry

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Freedom to work on projects that are interesting to me, excellent health insurance coverage, chance to travel to interesting locations, good contacts for later career opportunities.
cons: Weather, the State of Washington cutting funding significantly, and the standard complaints of a PhD program (pay level, time to degree, etc.)

review_title: The work is challenging and rewarding but the disorganization can be very frustrating at times.
pros: The compensation is great and the union ensures that graduate research assistants are not taken advantage of. I found the work challenging and learned a great deal from my work.
cons: At times it can be difficult to balance deadline driven research with graduate studies. Also most academics have a lot of projects going on so the project management can be very disorganized at times.

review_title: The University of Washington is an excellent place to work.
pros: Being in a higher-ed environment is more pleasurable for some personalities than working in a corporation. Projects are built around a set of compelling questions or investigations and not around products, necessarily.
cons: The University of Washington is a major public university, and so very large. There is the danger of becoming isolated or stuck in a "silo" with no chance of advancement or lateral moves.

review_title: Absolutely love working for UW CSE
pros:
Great team working with me as a 14x TA. Get to teach students about a topic I love. The community meetings involve free food with a goegeous Vista in the B+M Gates commons at the top of CSE building.
You also get to meet with a lot of fantastic, smart people who are all going to go off to do great things, so you build good connections.
cons: I honestly don't have any cons. I guess it could pay better, but being a 14x TA is so much fun it doesn't matter.

review_title: Great Opportunities, Not the Best Compensation
pros:
- Tuition Exemption Program
In the Medical School specifically:
- Professional Development opportunities
- Flexible schedule (in certain departments)
- Multiple options for healthcare/dental insurance
- Holidays, sick days, annual leave are better than most
cons:
- Pay scale is set for classified staff and low
- Maxed out in pay early in position
- Climate can be frustrating, hostile, with little resolution from management
- Upper management (aka Deans) do not understand what is happening on the ground

review_title: Great place to be a student, probably great place to be faculty, miserable place to be staff
pros:
+ 40 hour work week, tops.  Many people were rarely in the office for more than 30, and a few in my group had trouble managing more than a handful of actual work hours each week.
