+ Lots of holidays and sick days, decent vacation time accrual.
+ Occasionally interesting work.
+ Beautiful campus.
+ Cheap food and reasonably priced gym nearby.
+ Decent benefits on paper.
cons:
- You can be the most senior staff employee in your entire department, and you're still lower on the totem pole than a first-year grad student.
- Base salary is maybe half of industry average.  Factoring in total compensation, you're lucky to make 1/3 of what you could in the outside world.
- Advancement opportunities are nonexistent.
- Work depends on the whims of the faculty and their students.
- Your position could vanish any time a grant renewal doesn't go through, completely irrespective of the work you're doing.
- Many people take technical staff jobs there as a kind of semi-retirement.  Expectations are shockingly low and you have to be aggressively incompetent or unproductive to get fired, so you either have to be okay with being party to terrible work or pick up a huge amount of slack from your uncaring coworkers.
- In practice the benefits are pretty bad.  Matching 403b is less great given how low salaries are.  The PPO medical plans aren't free and have poor coverage.  The pharmacy plan I had was the worst I've ever experienced.  Vacation time accrual starts very low and is non-negotiable.
- Workspaces tend to be either old, spacious, and worryingly run-down, or new, well-kept, and packed like sardines.
- Have to deal with obnoxious and oblivious undergrads regularly.

pros: Pay, benefits and tuition reimbursement are the best thing about this job.  Also, the opportunity to work in a challenging, ever-evolving research environment is a benefit of working at UWMC.
cons: Managers are often too busy to provide instruction and guidance to research assistants.  This creates an environment where I often felt as if I was being blindly thrown into tasks I knew little about.

review_title: UW Libraries is a good part-time job for undergrads
job_title: UW Libraries Student Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros:
I worked at the UW Libraries in a non-circulation department. These are the pros:
- Flexible work schedule - Got to make my schedule each quarter around my class schedule and had some control over how many hours per week (within the range of 10-19.5). Also had no problem asking for time off for exams, summer vacation, etc.
- Great co-workers - I made a lot of friends at the Libraries and also had very good relations with my managers
- Nice break room - Suzzallo break room is very comfortable for employees!
- Good amount of employee appreciation - There are scholarships for library employees (I received one!), holiday party, student employee appreciation week, birthdays, getting together after work, etc.
- Relevant work - It depends on what you are looking to do after college, but at least for me, I felt I gained relevant skills that helped me be more competitive in the job market

Ultimately the best part of the job was having the support of the people I worked with. I felt like my managers were generally interested in my happiness, my school success, etc. Although the job was not glamorous and pay was not high, the people I worked with and the support I received as a student employee made it all worth it for me!
cons:
- Pay was not high - I left about 6 months ago, but at least up until I left there was a pay freeze (passed by the Washington State Legislature, NOT UW) that made it impossible to get raises, so despite working at the libraries for 3+ years and having A LOT of knowledge/skills gained, I did not make very much more than minimum wage
- Repetitive work - I could have easily taken on more responsibility or new tasks, but there just was not a lot of room for this kind of growth for employees. I stayed at the libraries longer than most student employees do, however
- Sometimes had angry patrons who were mad about library policies, but I learned how to provide better customer service through this experience, and managers always helped when it got out of hand
- A lot to remember - It took me a while to remember all of the policies/procedures I needed to know, and although management is there to help when you have questions, it was important to remember all of the details so you provided patrons with the correct information

pros:
Fair compensation, good insurance benefits, 403(b) investment options & match are nice (though match varies based on age, contributions are also mandatory after 1 year; I've never seen this before), access to WA State 457(b), flexible work environment, great work life balance, good professional development opportunities (conferences, workshops, learning materials, "POD" classes, some tuition reimbursement but it's tough to use), plenty of smart motivated people all around the University, pay increases are merit based and beat inflation, low cost unlimited use transit pass (or free with paid parking on campus), good bike accessibility but could embrace bike-commute culture more (showers in buildings and more indoor bike storage, please?).

Beautiful campus with a thriving academic culture and serious student involvement. You really get out of this place what you put in to it. If you embrace the culture, and embrace "the U", you can have an amazing work experience here.
cons:
The commute can be hard (time consuming) if you live more than a few miles away from campus. Parking on campus is expensive. Housing & rent prices are expensive near campus. Vacation time is so-so, only 3 weeks to start and you don't reach 4 until your 6th year, this maxes out just shy of 5 weeks in your 9th year. Most graduate programs do not participate in tuition reimbursement (don't plan on getting a free graduate degree by working here).

Departments on campus are very isolated and "do their own thing". Working for central IT would be a very different experience from working in a different unit or for one of the schools/colleges. This is both good and bad. On the good side, schools and colleges can develop their own culture, be extremely focused on their students, faculty, and researchers, meeting needs central IT never could. But on the downside, this leaves little room for advancement, many smaller IT units function more like a start up than a well oiled corporation (maybe this isn't bad?), and teams can be small, short staffed, and you might not have someone with advanced experience to learn from. This does afford a lot of freedom, and grant a lot of responsibility though.

review_title: Great Research University in the Pacific NW
job_title: Counseling Services Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: The University of Washington is primarily a Research I institution. It all depends on what office / division you are in, but there is ample room and support for professional development and upward mobility within the institution.
cons: Again, it depends on which office / department you are in and what your role is within the university, but it isn't too hard to find people who are rather complacent and uninspired. It is just their job and nothing more. I don't like to spend my time around those people. Life is too short for that.

review_title: Good place to be an instructor
pros: Freedom to design your own syllabus, hard working students,beautiful campus. Good benefit, health insurance, good work-life balance. The quad with cherry trees in the spring is the most beautiful place. Love it.
cons: My only complaint is the atmosphere in the Economics department. The academic environment is not that engaging somehow. I felt detached to the department, completely on my own.

pros: Continuing professional development funding and education, relaxed atmosphere, amazing students, and campus that is always moving forward, growing and changing to provide access points at an affordable tuition.  three campus system so lots of room for mobility.
cons: Lots of meetings, slow to make decisions, facing some major budget issues this year (as a UW system), pace of work can be slow depending on the time of the year and department you serve.  Compensation is not competitive with private industry or the community colleges but better than some of the private colleges in the area.

review_title: Swimming Upstream; Doing ALOT more with ALOT Less All The Time!
pros: If you believe in the mission of the department you are working for, the UW is a very committed organization.  It's "Purple & Gold" spirit is unmistakable, even if you didn't graduate from the "U", you can't help but get caught up in it.  The benefits are very nice if you can hang in there for more than 5 years.
cons:
It is a network that recognizes that you got the objective completed, not how you got there.  "Scorched Earth" management style is rewarded in "employee of the year" bonuses.  Performance reviews aren't based on any concrete measurables/deliverables, ie, 25% of job is management of programs, 75% is supervising staff, etc.  
Employee turnover is high - 25% in 1 year in my dept.  Rather than contracting out the work while a search is being conducted, the work is split up among program managers and filling the spot has taken 18 months on average.  That's alot of time carrying additional portfolio work, and being measured on how "successful" you are at it, while receiving little or no training on it.
There is no formal training on dept processes/procedures - more like "plug and play", or an hour "training" by a Director who has maybe a 25% knowledge base on the process, doesn't do the work themselves, but is doing the training on it.  Given that there is no real training, it is surprising that Trail and Error is not accepted as a learning tool.  The culture of don't-take-responsibility-for-your-errors/actions and CYA is reinforced almost on a daily basis, starting with HR.

pros: Flexible, standard benefits and perks of academia. Large amounts of opportunity in terms of successful faculty members to work with and collaborations you can make career wise. Great research university, experience will depend on individual situation (lab) you are in, but university as a whole is great. Supportive graduate programs and university resources for graduate students
cons: Also comes with standard lower pay of academia and possibility of being overworked depending on the lab you end up in. For me this was not the case as my PI is great but something to be aware of.

pros: Benefits are great. The location is beautiful and close to food and shopping. If you can get in to a niche with a great boss, you'll enjoy working here.
cons: There's a general lack of work-life balance. Due to the size of the organization and the tendency to hire from within the UW community, change is slow. Everyone is used to the way they've always done it, so that's how things continue to be done, resulting in a lot of inefficiency and workarounds.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
Work Stability: 

The work is relatively stable, due to high amount of federal and private funding UW receives. UW is a funding behemoth, the upside of which is relatively large number of RA opportunities (PIs need cheap labor, i.e. you, if you are a graduate student). If one project ends and you need to move, finding another opportunity should not be too difficult. There are employment opportunities year-round, with mid-to-late summer a relatively hot hiring season. 

Personal Growth:

Because there is no lack of funding, it becomes all about productivity, since large grants require justification (i.e. articles and conference papers). PIs are typically relatively seasoned faculty with a solid publishing record, so they have the capacity to forefront a graduate student on a paper, and pay their way to some conferences -- as long as you do the analysis and contribute to the writing. In my experience, grad RAs often seem encouraged to take lead on papers - as long as something gets written and accepted and presented eventually. 

Time off: If you recommend yourself as a productive, reliable RA and develop a positive relationship with your PI, there is good chance s/he will have no problem letting you take a week or two off during the winter/spring breaks, and additional time off (perhaps a month) during the summer (especially if you are an international student needing to travel home to visit your family). 


Other pros:
- You get to work with experienced, smart individuals with well-rounded life and work experiences. 
- You can find faculty who are naturally good mentors. It may take some looking, but they exist. Find one who is not an overachieving robot (good luck). 
- Beautiful campus setting, LOTS to do both on and off campus, lots of healthy options for taking the edge off.
cons:
For a Graduate Research Assistant, you are on a half-time (50%) appointment. Pay varies by college, engineering, medicine an business pay more, which can make a difference between not making ends meet and barely making it.

Compensation: $1600/month. Seattle is among top 10 cities in the US with the highest cost of living. Rent for a most basic, older, 600sqft 1 bedroom apt (no roommate) that doesn't require an hour-long commute is about $1000/mo, and that's a good deal. So you need to make it on $600/mo for everything else (food, utilities, clothes, supplies). 

Work-life balance: it is what you make of it. Quality papers require quality analysis and writing, which takes time. RA appointments tend to evolve from half-time into full-time, unofficially. If you plan to do quality work, you can forget about 8-5 workdays and free evenings. Welcome to the Midnight Oil Burning Club. 

Advising: It works like this. UW is a research-intensive institution. This means that faculty are primarily evaluated based on ability to secure funding and ability to produce research output. Everything else is a distant non-priority when it comes to what really plays into their career growth. However, what plays into *your* career growth - what helps you make good decisions, get timely advice, and benefit from the wisdom of the more experienced senior researchers - is personal attention and basic human consideration. When you come to UW, you first and foremost subscribe to the culture of the place; the culture does not bend itself to cater to your needs for quality advising time and attention. 

So you need to adjust expectations in this regard and either accept this limitation and forge ahead, or consider other schools where faculty care more about the welfare of their students -- not just hire them.

review_title: Good and bad at the U--staff review (not faculty)
pros: Really depends on your department. Overall it is challenging to overcome the bureaucracy and feel like you can really get things done. Quality of life is great. Out the door at 5 on the dot. Great benefits=golden handcuffs.
cons: Very siloed environment. Initiative is not encouraged or rewarded. Many people have stayed too long, don't want to lose their benefits and don't have much drive.

review_title: Overall, a good employer to work for. Modest salaries are balanced by benefits and relative job security.
pros:
If you enjoy academic life, working at a major university might be for you. There are always opportunities to attend lectures, conferences, and employees can take up to six credit hours for free every quarter (working the class into your schedule may be difficult). Time off is fairly generous (ten named holidays, and classified staff accrue 8+ hours of vacation time monthly). Working overtime is usually not necessary, excepting major conferences or the beginning of the academic year. 

UW (at least at my department) places a high value on student satisfaction and supporting the students is taken very seriously. Also, UW is very progressive (and its policies reflect that), so if you lean conservative, you need to be aware that you will be in the minority here (it's Seattle, don't act surprised).
cons:
Navigating UW policy can be akin to navigating a labyrinth. Your department will have its own policy, centers within your department have their own policies, and other departments you may work with have their own policies. Have fun trying to interpret policy and apply it properly. 

Also, you might be surprised at the amount of politicking (jockeying) that goes on in an academic community; don't assume that non-profits are immune, or that simply doing your job well and keeping your head down means you can escape office politics. 

Finally, achieving promotions can be difficult and extremely slow, especially if you are classified staff. Do not expect the sort of salary increases that the private sector offers. If you're in with somebody high-ranked, though, you'll probably have corners cut for you.

pros: Great community and resources within the university. Everyone is doing some great and being a part of the bigger picture. I really enjoy working here. The work/life balance has always been a selling factor.
cons: It is unfortunate that the university has very low wages for people in much lower positions. Not a lot of room to move up. It is somewhat bureaucratic but that comes with working in higher education.

pros:
You should enroll in workstudy if:
-You don't necessarily need to make more money
-Your schedule is not normal for a different off-campus part-time job
-You would really prefer some experience working on-campus
-You can see yourself working on-campus for most academic years
-You are involved, and want to stay involved more
-Work on your homework or other projects and it would be OK
cons:
-You can only have less than 19 hours per 2 weeks
-Hours may vary, I've had 3 hours some paychecks; hours not guaranteed
-Not much to do on the job; can get boring
-Student training is mandatory, and can be inconvenient times

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: As an undergraduate researcher, I had the opportunity of working with some of the most brilliant scientists in the world. It sets your academic standard ahead of many others.
cons: Pay is not the best. In seattle i was getting paid below minimum wage for the city. Working with the PI can make or break your experience. If the professor is hard to get in contact with, you can be left without a paddle

pros: The mission is inspiring. The workplace is humane. The office I am a part of is very high-functioning, works well together, and enjoys one another's company.
cons: Being a public-sector institution, you will hit many, many roadblocks and bottlenecks on the way to achieving any goal. If you are a lifelong public sector employee, that will just be "the process." If you are switching from the private sector, you'll experience pretty frequent frustration.

review_title: Great benefits, but must be comfortable navigating bureaucracy and a lot of office politics to thrive there.
job_title: Digital Press Operator in Seattle, WA
pros: Some the best insurance and retirement plans in WA state.  Once you are a UW employee you can apply to any department and get priority consideration (if you are qualified for the position).
cons: Budget cuts result can result in lay offs or positions not being filled when people leave. Unfilled positions do not go away, the responsibilities just get delegated to other people in the group. Moral can be an issue, depending on your work group and managers.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: UW is an institution that is very big, but the support and management are very well organized and dedicated to making sure employees receive the attention that they need. Being a Teaching Assistant comes with lots of perks, like being more connected to faculty members, staffs, and students. Get a good professor who cares about students and the TAs, and it'll be one of the best jobs you can get as an undergraduate.
cons: Depending on your level of experience in the subject you're teaching or TA-ing for, the pay might varies but never below minimum wage.

review_title: Exciting place to work, access to benefits could use improvement
pros: Although much depends on the department you work in, overall, there is a positive and collegial working environment,  with friendly students and staff. The UW is a world-class research institution with amazing research and continuing education opportunities, state of the art equipment and access to some of the top minds in many disciplines via department lectures, conferences and other events. It is a breath of fresh air working with students and helping to train the next generation for the world's future challenges. The health, pension benefits and other fringe benefits are very good. Work life balance is generally good, but it depends on your immediate boss and group/depeartment.
cons: The salary is lower than a comparable salary in industry regardless of your experience. There is also some politics with access to certain benefits. For instance, staff that belong to a union receive free bus passes, while those that are not part of a union (you have no control over whether you join a union or not, it depends on how your job is classified and no one asks you if you agree when you accept a job offer) do not. The best parking spots are reserved for faculty, staff are generally required to park at least a 10-15 minute walk from the garage nearest to their office because there are not enough spaces. Office space is also often at a premium although this depends on your department/unit. Some staff members work all day in spaces with no windows and barely a desk of their own while entire offices and lab spaces sit totally empty for months (or even years!), reserved for the next all-important hotshot hire.

review_title: Flexible, hard to translate to a "real" job if you don't work a specific job title
pros: As a student, they take your classes into consideration when scheduling your shifts which is nice. Management is very chill and approachable.
cons: Unless you're working a desk job for a department or leadership/mentoring role, your work is hard to translate into a career.

pros: Reasonable pay, good medical, dental, 401k.  Great for building career options down the road.  As a research engineer/assistant you are actively involved in cutting edge research.  If you are working in your desired field this can give you greater opportunities in the job market or for graduate programs.
cons: Less pay than market price in industry.  Lab environment can be more isolated than an industry environment.  Working in a smaller lab could potentially be claustrophobic.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: I am very satisfied with the healthcare and gym. The campus is also very nice, well kept with lots of greenery. The libraries are also great.
cons: The building I work in is older and has no A/C so turns into an oven over the summer. Graduate students are not well paid, but the teaching workload was reasonable.

pros: Generous with vacation/sick leave. An emphasis on work/life balance. Tuition reimbursement.  Great location and a big organization to move around in.
cons: Benefit package is great but very expensive. It is deducted from your paycheck. You lose about 35% of your listed salary in "benefits". Raises are small or frozen due to the state budget. There is a lack of motivation among employees to succeed.

review_title: Glad for the experience and ability to make a contribution
pros: Benefits at professional level;  slower work pace vs. working with companies
cons: Steep hierarchy for decision making

review_title: Can be great but highly dependent on who you work for. My rating is 3.5
pros: good benefits, innovative research, flexible schedule, excellent reputation
cons: a tendency for management to protect research faculty over middle-management staff regardless of how inept some faculty are in the management of their staff.  To be fair, a tendency to protect "more valuable staff" is not unusual-UW is simply doing what you would expect.  In my particular group, complacency and loyalty were valued assets more so than others.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: GAIP provides good benefits for graduate students and their dependents. It's difficult to give a review because experience working here highly variable depending on program, advisor, etc.
cons: Stipend is low compared to what is offered by other universities in expensive cities and has not been adequately adjusted for rising housing costs. Additionally, grad students that are fully supported still have to pay quarterly fees. This reduces annual earnings by about 1500 dollars.

review_title: Valued work experience but management practices are still below par
pros: Benefits. Most departments strive to be flexible with employee schedules.
cons: Preference given to staff employees who have a Master's degree. Several years of budget cuts and anticipated cuts are taking their toll on employee morale. Very hard to advance within a department.

pros:
-Cutting-edge research
-Good benefits (4 health care choices, paid dental, FSA, matching retirement contributions, discounted public transportation)
-Good academic reputation
-Generous vacation and sick leave
cons:
-In your local department you will be at the whim of vicious, bitter, unprofessional, unmotivated mid-level bureaucrats
-Very difficult to get a promotion or raise due to institutional policies
-Culture of covering up illegal or unprofessional behavior/actions for the sake of the university's reputaton

review_title: You will feel overworked and underpaid but everything you do is ultimately for your benefit
job_title: Predoctoral Research Associate II in Seattle, WA
pros:
- Fund your PhD without accruing more student debt.
- High-expectations encourage you to do good work.
- Supportive environment.
- Good work leads to publications, which boost your CV.
cons:
- You're expected to work considerably more than the 20 hours you're paid for.
- Work can be very isolated unless you're part of a collaborative research group.
- It's easy to get lost in the crowd.

pros: Overall, the benefits are pretty good. Full time staff members accrue 8 hours of paid time off and sick leave each month.
cons: Since the University is so large it often takes a long time for changes to be made. Also, the lack of funding for certain departments/areas can slow the progression of change.

pros: I worked in acquisitions at the UW Libraries. They always treated me very well and had a clean, relaxed environment. Hours were pretty flexible, and overall I felt respected.
cons: At times they felt so set in their ways that if they were to do something wrong, they would never have noticed. Overall this wasn't really a problem, though.

job_title: IT Help Desk Lead in Seattle, WA
pros: Great team to work with, a lot of helpful people. Job is as rewarding as you make it. There are a lot of knowledgeable people, and you can get a wide range of experiences. Great for students, since they work around your class schedules. High compensation
cons: Only 20hrs per week by UW law. A bit repetitive, but plenty of side projects and promotions to pursue.

job_title: Contact Center Representative in Seattle, WA
pros: There wasn't one thing that was good about my job. They micro manage you- if you are 1-2 minutes past your break time, management sends a letter and docks you points. If you do a good job, management makes a big deal that you can wear jeans. How about some food or bonus? Very demeaning atmosphere- my only regret is I didn't quit sooner !! Don't apply here unless you want to feel insignificant and unappreciated!
cons: Management doesn't care about you. They make you take time out of your break time to talk to management about work related issues. They slave drive you and absolutely don't care what is going on in your personal life.

pros: A great school that is conducive to learning, personal, and professional growth. Very inclusive to diversity in a professional setting and emphasize different gender, race, and liberal views
cons: I can't think of anything in specific, but the Seattle Freeze seems to hit the school culture. The number of international students, especially from China, makes the school look predominantly Asians and there is hardly any interactions between international Chinese students and locals, which can make other groups feel left out.

review_title: Lack of growth and learning opportunities for skill seekers.
pros: Raises to be given quarterly. It's on campus and easy to schedule around classes.
cons: Different offices have different policies for time off. The offices tend to prefer a twenty hour work week and work study students. The budget has frozen all pay increases. Learning new skills is difficult. Deadlines are frequently changed and some projects are time sensitive, but you won't know until it's already due.

job_title: Human Resources Manager in Seattle, WA
pros:
Contribution to society at Macro level
Managers who support work life balance
cons:
Slow changes
Academic bias in unrelated field... if a drain has to be dug, Professor's opinion will trump that of plumber...

pros: UW-IT is very well-managed and they promote a positive culture.  The department encourages employee development and when graduation is near, they help make the way out easier.  It was a joy to work with the department.  There are several perks for students looking to work part-time, such as flexible schedules, easy commute from classes, and co-workers who are also students.
cons: To get the most out of the available positions, you need to be a Freshman or Sophomore at the university when starting.

pros: Work at your own pace. Sometimes if your grading assignment has flexible professor, then you will be fine - able to push back graded homework back a week or so.Take home job
cons: Compensation is almost basic wage. Each grading homework is assigned 4 hours regardless of the amount of extra time put to have the homework completely graded. If you don't like reading someone's unreadable handwritting, then this job isn't for you. Also depends on professor for each assigned class for homework to be graded. If professor is very demanding, then it might affect your quarter.

pros: The University of Washington is a prestigious research institution with plenty of resources. All peers, mentors, and PI's were hardworking and intelligent. Great opportunities!
cons: The campus is very large. Therefore, there is a lot of walking. The extra exercise, however, really wasn't that much of a con. Also, red square is very slippery in the winter months.

review_title: Foster School is a great place to work
pros:
The UW benefits are top notch.
The Foster School is growing and changing.  2010 forward will be exciting times.
Teamwork is highly valued
cons: When you work for a non-profit, you ARE non-profit.  The pay as a staff member is fairly low, considering the hours and education required.

review_title: Nearly all positive, expect for senior administration.
pros: My department is a great place to work.  Our students are excellent, our staff top notch, and these attributes enable faculty to focus on their teaching and research.  Salaries could be better, but offers elsewhere were never very enticing.
cons: The senior administration under Mark Emmert and Mike Young has lacked transparency, effectiveness and honesty.  They have been extraordinarily inept at maintaining support of the state legislature.

pros: Good support system and a very open, friendly work culture. There are many avenues and opportunities to grow skills and become involved with various work that supports operations.
cons: Slow to implement changes suggested about improving systems and processes. There seems to be an organizational lack of motivation towards high performance as compared to private sector organizations

review_title: OK but not great support for graduate econ students
pros: Being a graduate student is pretty nice - flexible work hours, smart people around you, great health insurance.  For those who want to keep living the student dream, but with a little more cash.
cons: The economics department faculty treat your every question like a tremendous burden on their time.  A lot of ego and politics - professors within the international economics field weren't able to agree on a new hire after a year of searching, interviewing, and fly-outs.

review_title: Great place to work, fantastic mission
job_title: Director of IT in Seattle, WA
pros: The people and atmosphere here are fantastic.  It is wonderful to be around so much research, energy, and desire to make the world a better place.
cons: Nothing major of note.  There can be some of the usual office politics, but if you keep your distance, there's nothing to be concerned about.

review_title: A community of people passionate about teaching
pros:
- Numerous resources to help staff with teaching/grading
- Weekly community meetings and quarterly events to build strong bond within community
- Experience with hands on teaching. Responsible for teaching 1-2 sections per week. 
- Strong cause: "help students succeed"
cons:
- Grading can take a significant amount of time 
- As a full time student, juggling course work and this job can be taxing

pros: The best reasons to work at University of Washington are the people. They provide a professional yet friendly environment that allows you to love where you work
cons: The downside of University of Washington is competitive salary. Although they treat their employees very well, I think they are less compensated when it comes to how much their employees are paid.

pros:
Great management team, opportunities for learning and great employment benefits. People are really working because they want to make a difference in someone's life. Most managers are seniors working there for more than 8 to 10 years. 
Managers constantly giving positive feedback and teaching peers to improve performance.
cons: Few opportunities for advancement at the current position. Heavy workload due to shortage of employees and tied budget due to State cuts.

review_title: It was a good expierience for me working in an unknown environment.
pros: There was a great energy when coming into work. All my coworkers semed to get alone and everyone worked hard to make things run smoothly.I really enjoyed my expierience.
cons: There really were not any negatives about working in this job. It would be really hard for me to complain about this job.

review_title: Executive Assistant - Great Place to Work!
pros:
Committed staff who thrive on working with students and the mission of the University.
Benefits are unbelievable - 100% match on your 403B on up to 10% of your salary, depending on your age. 
Affordable health care.
Beautiful campus environment.
cons: Academic units can be silos. Classified staff very constrained by union rules regarding jobs.

pros: The UW has great benefits and access to resources. The people are great and it's nice to be in the high ed environment with innovative and life changing research.
cons: Since it's a public institution, there is a culture different than private industry, and you need to be prepared to adjust the way you plan and execute. Success often depends on partnership and collaboration.

review_title: Siloed, poor communication, unclear and moving expectations
pros: Benefits are decent, gorgeous work place, discounted orca card, access to the library
cons: My management team never set clear expectations, and consistently moved those expectations at the last minute. The UW doesn’t award longevity or experience. The UW is more concerned with accolades and staff are concerned with personal growth over well being and growth of students or their work teams

pros:
The job security is the most important at the current economic situation. 
The health insurance is relatively good. 
The U matches 100% of the 403b contribution. 
Working schedule is flexible.
cons:
The pace is slow. No much room for career advancement within the U. 
The salary is OK but much lower than that at other academia institutions in Seattle.
On campus parking is expensive.

review_title: Lab Manager for a Large University Lab
job_title: Research Scientist III in Seattle, WA
pros: This is a very satisfying occupation.  I work with outstanding individuals and my work makes a difference.  University benefits are outstanding.  Though this occupation I have grown and become very qualified in a variety of skills.
cons:
I work on soft money so there is little job insurance and my job will be ending soon.
Little room for advancement.
Relatively low pay.
This occupation is consuming.  
I work 7 days a week and am on call 24 hours a day.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: It's the best place that I have ever worked. There is truly a team effort that each of us know we can depend on. Excellent communication skills. It's a place where patients really do come first and are what is most important. I'm very proud to be a part of what they stand for!
cons: I really haven't had any bad experiences. I wish that my position wasn't temporary due to funding.

pros: I had a lot of fun honing my skills in the fundamentals  of physics while also getting pain for it! The Physics department was more than willing to work with my schedule and I was very grateful for their flexibility.
cons: It would have been nice to get more opportunities to grade exams or pick up hours in some other way, but all in all, it was a great experience.

pros: The University of Washington (UW) is proud to be one of the nation's premier educational and research institutions. Our people are the most important asset in our pursuit of achieving excellence in education, research, and community service. Our staff not only enjoys outstanding benefits and professional growth opportunities, but also an environment noted for diversity, community involvement, intellectual excitement, artistic pursuits, and natural beauty.
cons: Research assistants need to be committed to the research, so it is best to manage your time properly and love what you choose.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: The department was very supportive, good training provided. I did a lot of grading. The flexibility was great to have, since I lived in Redmond.
cons: At one point, I was assigned an unreasonable amount of work. However, a conversation with the professor took care of the issue.

pros: Great opportunities for collaboration. Phenomenal research initiatives and one of the largest grant budgets of any public university. Truly a public ivy school.
cons: The ivory tower is real. If you stay on the prescribed course there is no friction, but be prepared to drown in a sea of bureaucracy if you need to do something special.

job_title: Manager of Program Operations in Seattle, WA
pros: The Benefits are good.  Many opportunities for training and to further your education with HR & management supportive time off.
cons: I don't feel that management and the executive staff is as supportive as they could be nor are they very transparent with information.  There have been multiple occasions that executive staff have placed blame on staff only to later find out they had previously signed off on that very thing.

pros: The store is on-campus, so it's convenient for students. They have a regular influx of new employees, so you'll meet a lot of people, some of whom are very cool. If you work in textbooks, you'll know when the best time to get a book at the lowest price will be.
cons:
Poor store and department management
Pathetic wages
Raises difficult to get
Anti-union
Inconsistent hours throughout the year
Influx of poorly-screened new employees every semester
Discount not competitive against online textbook prices
Lazy, incompetent employees treated much the same as the best

review_title: The University of Washington is filled with brilliant people that want to share their knowledge with you.
pros: The University of Washington has an atmosphere like no where else. You feel a sense of community and creativity there.
cons: Many of the teachers and students are from other non English speaking countries which makes it hard to understand and work with those people.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: The campus is beautiful and there are great public transportation options to get to work.  People were friendly and accommodating with work/life balance.
cons: With state budget cuts affecting resources and salaries, the atmosphere was at many times tense and stressful as we all worried about our jobs.

pros: Most laboratory in the University allow flexible schedule for the employee.  That allows for good balancing between work and family life.  The benefits and time off are pretty good.  We get every single state public holidays off.  UW also matches 5%-7% retirement contribution for professional staffs.
cons: There's not a lot of career advancement available within the organization.  That means the salary raise is pretty stagnant after reaching certain salary ceilings.

review_title: it has great benefits but it is not helpful to facilitate employee promotions, salary raises, visas
job_title: Research Scientist IV in Seattle, WA
pros:
you can have access to state-of-the-art classes and libraries and seminars and courses
the health and dental benefits are great
the vacation leave and sick leave are reasonable
cons:
it is very hard to obtain promotions
it is impossible to obtain salary raises
it is hard to access knowlegeable HR people

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: UW is very family friendly and has great benefits. My work schedule is flexible, though it would depend on your PI for specifics.
cons: My biggest con is that my salary is so low for the area.  Seattle is super expensive to live and my salary doesn't even cover my two kids to be in daycare full time.  Also, postdocs are somewhat invisible in my department.  After being here for 9 months, I am still not on the department listserv or the website.

review_title: Great place to work as a student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: As a engineering research assistant (with funding), tuition, insurance, and living stipend were covered. Research also counted to degree credits. Great opportunity to get into leading-edge technology, and R&D. Good networking when attending conferences. Especially good experience when looking to make a career in R&D and Academia.
cons: Working and full-time graduate school leaves little personal time, but that is expected. If you're looking to make a career in industry, two-years of work experience may be better than Master's/Research.

pros: Lots of resources available.  Library system in particular is excellent. Good place to study if you know in advance who you will work for and that you can work together.
cons: Lots of programs, initiatives, administrative departments, etc, and none of them can work together.  The entire organization has an awkward feeling of having tried to unify/streamline their way of doing things and then stopping after crippling the ad hoc systems that existed in each little department, without having anything capable of replacing them.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: A good place. Students and Professors are nice. A good chance to improve you ability on teaching if you aim at being a professor or instructor in an academic institution.
cons: The workload sometimes might be heavy. But it depends. You can select what you want to do and what class you do not want to do. In all I like the teaching atmosphere here.

job_title: Strategic Manager of Technologies in Seattle, WA
pros: At the University of Washington I developed, managed and implemented new programs within the College using the latest technology available. I enjoyed the "wide-open" environment that allowed me to explore, create and use new technology along with the application of older technology in new forums.
cons: Working for an organization such as the University of Washington often entails the navigation of a large amount of bureaucratic red tape.

review_title: Tutoring at the TLC is Great!
pros: It is great review for the tutors and a rewarding experience to pass on some of that hard earned knowledge.
cons: No big cons here to my mind. I could maybe complain that some students just want you to do their homework for them. But that should be something you as a tutor can handle if you are comfortable setting boundaries.

pros: When you are a student, working for the university can be your biggest asset.  If you can land a full-time position you can get many of your classes paid for.  Most management that I came in contact was very lenient in keeping academics first.
cons: Many student positions are overstaffed allowing employees to be paid to surf the internet.

review_title: The cultuare of arrogance is unfortunate in that it affects students and the strong management of good programs.
pros: Potentially stimulating environment.  Pretty campus.  Access to libraries, art galleries, athletic center.  Some work can be considered valuable to the common good.
cons: UW is an elitist organization where faculty rank students even lower than staff.  The academic rigor is lacking.  There is an art and science to the business of running a School within the UW system.  Unfortunately, most Deans don't understand that art or science.

review_title: Good benefits, good location but need to lift the salary freeze.
pros: The University of Washington provides good benefits and is in a location with a wide variety of affordable restaurants within a short walk. I find it a low stress work environment.
cons: Being a State University, UW has had a salary freeze for the last few years. Even us lowly postdocs can't get salary increases.

job_title: Continuing Education Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: One of the best parts of working for a university is the dedication and commitment to personal professional development.  The University has ample opportunity to explore learning opportunities.  There are many opportunities to advance in your selected career within the university.  There is a great deal of diversity and a commitment to growing the diversity of the faculty, staff and student body.
cons: One challenge at the university is working through all the bureaucratic red tape.  It can be difficult to change processes.

pros: UW is a state entity and you're given all of the perks of working for the government while working in an environment that focuses on higher learning.
cons: Working in higher ed does result in specifically stressful times of the year revolving, primarily, around specific important dates. For example, admissions deadlines and the end of term.

pros: I worked for HFS as a student server, then student coordinator, for a total of 1.5 years. HFS is pretty understanding of student's schedules. You have some control over which shifts you are given based on your class schedule, and there's usually someone available to cover for you if you need to switch shifts. This is also a great way to meet fellow students.
cons: At the time, student coordinators barely made more per hour than student servers, but were given much more responsibility and oversight during shifts.

review_title: Excellent Employer - I've been here 17 years and I'm lovin' it !
pros: Superb health benefits, beautiful campus, good managers, reasonable workload, good pay level, excellent (private) office space, quick and easy commute by bus, free classes for employees, sweet retirement bennies, free on-site retirement planning.  Oh, and I also love the libraries.  We pursue knowledge, research, and the public good every day, and no O/T is required.
cons: some mainframe (legacy) software needs updating.

pros: Overall, the University of Washington is a wonderful place to work.  One of the best things about working for UW is the benefits, including tuition, medical/dental, and retirement (403b). Also, the UW is environmentally and socially conscious which are huge 'Pros".
cons: Overall, it was a good place to work. It's hard to come up with something to list as a "Con" for the University of Washington.   If pressed, I'd say my least favorite aspect of working at the UW was the lack of employee parking.

pros: Being a graduate student at UW is great, presentation skills and teaching skills are valued.  The pay and benefits relative to other programs is good, and at least in the Engineering school the education is top notch.
cons: You are underpaid for what you do as most graduate students are, but relative to other programs the pay and benefits here are excellent.

job_title: Web and Computing Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Good benefits and great resources if you need help.  The UW in general has a good work life balance.  People expect you to go home when the day is over.
cons: Sometimes too much bureaucracy.  It can be hard to figure out who the right person to talk to is.  Some departments are better than others with this.  The parking on or near campus is also ver limited and expensive.

review_title: I like working for the UW. Only if UW sponsors H1B for staffs, I would like it even more.
job_title: Lab Technician II in Seattle, WA
pros: Nice environment, people there is really friendly. Great life insurance, medical, eye and dental. I had great experience with my previous lab jobs.
cons: Doesn't sponsor H1B visa unless you're a faculty or fellow. Also, there is a lab that is heavily dominated by a certain race.

pros:
Seems like a great environment to be in at middle-age and beyond.  The hours are flexible and
the work is occasionally interesting (science!)
cons: For a developer, the pay is far below market.  It seems like a nice place to start your career or to settle into, but the promotion ladder seems reserved for managers and M.D./Ph.D.'s

review_title: Great place to work, salary sucks.
job_title: Research Study Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: The benefits are good.  The tuition assistance program is generous, but can be tricky to actually use because it's only available if there is a seat available in the class and you can't register until 2 weeks after the start -- so it's not a true benefit.
cons: Salary.  The salary is shamefully low.  It's a nice place to work but you'll never get anywhere with this job.  What you see is what you get. There is no advancement opportunity.

job_title: IT Senior Director in Seattle, WA
pros: The culture is open and inclusive and exciting! Excellent medical, dental, life insurance and other benefits.  The UW offers many opportunities for advancement for entry and mid-level employees.  Many UW Schools/units afford flexible schedules and some offer teleworking opportunities.
cons: Governance by consensus can be tiring at times, but part of the culture of inclusion is to offer opportunities for open discussions to enhance the outcome of projects or strategies.

pros: The University of Washington has good benefits, beautiful campus, and great food options.  They offer excellent opportunities to learn. Excellent commuting options.
cons: Some management styles can be difficult to work under. My direct manager would sit at his laptop and watch sports half the day, never worked full days, and then micromanage the people under him as though worried they might follow his example.

pros: Benefits and paid time off
cons: Lower than market salaries for majority  of non-faculty staff positions, understaffing approach campus wide as means of operational cost saving

review_title: The University has so many opportunities
pros: so many opportunities; supporting students; great benefits
cons: limited pay; School's inability to manage out poor leaders

pros: Working with students at both the undergrad and graduate level was rewarding. The medical and retirement benefits are fairly good.
cons: I have worked in government, nonprofit, and industry but never have I been treated as poorly as an employee as I was working at UW. The staff are underappreciated, and underpaid. The salaries are so low that UW is not even competing with many of the nonprofits in Seattle.

review_title: Very good learning environment and well balance life-style
pros: The location of UW is very good, it's in Seattle area which has well diverse cultures.  The work place is very nice and you gain benefit of being close to the research activities at UW.
cons: UW doesn't sponsor H1B so it is hard for international students to continue working at UW.  Otherwise it's a great place to work for.

review_title: Amazing school in the heart of a lively city
pros: In the middle of Seattle, so a lot to do outside of working. You get access to a gym and have a pass for public transportation. Working in the athletic department gives you access to events, football games and such, that is better than the public or even alumni.
cons: Smaller department with not as much money as the bigger school, so it is harder to act on ideas when people have them because the resources just aren't always there

review_title: Relaxed student job working with interesting people and technology
job_title: Student Lab Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
-Working with cutting edge technology
-Getting to know top researchers in the field
-World class research university
-Beautiful campus
-Extremely flexible hours
-Good opportunities to learn more about the field
cons:
-Low pay
-Limited hours (hired on grant funding)
-Few opportunities for working directly with faculty
-No benefits

pros: Great university with a lot of great research being done. Experience really depends on the lab where you work. I had a great experience.
cons: Only con is that the pay is kind of low especially when you are starting out. All of their funding comes from grants, so your job depends on whether there is funding or not.

job_title: Graduate Research Fellow in Seattle, WA
pros: The UW offers its graduate student employees (research and teaching assistants + fellows) a great package that has been bargained by a strong union. The advantages are numerous including access to gym, public transport, daycare, good health insurance, etc.
cons: Large organization, sometimes paperwork becomes difficult, and large programmatic changes in payroll have sometimes caused serious delays in some students getting paid.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Seattle, WA
pros: A lot of intellectual freedom, and premier researchers to work with.  World class departments more or less across the board and many opportunities to work with them.
cons: Poor pay scale, management eyes the graduate student benefit package regularly as a way to solve their budgetary problems.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Seattle, WA
pros: World-class professors, huge variety of coursework and research options, diverse seminar offerings, very active grad student union (hence, fantastic health coverage), access to superb recreational facilities included in your student fees; very bike-friendly campus
cons: Funding for teaching assistants and benefits is at risk as management seeks to cut costs; grad student experience varies based on department/program; parking is expensive

job_title: Research Scientist Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
Work you can take pride in
Many benefits (gym, healthcare, bus pass, etc)
cons:
Bad management
The specific lab and department had terrible communication and morale
The specific lab had an unhealthy atmosphere, there was no team feeling or sense of community

pros: I find my co-workers are all considerate, professional and hardworking. I learn a lot from them and appreciate all the professional development opportunities as well as the good benefits and resources for work/life balance. I also appreciate all the work to reduce waste and the environmentally friendly culture that taking shape.
cons: As with any large organization there are time consuming procedures and protocols to follow and take a long time to become proficient in.

pros: The brand, the name, nothing else. It looks good on a resume which is the only redeeming value. Use that to get a real job.
cons: You're not encouraged to advance or grow career wise. You must stay in the same job and it's expected. Managers grandfather in friends which makes the working enviornment that much harder. Refer a friend and if they don't meet the criteria, i.e. pretty blonde girl or blue eyed guy then forget it. They have the same hiring criteria as Abercrombie & Fitch. The infamous benefits are not that great.

pros:
Work life balance
Opportunities for growth and development
Great benefits including vacation, sick leave, multiple options for medical and dental insurance, even a tuition exemption program and several retirement plans
Management is interested in helping employees be successful.
cons: The pay is inline with or better than other public higher education institutions, but still a little less than the private sector. Experience can vary by school or department, but all the ones I've worked with have been great.

pros:
* Flexible schedule for the most part
* Amazing architecture in some of the buildings
cons:
* Limited opportunities for growth
* Non-existent avenues for feedback and engagement with administration
* Lack of vision
* Lack of interest in educating students and mostly concerned about either money or power

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: I loved the ability to work in my department to support myself while going to school. In addition I felt like the experience added to my education. There is also something about hearing undergrads complain about tests and papers that made me want to NOT emulate them and maintain a positive attitude in my own classes.
cons: The spike in workload generally corresponds to your own class deadlines.  Depending on the complexity of grading, the time commitment can be a real burden for low pay.

job_title: Art Lab Administrator in Seattle, WA
pros: Flexible, work study, interaction with other students, learn to work independently. You are able to make mistakes in this environment and learn from them. People who you support are also students, so they can easily relate.
cons: pay was a little low, since it is a student job, short staff means harder to find coverage for when life happens and an employee cannot make it into work.

pros: Very good people to work with. They understand your study schedule and always work around that in an efficient manner. Great way to learn for someone with less experience
cons: None that I could see to be very frank. Its a great place and they pay decently well also. If you are looking for a temporary job, there are none better

pros: The University staff is extremely knowledgeable and educated with the importance of massage therapy to athletic performance. Schedule can be flexible and staff support is fantastic!
cons: Depending on how many hours and teams you woukd like to work, there are times where work weeks can be very hectic, and others where you may need to work when the University slows down for the summer.

pros: Casual work environment & beautiful campus
cons: Some departments will advertise job vacancies that are already filled by internal staff just to meet EEOC requirements and avoid potential lawsuits.

job_title: Network Engineer in West Seattle, WA
pros:
Great chance to flex your knowledge.  I thoroughly enjoyed many of the projects that I worked on.
Competitive  compensation "if you meet the criteria"
Some of the team were great people to encounter
cons:
Management is shady. 
Some co-workers  are hateful and allowed to be so
Don't get sick, they will eat you alive
HR is venomous

review_title: A good place to work for if you are a student and want a part time job!
pros: Work atmosphere is very friendly. Everyone knows each other and communicates freely. And work schedule is super flexible. You can work whenever you want, during class breaks, on the weekends... Obviously this also depends on what kind of job you are given from your supervisor.
cons: Only good for a student who wants a part time job in campus. No benefits other than hourly pay.

review_title: Great place to work; very unfriendly towards international staff
pros: UWMC is consistently ranked high. Wonderful benefits. Good salary. cutting edge research. highly collaborative environment. awesome if you have long term research career goals. flexible work hours and most of the ppl i work with are really cool.
cons: Very unfriendly for international STAFF. You are ok if you are faculty with PhD. Dont accept a staff position and they wont sponsor your WORK VISA. I feel discriminated here.

job_title: Research Scientist III in Seattle, WA
pros: You can set your own schedule, the benefits are great, and the opportunity to learn through free higher education is great. I  design my own experiments and run my own project- which is very nice.
cons: Decreased wages, no increase in pay since the pay freeze back in 2010, management style is lax and can cause confusion amongst lab member.

pros: There is long term stability working for the State of Washington and benefits include generous health care and good retirement options. There are also stable pensions and retirement benefits.
cons: Although the University of Washington is revolutionary in research, the rest of the institution is slow to change. Change happens at a glacial pace, and I miss working for the dynamic private sector where it feels like you are making a difference.

review_title: Varies from one department to another, as far as I can tell.
job_title: Public Information Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Flexible working hours, great benefits and good people. Located right in the middle of Seattle but away from Downtown, making parking and traffic bearable if you live north.
cons: Can seem siloed at times, and you don't tend to interface too much with different departments. I think that it can be hard to feel a connection to campus if you work at a building off-campus, like in the Tower or elsewhere.

job_title: Research Scientist I in Seattle, WA
pros: I have the freedom in my position to work independently and learn a lot in the process. The skills I've gained will be indispensable in my future career and education.
cons:
Being a public institution, don't have too high of expectations regarding salary. 
Also, coupled with the low salary, there is no free parking for employees. I understand that a lot of people bus/bike/walk to campus, but it's kind of crazy that to park in the lots it's $15 per day for everyone including employees

review_title: Great place to work, if you can afford it
pros: Met the most brilliant people, all interested in their field. The place is so big, you could experience all different kinds of work cultures and bosses, but in my case, supervision was mild, leaving you time to figure out new and better ways of doing things.
cons: Very poor pay, typically. Hard to rise if no one ever leaves your division.

pros: Great group of people in many departments. Create opportunities for new concepts (not always approved). Good recognition program and events to recognize special occasions, milestones, and work excellence.
cons: Managers unfair to people they just don't like and never give them a chance. Upper management has experience issues when coming to reviews (not knowing aspects of employee work). Some evidence (not personal, but to former co-workers) of blackballing of former employees to new opportunities.

review_title: Great benefits, opportunities to learn and stimulating environment.
pros: I have worked here for seven years and have found the support I need, whether from my manager or a consultant within the university system. I have grown and learned a lot in my position. It is a wonderful place to work.
cons: As a state employee you are tied to legislative decisions, regardless of your department. The salary freeze and layoffs have made for a slightly negative work environment at times.

review_title: Great environment and benefits, but slightly low pay
job_title: Senior Computer Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros:
Great people - even the few annoying ones have redeeming qualities
Great benefits - continue your education for free!
Diversity - people come to the UW from all over the world
The campus - gorgeous
cons:
State school = bureaucracy
Rate of pay is often below that of equivalent positions in the private sector
Shrinking state budgets often result in increased responsibilities without a corresponding increase in compensation

review_title: Overall good experience working here. Managers kept me in the loop and made sure that I knew what I was doing.
pros: Friendly people to work with and right on campus. The best part is walking 5 minutes from campus to the UW Tower to go to work.
cons: Low pay compared to jobs at at other companies for the same skill level. You are essentially trading pay for convenience.

pros: Great people and fast moving environment. It is very collaborative and helps people learn and grow very fast. Very prestigious
cons: It is a huge organization. Hard for administrating and coordinating events between departments. Sometimes people will ask you to work in the field you are not familiar with

pros: UW is a great place to work. Campus is dynamic. Work/Life balance is superb. Benefits are excellent.
cons: Salary isn't the best. The UW is a huge state school. Sometimes simple changes (like adding a new position to staff) require more time than a private company. Red tape.

pros: The scheduling flexibility was fantastic, especially for students.  The pay was good for the job, better than most campus job.  Boss (director), was a wonderful person.
cons: I can't think of any cons.  It is an ideal job for students at the University of Washington, especially if you like teaching or instructing.

review_title: Pleasant Time at University of Washington's Medical Center
pros:
Allows for flexibility with work schedule in conjunction with school
Friendly atmosphere with management and co-workers
Can navigate to other departments if interested
cons:
Though there is flexibility with work schedules, cumulative work hours are too laxed
Have the attitude to "let go" certain employees that lack sufficient motivation thats been working for over a year

review_title: UW Libraries is a great place to work, with good and knowledgeable people.
pros:
Development of communication and people skills
Great colleagues and managers 
Helpful workshops and meetings
Great Intellectual community 
Respectful treatment of employees
cons:
Few advancement opportunities
Lots of bureaucracy
Low pay in comparison to private sector  
No parking passes, or transportation/bus stipends 
Few to no performance reviews

review_title: Difficult to find a good place to work at the UW
pros: The campus. Husky pass. UW Temp Staffing.
cons: Disrespect to older employees. I would recommend against working at Harborview or in the School of Medicine. Supervisors who don't know how to supervise and managers who don't know how to manage. Non-supervisors and non-managers suffer as a result.

review_title: UW is a good place to be a graduate student
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Seattle, WA
pros: They provide solid benefits. It is located on a beautiful campus in the middle of Seattle. Many of the faculty members are top notch.
cons: Course load is a bit much compared to other programs. There should be better oversight as to who and how many people they let in to the program

review_title: Training opportunities are good...for a very narrow career path.
pros: Fantastic location---mountains, Puget Sound, great restaurants, bike trails, etc. Great colleagues and interesting seminars all year. Good health care and dental options.
cons: Little training for a future job. Stagnant salaries. Mandatory retirement contributions for employees in training positions (i.e., a pyramid scheme). Virtually no benefits other than health/dental. The cost of living is higher than average, but it's not impossible.

pros: If you're looking for stability and room for growth, then UW is the way to go. There's so many opportunities within different departments. You can move from one department to another, but you'll always remain employed under the U. This is helpful as you won't have to change your insurance/retirement plans!
cons: Low pay for the work you put in. If you were to work elsewhere, you could definitely make more.

review_title: Generally positive culture with the usual bureaucracy and corruption.
pros:
(This review is for a support staff, non-teaching, position held by a PhD recipient from the same university. )
The university attracts many interesting people to work with. 
The environment provides some unique projects and challenges.
The benefits are decent.
cons:
Like many large public universities there is a high level of administrative bloat and signs of nepotism everywhere. 
You will likely encounter roadblocks to getting your work done due to the bureaucracy and scope of the institution.

review_title: A unique working experience but can be frustrating at times
job_title: Assistant to the Chair in Seattle, WA
pros: Thereare a lot of job opportunities across campus amd the pay is good. Good benefits, paid holidays and a great retirement plan.
cons:
The tuition waiver benefit isn't as useful as it used to be. With tight budget from Olympia, many departments are struggling. Makes for a more stressful work environment. Lots of layoffs and reductions without much notice.
Departmental leadership are not given training on leadership.

review_title: As good as can be expected
pros:
Great work / life balance
Great benefits (Health, retirement)
Great infrastructure
World class research across board
Extraordinary administrative grant submission support system
cons:
Very siloed: can be hard to find your way
Promotion criteria aren't followed
A great deal of ego-driven individuals who put themselves before anything and anyone else
Very intransparent
Family doesn't matter
No mentorship tradition: you are on your own.

review_title: The University of Washington is a great place to work.
job_title: Research Scientist III in Seattle, WA
pros: Access to an immense trove of academic documents and to the faculty and staff of many departments.
cons: Scale.  It is way too big.  The shear size of the institution makes it hard to make significant changes to the administrative structure.  It is subject to the austerity measures of reduced state and federal funding.

review_title: A good place to go to school.
pros: Good city to live in, lots of outdoor opportunities, easy to bike to work, lots of beautiful outdoor spaces, and intelligent undergraduates.
cons: Pay is low, our union has been taken advantage of, and our voice is not heard in making any decisions.

review_title: Stay there for your colleagues, leave for better pay and advancement
pros:
Lots of kind, welcoming, caring staff
Opportunities for professional development
cons:
There is no advocate on campus for staff - do not look to HR for assistance, they are there for the university. 
Lots of inequity in terms of pay, flexible schedules and release time for furthering your education (ironic, I know)

review_title: Commuter Services Student Assistant Job Review
pros: I like some of the managers, the students, and a few full time workers. Working in the gatehouse is great, especially when you need to do homework.
cons: It sucks working outside, especially when it snow, rain and hail at the same time! Also, some of the full time workers and managers can be grumpy.

review_title: Lucky to work for a good director.
job_title: IT Project Manager in Seattle, WA
pros:
amazing work life balance
super supportive director
casual dress
fantastic benefits
work for a good cause
cons: really difficult for salary to keep up when moving to a new role. i started out with an amazing salary for the role but got promoted several times and the salary just couldn't keep up with the increase in responsibility. also, there are a lot of "career" employees who are super set in their ways and hinder progress.

pros:
Washington offers the highest minimum wage salary, so working for the restaurants is easy work for decent pay that allows for some spending money

Most of your coworkers are fellow students so there's an opportunity to network and get to know your peers
cons: Management is terrible, since they generally deal with students with a high turnover ratio they don't make themselves known or take the time to get to know you

job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Richland, WA
pros: Had an amazing experience working in a Housing roll responsible for a group of Resident Advisers.  Provided the feel of an RA job with more responsibilities and different leadership opportunities.
cons: You are required to live on campus in a residence hall, which some people are not keen on. Other than that, no cons that I can think of.

pros: University of Washington is one of the most famous university in the world. I gained a rich and deep real experience of skills and way of thinking in engineer field through courses, projects and research opportunities in UW.
cons: Most students in UW are enterprising and hard-working students, so you might encounter a fast-paced and challenging social-life and study cycle.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: WA state benefits are really great.  Matches retirement contribution, but only 5% if under 35 (as I am).  Discounted Orca fares. Good community and on campus resources.
cons: While pay is in line with most institutions, they have not taken the progressive steps that some other institutions have to require minimum postdoc salaries at 50k+.  They are honoring the overtime act currently have have provided the $3957 a month minimum despite it being stalled at the Federal level.

job_title: Assistant to the Associate Dean in Seattle, WA
pros: The work that the UW does with/for its students, faculty, and community is impressive, and the mission is very strong. You work with a number of brilliant and motivated colleagues. Campus is a fun work environment.
cons: The bureaucracy that comes with being a large public university can be stifling at times. Some faculty and staff can be difficult colleagues, and it varies widely throughout campus.  Tenure is a very powerful thing, and enables bad behavior among some.

pros:
I worked as a student assistant for Housing and Food Services. The pros are 
- flexible work schedule. They just put work shifts on a board and you can sign up with the manager. And no troubles if you have exams, homework, emergency or anything.
-Comfortable environment
-very friendly staff
cons:
I can't come up with anything unsatisfying actually. But if I have to say,
- works are kind of repetitive and boring. 
- can be very busy depending on the hour

review_title: Former Camera Man with the Husky Football Team
job_title: TV Equipment Operator in Seattle, WA
pros: Great benefits for student workers, such as free meals before or after work hours, Free parking during events and practices, and more husky gear than you'll know what to do with.  Also has great flexibility in terms of scheduling.
cons: Working environment can be a little intense at times.  This also depends on the coaching staff at the time, but when the team isn't doing so well there can be a lot yelling.

pros: Has good health care for patients and takes great care of them. Looks into what it can do to make patients healthier and well. great job.
cons: It is miserable to its staff at times and does not know how to appreciate the good staff when they have it.

pros: Health benefits, actual retirement possibility
cons: Terrible management. Blackballs people for standing up for themselves. Targets people who contact the union for issues regarding employment practices and is not so unlike high school. Not a meritocracy. You can double your workload and successfully complete assignments and another person who does much less moves on into other positions because they suck up to management instead of being honest.  Liars are believed and back-stabbing at FMC is routine.

review_title: Great place to work, with understanding supervisors
job_title: Help Desk Consultant in Seattle, WA
pros: Good pay, to be working part time and as a student. Amount of work given is fair, so you are able to manage you school work
cons: I have nothing really negative to say about the work environment there, besides that they should have a insurance plan for their employees.

review_title: Exciting place to be right now.
pros: UW is a university on the move with many dedicated staff members who care immensely about student success. The school is positioned to become even stronger in the near future and it's exciting to be part of this momentum.
cons: Very siloed compared to the other three universities I have worked at in the past and departments/schools struggle to collaborate across campus due to the constraints of the Activity-Based Budgeting (ABB) model.

pros:
Many opportunities research a topic of interest, especially in Chemistry.
Many opportunities to develop skills including teaching, lab equipment, instrumentation, computer, communications.
cons:
TA Protocol may change depending on the performance/ troubling trends noticed by other TAs.
Healthcare benefits have declined over the last few years. Standard pay for graduate students varies from year to year.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Great environment as a prestigious research institution. Supporting community of academics that work hard and make themselves available for help. Opportunities to network with top PhDs in various fields, further one's own education and conduct groundbreaking research.
cons: Processes seemed to lack standards. Project management was rudimentary which created stress, disorganization and delay.

pros: Doing research at the UW offers a bubble of opportunities that not only include competitive salaries, but working with some of the smartest people in the industry.
cons: Work-life balance may be difficult, I did not have consistent schedules and had to come into work at some inconvenient times that may include weekends.

review_title: IT Assistant, Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations
pros: Hours are very flexible in the NELC department. My Supervisor and I have one-on-one meetings frequently, and she always asks for my input on current events.
cons: There are not very many downsides to working for the Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations, besides their office space being located far away in Condon hall.

job_title: Lab Assistant & Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros: APL offers great benefits and from my experience a very positive working atmosphere. There are plenty of opportunities to grow and learn from everyone there.
cons: As with working within research in almost any facet, the biggest downside is available funding and knowing where your skills will be needed. Networking is key to avoid dry spells.

review_title: I worked one year at University of Washington
pros: Good Benefits, and  free classes.
cons: My lab was understaffed,  a lot of people quit. It takes a lot of time to hire more people because there are not a lot of candidates who want to work in academia since industry jobs pay better. For that reason, you end doing the job of your former coworkers plus yours. No growth if you are only a research scientist with a degree. Not work/life balance
