pros: great location: it's right in the city on a wonderful campus.  The weather's great and so is seattle.  Your experience is going to depend completely on what department you are working in; each department is like a different company, which can be a good or bad thing.
cons: bad pay; it's a university.  There really isn't a lot negative I have to say.

review_title: Fine place to work, but being a postdoc kind of sucks anywhere...
pros: Great facilities. There is a lot of collaboration and it is possible to find almost any piece of equipment that you might need to use. The post doc association has a lot of career development talks and socials.
cons: Parking is expensive. Although bus system is great, Saturday bus schedule is completely different and parking is $4/hour (and you have th move the car every two hours...).

review_title: It was great, learning and competitive.
pros: It was great to be working part-time for an income while going to school here. It was also great as the job helps to learn more new thing.
cons: Sometimes it was overloaded between work and school homework. During a tight deadline between work and school homework, work is going to win.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: The pros are that you get to work on interesting projects and take tuition waived classes that lead to an advanced degree.
cons: The cons are that the pay is extremely low and the work is done very inefficiently, resulting in very little work getting done per hour spent working.

review_title: Good Graduate School Experience in the BioEngineering Department
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Seattle, WA
pros: generally well funded and respected department, many opportunities for collaborations, close to medical center/hospital to allow for more clinically involved projects, involved and cohesive student body
cons: The required graduate curriculum was not very strong when I entered the department 5 years ago, but it has since been revised, hopefully for the better. The research experience you will have depends heavily on the atmosphere of the lab that you join and on the PI.

pros: Good work-life balance, smart people, great environment. While there is a bit of the bureaucratic overhead that one would expect from any large organization, things are generally well run and most of the departments can do a lot of things independently. The university is very open to adopting new technology and there are some really interesting projects happening across departments.
cons: Some offices are a bit under-staffed and the pay can be lower than at private companies

review_title: Student workers: the best place to work during your undergraduate years
pros: The biggest draw about working at the University of Washington while studying there, is the chance to make some high quality connections. Being around researchers and other faculty gives you a chance to make friends with them, pick their brains, and land better job or research opportunities. All you have to do is ask!
cons: Pay isn't the greatest, but what else do you expect from a part-time undergraduate job.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Seattle, WA
pros: UW has amazing resources for scientists, students, and postdocs. I receive good benefits. My salary is set at a federal level. There's a postdoctoral association and student union that advocates for students. The university is highly progressive.
cons: The cost of living is high in Seattle, so the salary does not cover as much as it would elsewhere.

pros: Beautiful campus, talented colleagues, great benefits
cons: Inadequate pay for Seattle area, competitive in a cutthroat way not a productive way, people will quickly throw anyone else under the bus to guard their jobs, and they will do so unprovoked, it is a campus that does very little to penalize harassers, and will find loopholes to retaliate against whistle blowers, direction of the campus seems to be to benefit administrators, not students

pros: Good team to work with, ability to take on side projects, opportunities to gain more skills, good benefits, easy access by public transportation,
cons: Lack of advancement opportunities simply because most people stay until they retire.  Not very telecommute friendly for positions that could be done 100% remotely, commute is very long unless you move to the city.

pros: There are a lot of great people that work at the University of Washington.  The mission and purpose of the organization is inspiring, and the University itself is a world-class institution.
cons: The traffic all around the University of Washington campus makes commuting a challenge at times, and parking can be quite costly.

pros: Very flexible, with excellent chances to meet and network. Always did something different, which kept things interesting. Good support from coworkers and managers.
cons: Working late Friday, Saturday, and just very odd hours in general. Pay is not fantastic. Working for a large organization tied to the government.

pros: Good pay for what you do (or don't), especially considering you are most likely a student. Great people! Relaxed environment, very flexible time schedules.
cons: Advancement is hard considering you are a student. No benefits really...but once again you are a student worker.

pros: Flex time, good benefits, "free" bus pass. Working at a University means you never do quite the same thing for very long. Great food nearby on the Ave! Most departments have fairly generous leave policies, so you can actually use your vacation
cons: Low pay, but that is to be expected working for a University. Not a lot of movement available unless you're willing to change departments. Lots of politics at the higher levels..

pros: As a leading research institute, university of washington offers countless opportunities to collaborate. The benefits are quite good as well.
cons: Not specific for just UW. The postdoctoral fellow position pays just a hair more than graduate students. This is cons of any academic job, however, and I don't particularly hold this over UW.

pros: If you are in Advancement, you will be paid more but worked more. Can be a good place to work with good work/life balance.
cons: Very difficult to move up within departments.  You must cross campus to go up.  Some departments can harbor long timers who do things "they way they have always been done" and can be difficult to work with.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: The position I held as Teacher's Assistant paid for my enrollment in a graduate science program. The hours were worked around research and group meetings and the compensation was decent.
cons: Some professor's are poor managers. They do not provide enough guidance or feedback. Sometimes they become unpleasant if you do meet expectations they failed to communicate.

pros: Smart, dedicated employees, generous vacation benefits (for the U.S.), flexible schedule (depending on the job), good health coverage and retirement benefits. UW supports bike commuting and public transit with special events and perks.
cons: A lot of academics could use more management training. Project management expertise is lacking in many units. Some units make up for management failures by working long hours.

review_title: One of the better places in Seattle to work
job_title: Program Operations Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Academic culture, inclusive culture, job stability, feeling of purpose, collegial atmosphere, beautiful campus, lots of mass transportation to and from.
cons: Lower pay, hard to get raises, lots of space wars--some people end up in hallways and closets

pros: University of Washington is a wonderful place to work. Their access to resources to get the job done is what makes working here so wonderful. They also really do carry an amazing benefits package. They make sure to take care of their employees.
cons: It is such a large institution. The biggest thing to look for when accepting a job here is who you you report to. Also because of the size projects can become very siloed.

review_title: Fine if you're using State Tuition Waiver
pros: The state will waive tuition fees if you are attending a state funded program. I was able to get my MBA at a huge discount while working here. The health benefits are great.
cons: Resistant to change. A lot of sexism in the workplace. If you are a woman, your work will not speak for itself and if someone higher up doesn't usher you through, it will be very difficult to get promoted/raises.

review_title: A nice, low-key place to work
pros: UW is a historic and impressive institution with lots of opportunities. People are open and there's a good work/life balance.
cons: The bureaucracy can be frustrating when trying to get something done or find out what is happening in other departments, groups.

job_title: Preventative Maintenance Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: The job is close to the campus and idea for students since the commute is very easy to make.  The job isn't all that demanding.
cons: The tasks and organization of certain things can seem wasteful at times.  Difficult to change things and implement larger changes.  Not much room for advancement.

review_title: Large Institution - Education and Medical Care
job_title: Research Study Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: Excellent reputation for some academic departments - Nobel prize winners on faculty-  health benefits - education benefits- multiple worksites, for example South Lake Union, Harborview Medical Center, Tacoma, Seattle and Bothell campuses-
cons: Each department or division is like a separate employer. For example, the climate at Harborview is very different from  upper campus or the UW Medical Center. Benefits are better than salaries.

pros: Great benefits, great co-workers, great location. Expertise is valued by all levels of the organization. Leadership is approachable.
cons: The university is complacent. There are so many "special" characteristics that inhibit transformational change. Change is desired, but there are many sacred cows. Too many unions also restrict change. Salaries, as usual for higher ed, don't align with industry.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Seattle, WA
pros:
Great benefits
Meaningful organization
Worked for an amazing director
Lots of opportunity to move up and try new things 
Funny, of complacent colleagues
cons:
I moved up several times from lower positions and the salary never caught up. I made ~$30k less than other people in similar roles with similar backgrounds. And I was way more effective at my job. 
Direct manager was kind and funny but pretty ineffective.

pros: The pros were that you could have a flexible schedule because there were so many employees and that it was conscientious because all the locations were on campus
cons: The worst part was by far the management. They had no respect and no organization. It was all he said she said and a complete mess.

pros: It's a big university, lots of smart people. In the department where I worked, the management team is great, the employees work hard and motivated.
cons: Some of the buildings are a little bit old, need some renovations. Certain degree of work place hierarchy in some places.

review_title: One of the best job environments I've worked in.
pros: Clean facilities, average pay (to start), everything up to code, good work environment, good management staff, climate-controlled buildings, set work hours, easily accessible by bus/car, paid street & private lot parking, nice campus.
cons: Takes a while for maintenance to fix things like burnt out light bulbs, bureaucracy, very little job security at low-level positions, lack of regular raises, mandatory union membership

pros: Benefits are good & accessible at UW, even for temporary employees. The lab I worked in showed great flexibility in striking a good work-life balance - work didn't interfere with my studies.
cons: Wages are flat & low for research associates at the lab I work in, leading to discontent. Work-study positions afford limited learning opportunities - the only skill sets I acquired were processing blood samples and handling biohazardous waste properly.

pros: Beautiful campus in a central location, great tuition benefits for graduate programs, strong work-life balance which is great for employees.
cons: Upward mobility is lacking in many departments as there are many people who have burrowed into their jobs (and their ways). Leadership at all levels lack skills to actually lead and motivate.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: The University of Washington is a great place to do a postdoc. The research environment is collaborative, the campus is peaceful, and Seattle is a beautiful city.
cons: As with any university, the salary is not commensurate with the level of education and amount of work required to do the job

job_title: Lab Manager, Research Scientist III in Seattle, WA
pros: Good flexibility, great people in most cases, good money. Great to work in an academic environment.
cons: As a research scientist you're usually working on soft grant money. Puts you in a position to be looking for a new job every 5-8 years in my experience.

review_title: Student Employee - Housing and Food Services
pros: Flexible hours, great first job, a good way to get work experience on your resume and they offer competitive pay!
cons: The work is too taxing sometimes as the scheduling is not very efficient and people often do not call out before not showing up. This increases the workload of the employees that do show up.

job_title: Predoctoral Research Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: Lot's of smart people. Easy to collaborate across departments. Great grad student compensation compared to other public universities. Seattle has great public transportation.
cons: Large bureaucracy. New payroll system leads to errors in employee pay. Seattle is too expensive, even with a generous RA stipend. I wouldn't recommend moving here until the next recession brings down housing costs.

pros:
Mature, driven, diverse student population; the students are an absolute pleasure to work with
Autonomy
Academic freedom
Insurance and retirement options
cons:
Poor retention of faculty
Successful lecturers are churned: laid off and replaced, or demoted to part-time
Lip-service is paid to diversity in order to benefit neoliberal management
Toxic workplace
Overly bureaucratic 
Lecturer pay

pros: Wide scope of research interests available.
cons: No benefits. Little to no room to transition to independent positions. Little University support/commitment to postdoctoral training. Pay is terrible considering the  cost of living increases in the Seattle area. Obtaining prestigious awards that pay your own postdoctoral salary almost always results in the University of Washington canceling matching retirement contributions.

review_title: Facilities, Students and Staff Support are Top Notch
pros: I love the quality of students I get to share my experience with. The UW provides a lot of resources for the class and helping me be a better instructor. Flexibility in class types (in-person, online, hybrid) helps fit the right instructional framework to the right group of students.
cons: While the buildings on campus are fantastic (Paccar Hall is amazing!), the facility downtown is a little dates.

review_title: UW Good Place for life sciences grad students
pros: As a life sceinces PhD student, I can say that you are well taken care of at UW. There are good benefits.
cons: Sometimes your department may be out of contact with the graduate school and things will be complicated by beaurocracy. It can be unclear at times.

review_title: Pros & Cons for working at University of Washington
pros: Nice weather, neighborhood and very nice campus; world-famous university particularly for genomics, computer science and medicine; no income tax on the state; multicultural.
cons: Some buildings (from not so rich departments) are pretty old; crime reported occasionally on campus; quite competitive; benefits not too impressive.

pros: UW is a great place to work and it is a beautiful campus to spend time on. Also lots of food choices for lunch.
cons: Downside of working at the UW as a staff member is if you are considered professional staff or if you are supported by the union.

pros: Great work schedule. Easy job. It is good to be able to work any hours I want to be able to study if needs be.
cons: The computer systems are old and poorly set up. The printers are a pain and take a lot of maintenance. Getting a bunch of errands that take precedence over others for no good reason.

review_title: Great place for the right person
pros: Interesting people, great students, good benefits. Can provide a great springboard into management if you are in the right office. Opportunity to study with the tuition benefit is great.
cons: Growth is non-existent, people stay too long in their jobs, highly political and bureaucratic, slow moving to make decisions

pros: Flexible hours; very pleasant campus environment and work setting; many offices have windows; support for communication and expression around projects;
cons: Lack of technology, my work area, experience of understanding of typical practices; distrust for new ideas, because project support is based on old, long-term relationships of stakeholders; treatment of contract positions as fungible and below others;

job_title: Student Orientation Leader in Seattle, WA
pros: Great learning opportunity. Tests your ability to facilitate big groups, as well as facilitate dialogue around small group discussions.
cons: You have to work a substantial amount of hours and you get pretty tired of working after a couple of months.

pros: I am a student, working part time at the Department of Transportation services. My supervisor was very understanding and, if given advance notice, will always give me time off if I have exams, assignments, etc.
cons: Not much to complain. I worked only for a year, and part time. One thing that I don't like about my job specifically is that it's a routine work, so not much difference from day to day.

pros: The Project Manager was a great leader. As long as the goals were in order she was flexible, listened to ideas and encouraged advancement like no other person I have ever met. The faculty was brilliant and very patient.
cons: The union was the only reason I was paid properly. New grants were never funded and the papers were not written in time for new studies to promptly follow.

pros: Lots of great students at UW. It's a diverse and fun group on campus, and students are eager to learn. The department I taught in had a very collegial atmosphere and I felt well supported.
cons: The professional students can come across as a bit entitled. If a class isn't immediately building a skill they want some students find it off putting. Also, the course software Canvas is frustrating and buggy.

review_title: Experience depends on the specific department
pros: The city of Seattle is beautiful and so is the campus.  My experience was a positive one as the chair of my department had a  'hands off' approach.  I had the good fortune of working with some amazing individuals who were very supportive of me, especially during my early years.
cons: A lot of red-tape for administrative issues but not uncommon for such a large institution.

job_title: Library Desk Possition in Seattle, WA
pros: Working at the Media Center is awesome. The people here are very chill. It is the perfect job for your first year or two at college.
cons: The pay is something like 9$ an hour. The work can be tedious at times.

review_title: It is a great place to work.  It is hard to get fired!
pros: You can pretty much get away with doing what you want with none or little repercussions.
cons: Some upper managment is very incompetent and instead of placing individuals into positions in which they ACTUALLY FIT, they would rather give them glorified titles AND PAY, then to pay the front line workers.

review_title: Innovative work and focus on student success
pros: Work in Housing & Dining, which embraces UW mission and values and operationalizes therm in an accessible way.  Collaboration and  innovation are encouraged and rewarded.
cons: Hiring process at UW level is cumbersome anddiscourages applicants. We continued to find ways to counteract this poor first impression.

review_title: Worked in various positions as a graduate student
pros: Depending on the position, people are generally cooperative and the campus location/environment is a great place to work in. Great blend of the academic and work world.
cons: A lot of programs are not tech savvy/updated and there is often lots of long, complicated paperwork to fill out. Teaching assistants are not paid as well as they should be for the amount of time they put in.

pros: In the two units I worked for, both gave me the freedom to develop programs to meet the needs of staff, allow for employee development and be autonomous.
cons: Many meetings with other units were slow in getting to actionable tasks. It often was decision making by consensus which, at times, aeemed like a waste of resources.

review_title: A stable, if difficult, place to practice interaction design
job_title: User Experience Designer in Seattle, WA
pros: Low pressure environment, great benefits, great work-life balance, your work will impact social good, soft skills will be exercised greatly
cons: Politics, magical thinking, and consensus-driven decision making WILL impede your work as a designer; most groups on campus will not be a place for a UX designer or researcher to make a career

review_title: Working at University of Washington as a Graduate Research Assistant
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
Absolutely amazing research going on in some labs
Beautiful campus and surrounding area
Colleagues are generally pleasant to work with and very intelligent
cons:
Advisor/Boss quality highly variable
Research quality highly variable
Cost of living in surrounding area is high

pros: There is a good work life balance.  It is a very laid back place to work.  The benefits are good.
cons: Not a lot of upside potential unless you want to be a PI.  Job security depends on grand funding.  Not a very efficient work place

pros: There are very few schools which allow undergraduates to run office hours but at the UW there are many of these opportunities.
cons: It can be very exhausting to work many hours while a student even with very limited hours being worked due to the number of students who show up to office hours asking for help due to the size of classes and number of TA's available to answer questions.

pros: Great benefits (especially the health care), beautiful work environment/campus, motivated team of coworkers, connection to the educational mission.
cons: Comparatively low salaries to what I could be earning in the private sector, very limited telework options. Limited growth/promotion potential.

pros: creative freedom, great work environment, very flexible schedule, marketing experience in every area possible. Great opportunity.
cons: Don't have the budget to support a full-time role. words words words words words words am I at 20 yet I have no idea but this seems long enough.

review_title: A wealth of student staff jobs
pros: flexible schedule, professional colleagues, may lead to other opportunities, great benefits for full time positions
cons: there are many different departments but I never had any issues or encountered any cons, supervisors/directors are generally very easy to work with, especially with students

pros: The students are very motivated and my coworkers were very friendly and made it wonderful to come in every day and teach.
cons: The faculty and administration at times can be disjointed in their goals for certain programs, which might be understandable given the size of the UW.

job_title: Student Billing Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Great working environment with a lot of flexibility for students. Very encouraging and supportive teams.
cons: There seems to be a disconnect between upper management of the university with the other staffs. The recent system conversion proved to have proved that there is no official training, and upper management is not very supportive in helping staffs get adjusted to it nor help to improve it.

pros:
Flex schedule

Good work-life balance

Interesting mix of people
cons:
interdepartmental cronyism

misguided and unaccountable unit manager

turf wars between projects

review_title: Large University with Large University Strengths and Problems
pros: Large and well-regarded state university in great city with strong broad-based faculty.  Excellent school of medicine and health sciences schools.
cons: The University is a very large institution with large institution-style bureaucracy.  Seattle is a great city, but the weather leaves much to be desired.

pros: Flexible time; relatively flexible research directions; good library and on line journal subscriptions; friendly administrative staff; good benefit package; PTO and vacation.
cons: Post doc as a low pay and low respect job; not even allowed to serve as a PI for grant application; sub par working environment.

job_title: Alumni Relations Student Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Great place to work if you are a people person, since you deal with alumni every day. Great employees, too. Very flexible work schedule.
cons: Work can be very bursty, depending on the day or even the time of day. Since many alumni are retired and getting on in years, it can be hard to explain and help them utilize the technology that UWAA uses, which gets annoying.

pros: The salary was reasonable, the health benefits were fantastic, and the tuition waivers kept me from taking on A LOT of debt. Everyone I worked with in getting the position was easy to work with and there was plenty of feedback.
cons: The hours were pretty sporadic term to term. Also, they are pretty competitive which means being unsure every term (if you are not granted a year long position).

review_title: Excellent benefits and an easy opportunity to shine.
job_title: Computer Services Consultant in Seattle, WA
pros: Great benefits including defined benefit pension, many systems and processing currently headed into the 21st century so there are ample opportunities to develop you career and show management what you are capable of. Implementation of Lean across the organization providing opportunities for process improvement.
cons: Hiring get locked up in HR. Pay is much lower than the private sector. Many current employees are typical "state workers".

review_title: great place to balance life and work
pros: Potentially stimulating environment. Pretty campus. Access to libraries, art galleries, athletic center. Some work can be considered valuable to the common good.
cons: It's a giant public university, so obviously there are a lot of rules/regulations and general "big company" slowness and resistance to change that usually happen.

pros: Benefits are excellent for this time and place.  Work life balance. More life. Non critical if you know the basics of your job.
cons: Politics, politics, politics. Maintain the status quo at all costs and if you challenge that status quo in the least you will be alienated, isolated and retaliated against.  Even if you think you're just doing the job you were hired for.

review_title: OK to work, but not quickly
pros: The work-life balance is great, the staff are generally competent and nice.
cons:
Decisions are never made quickly. "19-1 is a tie" is a common expression, because any objection, for any reason, derails projects and plans.

As a result, "perfect" or "comprehensive" solutions costing 10x as much are preferred over anything that is "good enough"

review_title: Low pay, but learned a lot
pros: I was a research tech and in charge of a lot of my own projects. I learned a ton, and my experience made me a great candidate for graduate school.
cons: I was not paid very much. However, this is pretty par for the course in a university setting.

pros:
-Upper level library staff have been super helpful in providing guidance to graduate students
-If you are enrolled in the MLIS program its essentially the best place to get hands-on work training
-Nearly all management I've encountered are extremely friendly and enjoy the work they do
cons:
-Unless it is one of the highly competitive GA positions with benefits, the pay is pretty meager.
-Career advancement isn't really a thing for student positions

pros: Work with top people for a highly regarded institution. Lots of opportunities for change, growth, and involvement.
cons: Part time faculty positions are not well paid and offered little job security.  Recommend it if you want the experience and are interested in the program you're teaching, not for money and commitment.

review_title: I was working in Housing and food services UW
pros: The atmosphere that HFS has is great! Very welcoming and I learned a ton about sales and really how to interact with people. I was able to use a lot of the skills that I learned to apply to the position that I currently have now and I am definitely more confident because of it!
cons: I think this job doesn't have downsides!

pros: The work can be fun, and you get to learn a lot of new stuff in labs.
cons: The work can also be repetitive and boring. I've had 10 hour days where only 2 hours of work actually got done due to lack of communication. There can be a lot of waste and inconsistencies.

review_title: Meaningful work with smart, dedicated people appreciative of my contributions
job_title: Director of Operations in Seattle, WA
pros: Can achieve work life balance through flexible work schedules. Excellent benefits. Challenging and rewarding projects.
cons: Pay inequalities between males vs females. Political climate difficult, entitled “lifers” can be obstructionists. Nearly impossible to fire anyone for poor performance. Shrinking State funding a challenge.

pros: You get  to study at work. Flexible hours. Great coworkers and staff. You get alone time to work at your own pace.
cons: If there are a lot of books to shelve, it can get tiresome.

review_title: Land of career opportunity, but lacks gusto in the compensation area
pros: Beautiful campus, great potential for career growth and advancement, great benefits, tuition exemption, professional development, library access, discounted gym membership, cell phone discount, employee assistant program, discounted bus pass, amazing co-workers, fun, lots of places to eat for lunch.
cons: UW salary growth depends on outcomes from the legislature. Too much bureaucracy and red tape. Staff are cramped for space.

pros: Study barista job is fun, easy, you get to work with your friends, good jours
cons: Bad organization and scheduling... many people telling you different things... was supposed to get raises every quarter, only got one when i was promoted after working there over two years

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: They were really great at working with your school schedule and meeting your needs as a student. Also you learned a lot of valuable skills.
cons: Not much room to advance, low pay and not many hours. You also likely wouldn't be able to work during the summer.

pros: The benefits and education.
cons: It's a snobby place and very political. I saw many patients who were confused and intimidated with health care navigation. It's easy to get lost as a patient and staff. High turn over rate in staff.

pros: Besides the benefits, job security and advancement, the work culture at the UW is mostly very supportive and stimulating.  I have very fond memories of all of my supervisors except for one - which is the reason I'm not working there any longer.
cons: If you have a supervisor that is not supportive, career advancement can be a dead end.

review_title: Stable, Upbeat (if a tad stodgy) Home for Developers
pros: Great work/life balance. Free access to a lot of college courses. Great health and other benefits. Interesting coworkers. Little pressure. Friendly and engaged management. Greater sense of purpose.
cons: Slow paced. Little innovation unless driven by yourself. Salary is under market average. Average time off allowances. LOTS of HR trainings.

pros:
Great Benefits
Beautiful work environment
Stimulating activities on campus
Smart people
cons:
Faculty manage lots of things they're often not trained to do. Its fine until you get one who is particularly bad, then its hell.
The faculty / staff divide is the closest thing the US has to a caste system.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: It is a university with a strong quality research focus and a breadth of teaching resources, it is a dynamic and exciting place to work. The diversity of researchers, teachers, staff, and students is exciting and enriching.
cons: The administration like most large universities is bloated and overpaid. They also work actively to undermine the labor unions present on campus. This has been a long term struggle.

review_title: Good student job while attending UW
job_title: Student Library Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Relatively easy work and low stress, very flexible schedule and I can set my own hours, and I can also listen to podcasts or my own music oftentimes while working.
cons: Tasks can sometimes be monotonous or tedious, so it helps to listen to a podcast on those days. Since it's a student job there is not as much room for promotion in the position.

review_title: Varies widely from department to department
job_title: Senior Computer Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros:
Great benefits (usual benefits as well as fitness center, exceptional library, other UW resources)
Great salary
Great funding
Nice campus and location
cons:
Human Resources department not helpful to non-union staff
Bad central administrative and computing support, a lot of redundancy in every department

pros: Great benefits, generous vacation, good health plans, 12 sick days a year, some educational benefits, subsidized transit pass, educational discounts
cons: Little career advancement unless you're faculty, pay is woeful even for public sector work, for technical positions you often work under faculty and staff with little domain knowledge leading to a total lack of understanding of what your job entails. And working with faculty can be a total pain.

pros: UW offers good communication and support, from both management and from support staff.  If full time, great benefits.  Good location.
cons: If not full time, not good benefits (if any).  Can be a lot of work for not much pay for lecturers.

review_title: A challenging but generally positive experience
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Seattle, WA
pros: Decent program overall (department in the biomedical sciences)
cons: None come to mind that don't already come with the territory for grad school.  Tough program but good training.

review_title: Decentralized business means results may vary
pros: Decent benefits, good amount of sick/vacation time, stable
cons: Salary freeze from 2008-2012 means UW is behind the market. Every department is different in how they treat time off, raises, employment considerations

pros: Great people to work with and never a shortage of projects to do.  I've been here several years and love it.
cons: Some folks have an interesting time adjusting to the type of operations work and flow of projects at the UW.  Working for a large academic medical facility has a different pace to it and some folks just never quite adapt.

pros: Huge access to data, and extremely bright people. Breathtaking beautiful campus!!!
cons: Bully culture, antiqued policies, did I mention it's a depressingly effective bulling culture. It would be okay if you could just take one of these individuals behind Mary Gates Hall and express thyself with punch combos, but that's the last thing anyone needs.... Depressing. Could really be an ideal place to work...

job_title: Senior Computer Specialist in Seattle, WA
pros: Great group to work with. I was in radiology, nuclear imaging. Very knowledgable and professional staff.
cons: Due to government funding issues through most of my years there zero raises were given. Little improvement in staff compensation or working conditions. Lots of nepotism.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Seattle, WA
pros: You get your tuition covered and a stipend that is livable if you work while getting your degree. The health insurance is pretty good while you are a student, and it is compulsory even if you have other sources of insurance. UW has some good perks in terms of student access to the gym, sailing stuff, etc, but is otherwise pretty minimal.
cons: Definitely low paying, as you are a student.

job_title: PhD Candidate and Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: Great research opportunities due to size of school and status as state school, at least for engineering
cons: Large enough to be unwieldy bureaucratically; pay isn't nearly enough for Seattle, almost every PhD student I know at UW is rent-impoverished; must pay several unnecessary fees each quarter

review_title: Be prepared to be treated like a child.
pros:
Gained experience in teaching
Got paid over minimum wage
cons:
The rate that I was offered was withdrawn after I had accepted employment, and they gave me $5 less/hr than they said they would.
Also, don't expect HR to help you.  As a student, their main goal is to squash your argument rather than attempt to reconcile issues between the employee and employer.

pros: As a student the University works well with your schedule to get you work that will fit in with classes and other commitments. There are also many opportunities to move up the chain of command and become a full time employee after graduation.
cons: Being under State of Washington law has certain limits that aren't compensated by benefits since you are just a student employee.

pros:
- If you're working a desk, you usually can get your studying done while getting paid.
- Management is relaxed. 
- Occasional HUB employee appreciation events. 
- Access to food court downstairs. 
- Access to refrigerator.
cons:
- Job can get a little boring, since you're usually addressing the same series of questions. 
- Not much "career" opportunity, since you're a student employee.

pros: Great benefits and a good environment to work in. Plenty of opportunities for growth and continuing ed.
cons: The higher ed environment can be a little crazy. Corporations can set rules that won't fly in higher ed, making our jobs a little more difficult.

pros: Good Benefits, work environment, supportive, mentoring, good flexible schedule in my unit, good life/work balance overall. Educational opportunities are good.
cons: Ability to move between units is difficult. It would be better for RN longevity and patient safety to cross train RN's. It could prevent burnout & provide some resiliency in staffing

review_title: University of Washington Aeronautics and Astronautics: People are running away from this department
pros:
Lots of good co-workers. 
The undergrads and grad students come in highly motivated and can be fun to work with.
Individual programs and labs like the MAE Program, wind tunnel, fusion energy related research programs, propulsion, etc. have great people doing great work.
cons:
Departmental management is extremely difficult to work with, including regular incidents of employees getting shouted at.  It is also terrible about budget decisions, causing concerns about layoffs and undermining staff management of budgets.  That also has brought infrastructure and organizational improvements to a halt; we have had multiple occasions when days were spent doing scoping, design, or pricing only to be told to wait for a one departmental leader or another to get back from where ever it is they go for weeks. Donations have had more than half the money diverted to some vague admin functions.

Five staff have left. Two others retired ahead of their original plans. Two have transitioned out to other departments.  Someone was hired and left five months later.  Job requisitions get approved, advertised, and then closed without hiring anyone.  Three positions seem to be going unfilled.  Symptoms of bad management, such as tardiness, are very high.  For an organization with core staff positions numbering only 17, these problems and high turnover rate incur more inefficiency and new problems.

Three older faculty members who carry a big teaching load are rumored to be getting squeezed out, while the new department strategic planning draft document calls for looking to other universities to poach their young professors who were recently awarded big grants. Many Aeronautics and Astronautics faculty members may as well be ghosts since their appearances in central or admin areas are fleeting.

Undergrads have begun avoiding the Aero & Astro major, since they hear stories of shuffled and postponed courses due to the effects of poor leadership.

pros:
Flexible schedule if you have a supportive manager. 
Generous leave package.
cons:
Low salaries - 3-figures rare for staff
Minimal opportunities to advance 
No training and development opportunities
Poor - even harassing - behavior by faculty systemically tolerated. UW leadership does not walk the talk.
Blurred work/life boundaries.

job_title: "Ingeniero de caminos, canales y puertos en prácticas" in Seattle, WA
pros: Great benefits, everyone cares about your professional development and will support you as best as budget allows to go to conferences related to your job.
cons: Drama. There is a lot of fake personalities and hierarchical structures in place that people take very seriously. Also, many of those in management are very resistant to change (staff and professors alike).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros:
Great School
Great Location
Beautiful Campus
Fair Course Offerings
Good Commuting Options
Excellent Opportunity to meet other students and co-workers
cons: Courses that I was looking for were often cancelled, probably because I was in a multi-disciplinary program.  Fellow students had excellent luck with their advisors but I did not work on the same wave-length as my PI and that lead to difficulty in coordinating efforts for projects and papers.

pros: Excellent caliber of teaching instruction, which made it being a TA and grader very satisfying.  Administrative staff were very friendly and easy to work with.  I would highly recommend working for the business school at UW.
cons: It's such a huge organization and it makes you feel very small.  However, the people that you work directly with are extremely fair and supportive.

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Seattle, WA
pros: time flexible , relax environment, nice co-workers
cons: routine work, less career development opportunity for future career.

review_title: Positive experience since the beginning; almost 10 years.
pros: Work/life balance opportunities, great benefits, supportive leadership with realistic vision and considered implementation plan. Also, a lot of interesting and cutting edge research going on.
cons: As many mention, the salary range is a bit below market, though once all the benefits of working at UW are considered, including living in the PNW, I don't feel it's much of an issue.

review_title: Excellent Genome Sciences Department in a wonderful, beautiful city
pros: Seattle is an amazing, vibrant city. The Genome Sciences Department is top of its class in the world. The grad program there loves its students and takes care of them every step of the way.
cons: The GS building is off from the rest of the campus so I never learned much of the other departments, even related ones.

pros: Excellent staff and a great community to be a part of. This is a first rate research and educational institution, and I am glad to be a member of its community.
cons: None that I can think of. There are often times when I found the management a bit slow in getting back to me on critical questions, but this has never been a major issue.

pros: UW is an awesome place to work. Your surrounded by smart people. They have lots of research labs and interesting things going on.
cons: I found it somewhat difficult to work and collaborate across different departments. The resources available to one may not be accessible to another.

pros: fantastic benefits,  excellent work/life balance. The school i work in has a wonderful work culture; that doesn't necessarily apply across campus.
cons: Academia isn't built to support staff career growth - it's about supporting the work of faculty and students. As a result, you really have to advocate for yourself and manage up if you want to find growth opportunities.

pros: Working with Aero/Astro students can be rewarding. About two thirds of the professors are good.
cons:
Aero/Astro Dept leadership since 2015 has caused nothing but problems, including huge staff turnover. They caused $1M+ in dept budget deficits that had to be dealt with in summer 2017. To deal with it, Aero/Astro gift money was wiped out, any research money not restricted by law was wiped out, and the College covered the rest which spoils internal goodwill for years. The dept is now under staffed and poorly resourced. For 3 years, leadership has made wildly unrealistic claims about millions of dollars of new gift money being promised by corporations, etc., but the department reputation is now so bad that even typical 10k or 20k amounts from traditional sources is in question. Staff who made fundraising and outreach happen are among those that dept leadership has driven away.
Shouting is often heard through the door of professor's office who is in the main leadership role.
Several ethics reports have been made and upheld, which made leadership persons angrier, while the main UW administration does not really have the manpower to do anything about that.
Besides the professors in leadership positions, about one third of the professors are difficult since they do not manage their research programs well or try to impose on staff things like grant proposal processing right at deadlines.  The same professors cause problems over and over. They get more pushy and rude over the years and blame staff behind their backs.

review_title: Work is phenomenal, pay is not
pros: The quality of research here and opportunities are outstanding. Collaborations are welcomed and even facilitated.
cons: This is largely dependent on the lab and changes from a PI to PI basis, but as an amalgam of my experience as well as those of friends I can say that the quality of research at this institution is phenomenal, but compensation is minimal, even within academia.

review_title: Great benefits, tough culture for staff
job_title: Continuing Education Coordinator in Seattle, WA
pros: The insurance and time off are great for professional staff. Commuting is relatively convenient if using transit or the Burke-Gilman to get to campus.
cons: Single-car commutes are discouraged and parking is expensive. There is a culture of staff being looked down on by faculty, event when staff members have advanced degrees and are scholars in their own right.

review_title: Lead Cashier at the District Market
pros: Wonderful coworkers, good pay and benefits, small discount on food

review_title: Not the same as UW Seattle or Bothell
pros:
UW Tacoma has been trying very to bring in great talent to this campus to turn in around. Kuddos to the recruitment team. the problem is, the retention of these talents due to subpar academic institution environment including support of mainstream educational philosophies implemented at many progressive universities. 

Many separate schools/units/departments have been able to change their cultural for the better (Milgard School of Business; Academic Affairs; School of Engineering and technology); but the entire campus as a whole is divided and not moving towards the same direction. 

The Chancellor and Vice Chancellors are top notch; although their vision and power is limited to reporting to the main UW campus in Seattle (UW Tacoma is considered a satellite and thus does not have authority to make some critical decisions; often having to check in with what is known as "The Mothership.")
cons:
Outlook is grim for this campus; mostly due to individuals who believes that this is the "University of Tacoma" and not the University of Washington Tacoma. If you are looking at serving students so they can be global citizens, this is not the place for you. You will be locked into preparing students for a region that does not have the economic or educational mobility to succeed against students from other institutions. Theories and practices common are dated, like 1990's dated.

This campus, especially within Student Affairs is riddled with problems that stems back to days when two division were combined into one; which lead to animosity among "team members" as many upper level management were cut. This combine with subpar hiring of "leaders" who have no experience in higher education or clear vision/direction for their units have lead to frustration and often horrible customer service to students. When division leaders have to read a book on customer service, that is a red flag. Many students transfer after a quarter/year to the other two UW campuses as they feel that the service they are getting is subpar; and they are correct. 

As students are transferring and choosing other schools, retention rate for this campus is low; which leads to budget cuts; which leads to lay-offs. Be sure to ask how you are funded (State; Student Fees; Grant), as this will greatly determine if you are inline to be cut if budget is an issue. 

This is not a progressive environment, where students and staff are faced with microaggression constantly. It is so bad that a campus climate survey had to be conducted. Mid-level management lacks the skills to be fair and handle personnel issues, and often favors individuals. HR is useless, as they have to report to the main campus, and incompetent with investigation or taking issues seriously. 

My advice to you as an long time higher education professional, take your talent to the other UW campuses or another institution. Your future self will thank you. If you are starting out your career in higher education, start here and leave after a year as competition for positions are not competitive and rarely based on qualifications.

Compensation is below average. Think small non-profit level. I think the only good thing is that when the clock hits 5, everybody just leaves as they don't care. 

This is one of those higher education institution that is very likely to go bankrupt and close within the next 5 years, I've seen the financial numbers.

pros: Very interesting job, good learning experience, encouraging environment, reasonable work-life balance
cons: No real opportunities to grow. You can stay in the same position all your life. Hierarchies are not respected or acknowledge by some of the managers.

pros: Work 40-hours per week, activities on campus, nice/lively campus
cons: Pays 20-50% lower than Seattle companies. Director positions paid twice as much as direct reports, which is not in line with employee contributions. Slow/unrewarding pace.

review_title: Great place to work and learn
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great to learn and meet great people. Environment is friendly and relaxing. You can find all kind of resources for your need to build a good and strong carrer
cons: Long hours of work, fast paced, working on weekends but this is all based on how you want to get your work done.

pros: The people and the  research projects are generally interesting.  There is some top notch research going on here.  Also you can take classes for free.
cons: The pay tends to be low and the hours long.  This is pretty standard for research, though, and I do not see anywhere else being different.

review_title: Great place to learn and grown
pros: Opportunity to move up. Tons of opportunities to better yourself through classes and training. I have felt very supported in my role.
cons: Policies and procedures can be ridiculously confusing, but its a state job so I should expect that

pros: Excellent environment to work in.  Great variety in daily experiences.  High satisfaction from helping patients and liaising and mediating between them, families and hospital staff and clinicians.  Stimulating to work with many different medical professionals.
cons: Lack of adequate career growth possibilities.

pros: The School of Music is a small department, so working for the Advising Office gave me the change to know nearly all of the student body, and I had the opportunity to consult the advisor about my student status whenever it was convenient.
cons: There is no window in the front advising office

pros: The University is a stable place to work for. Benefits are good with medical, dental, and vision. Some flexibility in work schedule.
cons: There is no consistency across departments and how employees are treated and managed. No real oversight from the University on this. Some departments pay employees well while others take advantage of their staff.

pros: I was a student employee and worked at the HUB Events & Information Services for 3 years. It was one of the best jobs I had and it prepared me for my full-time roles post-graduation. All the full-time staff were super kind and always very flexible for the students.
cons: None! I loved my student job!

review_title: University of Washington - It's a good place to work
job_title: Assistant to the Director in Seattle, WA
pros: It's a big institution and there's lots opportunity for you to grow.
cons: It's a big institution and it's mired in policies and procedures.

job_title: Research Scientist III in Seattle, WA
pros: Beautiful campus, great benefits, working with and developing upcoming youth, some fantastic personalities around campus.
cons: The "academic discount" in pay, salary increase freezes, continuing budget cuts, low levels of engagement outside of the job.

review_title: Great place to work. Crappy upper management in UW Medicine.
pros: Beautiful campus, great benefits, good colleagues,
cons: people at the top have no clue esp in UW Medicine. The dean is cocooned by his inner circle and remains out of touch with the excellent work force.

pros: Cheap bus pass available, reasonably priced health insurance with vision and dental, university eventually contributes to your retirement account
cons: Seattle cost of living has been rising steadily since I've gotten here whereas postdoc salaries are still at standard NIH rates, there is no contribution to your retirement plan while on an NRSA, health insurance isn't great

job_title: Research Scientist IV in Seattle, WA
pros: Flexibility of hours is nice as research depending on the field can be quite inconsistent. It's also nice to have a position similar to a professor, but without the graduate students, or hard requirement of teaching/student advising.
cons: Severely underpaid for an experienced, academic researcher despite the known differences between the private sector and the university setting.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: Good experience, networking opportunities, flexible hours, good location and neighborhood, access to entrepreneurial resources, exciting and flexible job duties, great city
cons: No bonus/tips, no perks, no job security. Limited promotion opportunities. Postdoctoral appointments are often times a transitional stage for those who seek academic positions. Thus all the cons are typical and kinda expected.

pros: The department I'm in offers a flexible schedule. Overall, the UW is a friendly and progressive place and offers good benefits (matching 401K for professional staff).
cons: Parking is terrible and expensive. A parking pass is $150/month. If you have access to the light rail, it's a great way to commute. The UPASS is $80/quarter.
